story:
ALEP - À.ELLES.EUX.PAIX

Le cadre
Ce recueil n’est pas un ouvrage nostalgique de la « belle époque » de la ville, ni un traité diplomatique sur les négociations, ni un état des lieux des forces militaires sur place. C’est une photographie d’Alep aujourd’hui, avec les peurs des uns et les espoirs des autres…
Le coup de projecteur d’Ammar Abd Rabbo, photographe syrien à la renommée internationale, est d’autant plus précieux qu’il porte un regard à la fois personnel et tendre sur la ville phare de son pays, l'une des plus vieilles villes du monde à avoir été constamment habitée (depuis le VIe millénaire av. J.-C.) grâce à son emplacement stratégique des points de vue militaire et commercial entre la mer Méditerranée et la Mésopotamie. D'ailleurs, le centre de la ville a été classé au patrimoine mondial de l'humanité par l'Unesco en 1986. Ce centre-ville est aujourd’hui en ruines.

ALEP À.ELLES. EUX.PAIX, est dédié à tous les habitants de cette sublime ville.

 

Les contributeurs
Christophe Boltanski: journaliste, écrivain et chroniqueur français, lauréat du prix Femina 2015 pour son roman « La cache ». Il s’est rendu en reportage en 2012 à Alep.
Edith Bouvier: journaliste indépendante, elle a été blessée et bloquée pendant plusieurs jours à Homs en couvrant le conflit syrien. Auteur de «  Chambre avec vue sur la guerre » (Éditions Flammarion). Elle s’est rendue en reportage en 2014 à Alep.
Nora Charabati Joumblatt: d’origine syrienne, elle est la présidente du Festival de Beiteddine et du « Children Cancer Center Lebanon ».  Également fondatrice de l’ONG libanaise « Kayany » (2013) qui a pour but de scolariser les enfants syriens. Sept écoles ont déjà vu le jour. Née à Damas, Nora Charabati Joumblatt est « Aleppine de cœur ».
Magyd Cherfi: chanteur, écrivain et acteur français d'origine algérienne, membre du groupe toulousain « Zebda ». Magyd Cherfi a donné des concerts dans les années 1990 à Alep.
Jean-Pierre Filiu: universitaire français, historien et arabisant, spécialiste de l'Islam contemporain et  diplomate en Syrie. Il s’est rendu plusieurs fois à Alep dans les années 1990 puis plus récemment en 2013, et a effectué une visite marquante suite à laquelle il a publié « Je vous écris d’Alep » (Éditions Denoël).
Nicolas Hénin: grand reporter indépendant (Le Point, Arte) et journaliste d’investigation, auteur de « Jihad Academy » (Éditions Fayard, 2015) et de « La France russe- Enquête sur les réseaux Poutine » (Éditions Fayard, 2016). Il a été retenu en otage à Alep en 2014.
Salam Kawakibi: politologue d'origine syrienne et directeur adjoint de l'Initiative de réforme arabe. Ancien directeur de l'Institut français du Proche-Orient, à Alep.
Marie Seurat: épouse de Michel Seurat, sociologue et chercheur au CNRS, mort à 37 ans en captivité. Née à Alep où elle a passé son enfance, elle est l’auteur de l’ouvrage « Les corbeaux d'Alep », (Éditions Gallimard, 1989).
Camille de Rouvray: enseignante de Français Langue Étrangère (FLE). Lauréate du prix Panorama des idées « Grand récit » 2015 pour son livre « Quitter Alep en guerre » (Éditions Bord de L’eau, 2014). Elle a vécu et travaillé à Alep de 2009 à 2012.

 

L’objectif
Nous avons besoin de 10 000 USD afin que ce projet voie le jour. Le préfinancement paiera la production, l'impression (1 000 exemplaires) et le lancement du livre. L’argent  collecté permettra la réalisation d’un très bel ouvrage. À noter que 8 % de la somme iront dans la part de contribution à reverser à Indiegogo.
Si la somme demandée est dépassée, le surplus permettra d'augmenter le tirage du livre et/ou de mettre en route la version anglaise également en gestation.
En adhérant à notre formule de prévente du livre pour le prix préférentiel de 33 USD au lieu de 38 USD vous contribuerez ainsi à assurer la faisabilité de ce projet dont le lancement est prévu pour décembre.
Cette levée de fonds est une manière efficace de faire connaître cette publication  au plus grand nombre de personnes possible et de la préfinancer.

 

Derrière l’objectif
Qui est Ammar Abd Rabbo ?
Ammar Abd Rabbo est un journaliste et photographe français et syrien, né à Damas. Il a vécu à Tripoli (Libye) et à Beyrouth (Liban) avant de s'installer en France à l'âge de douze ans. Ancien élève de “Sciences Po” (IEP Paris), il a travaillé depuis 1990 avec de nombreuses agences internationales comme Sygma, Sipa Press, Abaca Press, et c’est un collaborateur régulier de l’Agence France Press (AFP).
En plus de vingt-cinq ans de reportages photographiques, il a couvert aussi bien les coulisses des concerts de Michael Jackson que les inondations causées par l'ouragan « Katrina » à la Nouvelle-Orléans (2005), ou encore la guerre en Irak (2003), au Liban (2006) ou les révolutions arabes en Libye (2011) et à Alep, en Syrie, en 2013 et 2014.
Il a signé plus d'une soixantaine de couvertures de magazines très différents comme Paris Match, Der Spiegel, Le Point, L’Express…
Noir Blanc Et Caetera , qui sommes-nous ?
« Noir Blanc Et Caetera » est la dernière-née des maisons d’éditions au Liban. Elle se propose d’être innovatrice dans son domaine, à savoir proposer à l’auteur un maximum d’avantages et lui donner un droit de regard sur son ouvrage, depuis sa conception jusqu’à son impression.
C’est une maison qui fait de la résistance culturelle dans un pays où s’exprimer librement devient de plus en plus difficile.
Fondée en 2012, “Noir Blanc Et Caetera” a déjà plus de 20 publications à son actif. De nombreux projets sont en cours pour 2016 et 2017.

 

Zoom sur le format:

Dimensions: 21x23 cm.
Broché: 104 pages en couleurs.
Couverture rigide.

 

Développement:
# Début novembre 2016 : fin de l'appel au pré-achat sur Indiegogo.
# Fin novembre : production et impression du livre au Liban.
# Début décembre : livraison des ouvrages commandés. Pour les achats effectués au Liban, vous pouvez choisir de récupérer votre ouvrage lors de la signature qui aura lieu en décembre.
# En décembre : lancement du livre au Liban – Organisation de plusieurs rencontres et dédicaces – Livre en vente en ligne sur www.noirblancetc.com
# À partir de janvier 2017 : lancement du livre ALEP À.Elles.Eux.Paix en France - Organisation de rencontres et dédicaces.

 

Les grandes aventures commencent toutes par un petit pas. Merci de relayer ce message autour de vous afin que cette chaîne d’entraide soit rapidement bouclée et que « ALEP À.ELLES.EUX.PAIX » voie le jour.

story:
Short Summary

About the Book

Here’s a brief introduction to my book, The Time Traveller’s Resort and Museum. I hope you like it.

“If you need to know men's secrets

Or if there's something you need to find

If you want to see the dinosaurs

Or the insides of your mind.

If you want to watch the earth begin,

Or see what the apocalypse will leave behind,

You need to thank Alice Anderson,

For Alice is the mother of time.”

That was how the rhyme went. Every time traveler knew it. Everyone that is, except of course, for Alice herself, since she hadn’t invented time travel yet. Since returning to London, Alice’s life has been turned upside down. She’s been accused of murder and lost her position in the scientific community. Her only ally in this journey is a strange man who seems to think that Alice may be about to open up a strange new world of possibilities, but is probably not telling her everything he knows.

Obviously fake quotes made up by the author for the purpose of filling up space on the back of the book.

“The torch has been passed to a weird generation.”

John F Kennedy

“I remember the time David came over for drinks. ‘Twas the best of times, it ‘twas the worst of times.’ No, wait, it was just the worst of times. By the by, what exactly is ‘Tequila?’’”

Charles Dickens

 “The first time I met David, he told me how much he liked my book. I said “Which one?” and he said “Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.” It sort of went downhill from there.”

Jane Austen

About Us

David McLain graduated from Purchase College, where he directed a production of William Shakespeare’s The Tempest. He is the author of the novels The Life of a Thief, and Dragonbait.  His short fiction has appeared in over two dozen magazines. You can read his blog about his dog at mydogisgross.tumblr.com

Felix Eddy Graduated Magnum Cum Laude from Alfred University. She is the author of A Bestiary Alphabet, and has illustrated several books. You can see more of her artwork at www.felixeddy.com 

What We'll Be Doing With the Funds We Raised. 

Spending it. (Seriously, do I have to explain this? Our house burned down this year. No, I'm not kidding.) We do about thirty shows a year, up and down the east coast, of the Art, Comic Con, and Steampunk Variety. The money goes toward helping us spread the love of everything we do, which ultimately increases the value of every book that you buy. 

Stretch Goals

1000.00- If we hit the goal, I will raffle off at least one of each prize to everyone who has donated to the campaign, with the exception of the original book cover. This means, that if you donate to the cause at any level, you can force me to write out the entire novel, in pen, and then, if you want, burn it in the fire while laughing at me. Or you could get one of Felix’s paintings. Whichever.

1500.00- If we hit the big 1-5, I'll raffle off at least one prize from to everyone who has donated to the campaign. Also, I'll pay the mortgage. I can't begin to tell you what a big deal that is.

story:
Our big goal is $100 million! If it is collected within the first three days, $500 of pledges will immediately be spent on spreading the word for this campaign! Additionally, 10% of all pledges collected within the first three days will also go towards advertisement for this project!!!

 

Regardless of whether this project reaches its financing goal or not, each of our supporters will receive an e-book for their reading pleasure and a special web certificate within a month of supporting us.

 

You can read the first twenty pages of the novel below!

 

Greetings, dear friends!

I know what you’re thinking. “This guy is out of his mind, setting a goal like that!” Please, read on, and you’ll see I’m not *that* crazy. ;)

Who am I? Just an ordinary guy with a big dream. Don’t they say that you’re as big as your dreams? Something like that, anyway ;)

My name is Dobromir Ivanov, though I tend to write under the pen name of Dob Vans. I am a classically trained musician; I play the viola. I worked in an opera theater for fifteen years, and I currently own a small business while I make different kinds of art. I live in Bulgarian, Europe, and am fully aware of how difficult it is to publish stuff written by an author from such a small country, even if they specifically have the western reading audience in mind. In the novel at hand, there is nothing bound by region or conviction. Well, perhaps just a gentle whiff of my home country.

***

Dear friends,

Since my end goal is colossal - $100 million to finance the creation of a high-budget film adaptation of PLANET SHIP 1 – PREDATORY FOG – I will need to be backed by quite a lot of people. So, to better reach a wider audience, some of which may kindly and graciously become backers, I will need to popularize my idea. The more people come across this project, the more likely it is that it will gain more supporters and backers.
So, in one project, I’ve separated the pledge options into two. The SMALL project aims to gather traction for the BIG project, which I have described below. Those of you who believe in the success of this project and back me within the first three days after the project launch date will receive a special perk – a digitized version of one of my paintings, signed for the respective SPECIAL BACKER.

First, I’d like to thank each and every one of you from the bottom of my heart – I thank all of you who decide to back and share my project with friends! I want you to know that, if we, you and me, manage to turn my novel  PLANET SHIP 1 – PREDATORY FOG into a big blockbuster movie, you will have been the main reason for this being possible!! Thank you all!
 

 

 

PREDATORY FOG is the first novel of the PLANET SHIP series and features everything a big Hollywood production requires. The plot is highly dynamic, the characters are varied and interesting, and, naturally, there are plenty of twists and turns. You’ll get to see future tech the likes of which have not been featured in science fiction. Espionage, adventure, genuine human relationships, love, war, breathtaking space vistas, colossal construction projects and new, amazing weaponry. Galactic skirmishes, arena fights between people with muscles of iron and artificial creatures. The novel has been written as a, if you will, glimpse into the future. That is, it treats fiction as a plausible progression of what we know to be true. This piece of science fiction is as much about science as it is about humanity.

The plot spans some five-hundred pages, taking place around the year 2569. Humanity has spread to six planets throughout the galaxy, yet, its innate adventurous spirit drives it to search for ever greater and faster means of travel and more ways of conquering the Universe. A genius inventor comes up with a way to achieve just that – a planet, which can function as an enormous space vessel. However, evil forces lead by a fanatical dictator will aggressively intervene and seek to take over the greatest achievement of the united human species. Only an individual of unique qualities and abilities can help neutralize the space-faring threat. But where can such an individual be found? How is he or she to be recruited for the noble cause?

From the very beginning, I thought of the book, and eventually wrote it, as a dramatized movie script. While I worked on it, I could picture the various scenes – real, fleshed out, as if they were happening right in front of my eyes. This is why the chapters are usually short and lead into one another like quick film edits.

The book is not intended only for fans of the Sci-Fi genre. A number of my friends, all from different walks of life, interests and social strata have thus far read and like it quite a bit.

This is not just science fiction. It is my best guess as to what things will be like fife hundred years into the future in all facets of life. In its pages, readers will encounter a veritable bubbling volcano of relationships, passion and real characters – love, hate, friendship, betrayal, hypocrisy, lies, naivety, lust for power, despotism, manipulativeness and subordination, ambition and domination, treachery and honesty, willingness to suffer and egoism. All fundamental components of a society, regardless of whether we locate said society in medieval times, today, or a couple of centuries in the future.

You may ask, “Why not publish it back home?” Well, that’s something of a tall order in my country, unless, of course, you’ve already established yourself and have stable financial backing. And, as I said, the novel is meant for a global audience. Ideally, there will be copies of it from the North Pole all the way down to Antarctica. Publishing houses here don’t have the resources for that sort of thing, and there aren’t many agencies who introduce local authors internationally. I was told that western publishers aren’t really all that interested in authors from my general geographic whereabouts. I have no clue why. Is it the way locals have presented themselves on the international stage or because of some prejudice? Honestly, I don’t know, but that publishing employee turned out to be right. I wrote to a few big agencies, but I never heard back. I’m no Stephen King or Michael Chrichton. Definitely no Donald Trump or Putin. I actually have no idea how an agency chooses their clients based on a short letter and (when they *do* ask for a text sample) ten or so pages of a novel. Whether a person is popular or not is definitely part of the equation. Sometimes I wonder how many great works are just gathering dust in the dusky drawers of their creators?!

Meanwhile, I approached a major documentary network about possibly creating a killer of an ad film based on my novel, since their name, logo design, activity can be a notable element in the production. It was in there, in the plot, a key component from the very beginning. I was told that such a venture was “not part of their programming plans.” I even tried to contact Elon Musk, since he is obviously a visionary, dreamer, and citizen of the cosmos in general, to try and introduce him to my book, but to no avail. Same thing with Neil deGrasse Tyson. I wrote to the Bulgarian representatives of a big film and TV production corporation – no response. I could go on, but I trust the point has been made.

This is where I should clarify why I’m not seeking to self-publish via physical media. It’s simple. If I set a goal of $5,000 and reach that, I could print (at a price of  $10 per copy) five hundred copies! I’d need more just to thank my backers! Let’s say I set a much higher goal and succeed? How would that benefit my future development? Isn’t that what crowdfunding is for? Do I need to reimagine myself and qualify as my novel’s production line? What market should I aim it at? How do I deal with delivery etc. That, I believe, should be left to the professionals, while the creators… create away.

And so, I’m aiming high. My dream is to have a big Hollywood movie made on the basis of my novel, and I’m certain that no major studio would scoff at a $100,000,000. That, in my mind, is the budget required for a worthwhile production. Also, I’m not just going to give that money away to a studio. Even if I’m not a producer per se, I’m definitely taking an active part in the creative process for my novel’s adaptation.

My dear future backers, this project might seem unfeasible, even delusional, I know. Yet, I am convinced that a belief in oneself is the first step to accomplishing ANY task. There is a saying in Bulgaria, which roughly translates into “gathered and united, people can even lift a mountain.” In other words, unity makes strength. Take on the challenge so that we can all be proud of our common deed! Share the project with your friends, let us be the driving force behind a fearsome wave of creative life force. When George Lucas made the original Star Wars, he had no notion of how successful his passion project would become. He must have stood at the door of the movie theater after that first projection, waiting to examine the expressions on the faces of the departing patrons. How deeply excited he must have been to see them not departing, but lining up again to buy another ticket!

I believe that you’re here not to simply buy another book. I know that you want to greenlight human creativity, so that more pieces that result from that creativity may belong to humanity, even if that means opposing those who are in control of humanity’s resources. Each of you will be rewarded with a little piece that will hopefully remain with you as a monument to generosity. Most important of all, you will be left with the indelible knowledge of having made possible something awesome!

The novel wasn’t written with 7.5 billion people in mind. Some of you, after you back the project and receive your copies will, no doubt, not find it to your liking. What I hope, though, is that you’ll enjoy supporting a wacky dreamer who dares meddle in the world of the all-mighty players and hopes to change it for the better, even if it’s just a tiny, tiny change.

I am fully cognizant of what it means to undertake such a project, and I truly believe that it will be successful world-wide. After all, I’m not going into this all alone. I am beyond certain that among those reading this, there is a sufficient number of kindred spirits and supporters. I’d just like to say, at this point, thank you!

I’ve not been alone up to this point during all my years in the creative netherworld. There are a number of people, my friends, without whose help and support this project would not be possible. I would like to express my unending gratitude to my most selfless supporters.

The boy was playing in the sandbox in front of the apartment building. His father observed him – the smile on his face twitching in an unconscious impulse of pride and tenderness. His son had constructed a couple of sand hills, apparently a proxy for the glorious palace in the boy's mind. The child rose and glanced at his father, whose entire being exuded a kind of singular sense of triumph. The boy stretched out with his hands, laughed in anticipation of the father's approval, but was too late. The man stood up from the bench and started forward, arms stretched out as well. As he walked, a dark shadowy mass came in and dimmed the sunlight. He looked up and froze on the spot; his face contorted in a grimace of horror. The flying object obstructing the sun hovered, immobile, above the open areas between the apartment buildings. The boy followed his father's gaze and immediately turned to him with bewildered, questioning eyes. Before the father could move even slightly, a lightning-white flash struck him. The man turned gray, much like concrete, and was literally rendered into stone in seconds – then fell apart into countless tiny particles. What seemed like grains of fine sand settled on the concrete slab the man had been standing on. The boy just stood there, confused. His eyes filled with tears as he started to sob and look around. There was no soul in sight; he was all alone amid the palpable workday afternoon silence. He looked up. The sun's rays caressed his cheeks glistening with teardrops. Once again he focused on the small pile of sand on the playground. He leaned down, took his bucket and toy spade, approached, tripping and stumbling along the way, knelt and began collecting his father's ashes.

 

 

PART ONE

GHOSTLY AID

 

 

            1.Professor Alexander Belk was so amazed at the idea that had just bloomed in his mind that he nearly spilled his coffee. It was early in the afternoon on December 10, 2569 of the Standard Interplanetary Calendar. In what constituted a small wonder, the Professor was currently enjoying a brief period of no meetings or arrangements, so he made the most of his break out in the open air. He sat alone at a table in the café overseeing the Third strait of Swan city, enjoying the gentle sunshine of the local star Lan. His thoughts fired rapidly, flowing into each other like dissimilar layers of fog and mist. He pictured the lecture hall, full of students, not much younger than himself. Then he dove into deep thought about how necessary it was for him to finally stir up his monotonous, orderly scholar being by means of the affections of some interesting young lass. He then decided to leave such burdensome contemplation behind and let himself focus on what he loved most – fantasizing about space exploration, the future of civilization, even considering the notion of universal dissemination of the human species. The last subject was something he came back to quite often. No, it couldn't be done with ships. Even if said ships could house hundreds of thousands of individuals. The distances which had to be traversed and the amounts of time that would take were so great that no artificially-manufactured society of beings would be able to cope without succumbing to self-annihilation. What is more, nothing could justify using the newly-discovered engine technology, known only to a small number of scientists and high-ranking politicians on Arfinia, in a simple space-faring vessel. The so-called space-warper was a discovery of colossal importance; producing an actual working engine based on the technology would take immense resources, the likes of which even his own homeland would not be able to spare, in spite of being the most powerful state on all six habitable planets.

            Alex tasted his coffee as he reached this point in his contemplation and … The image came to him without warning, striking and clear. Not just an idea, but an entirely functional system of analysis, concept, and implementation. His hands twitched but Alex overcame the urge without spilling a single drop of the precious fragrant liquid. He looked around, saw nobody was paying attention and stood up. He leaned on the railings and gazed into the wave-like structure of the strait splitting the continent in two. He took in a few breaths of fresh air, looked wistfully at the emerald-green sky of Grenaira, sighed a sigh of affirmation and set his body phone to dial mode. The cerebral impulses of the answering party responded, but there was no voice on the line. Probably not the best time or place to talk, yet listening was obviously an option. Alex smiled, his face taking on a provocative expression. He caressed his stubble and declared triumphantly, "Planet ships! But, don't mind me, please, carry on with your ever-so-important affairs of state, he-he-he ..."

 

            2. Timothy Shevchenko sat at the Round table where the Interplanetary Council of leaders was holding session. The place chosen for the meeting was a middling hall some ten floors above the Mahmuldar congress center, Mahmuldar being the leading state on the planet Saa. On this specific occasion it was Timothy's go at representing Grenaira. He was selected from a pool of the seven presidents of Arfinia and leaders of other, smaller states. Earth's representative had been speaking when Timothy received the call. He waited, rather impatiently, for the speech to be over, so as to make use of the small break window that would follow.

            He retired to the room assigned to him and immediately activated his holographic monitor to contact Belk. The Professor popped up on the screen, grinning a ridiculously wide grin.

            "Quite the meeting, I take it?" he stated inquisitively.

            "Young man, have you thought this through?" Shevchenko started, not skipping a beat. "Or are you just keeping yourself busy and wasting my time with science fiction?"

            "Through? I haven't thought at all," the Professor added, maintaining his upbeat delivery, "the whole thing just materialized in my head. The whole system, Mr. President, a completed project, down to the smallest detail."

            "You believe it would be feasible for us to execute?"

            "Depends on what you mean by us."

            "Right, so we can't do it alone. Hm, a planet ship you say, Al?"

            "A planet ship."

            "Quite the idea. Probably in the quadrillion ballpark..."

            "More like quintillion, Tim."

 

            3. The dissemination of humans was not a new idea. The subject had been considered current ever since Homo sapiens had taken its first steps and haughtily looked down upon all other creatures roaming the African plains of its homeworld. Not long after, at least on the immensely grand scale of time itself, the nascent species conquered and populated its planet. It was not enough, however, and humans looked up at the stars. In 2171 a human astronaut stepped on a habitable alien planet for the first time. This opened the proverbial floodgates for the little green planet. Grenaira became humanity's second home. Slowly but surely, space exploration went further and further, and throughout the centuries, thousands of ships criss-crossed the galaxy, discovering ever more twins of old Earth. The number of human beings grew incessantly, and there was no lack of enthusiastic volunteers who wanted to settle, start anew, throw away the shackles of one gravity index for another. Regardless of the motives of any single individual, by the end of the 25th century human civilization consisted of six planets, perfectly suited for life, as well as hundreds of less hospitable colonies which provided an endless supply of valuable natural resources, built upon sparsely populated asteroids and planetoids.

            And even though there was sufficient space for billions more humans on these worlds, even though they could feed many generations to come, even though the members of the societies there could traverse distances, which just a few hundred years prior might have seemed unthinkable, to visit their brethren from light-years away, there were, nevertheless, people who never stopped dreaming of taming more of the frontier. Just like the man who had constructed the first raft and sailed Earth's oceans to colonize another continent, there were modern humans who dreamed of building ships to lead humanity to other galaxies. Nobody had gone beyond the Milky Way as of yet. That is, unless one believed the numerous myths and legends of astronaut folklore.

            Some insisted that man had not yet matured enough to travel the distances between galaxies, and that such a thing could not happen before humanity developed into whatever evolution had in store for it. Others were convinced that very thing had already happened. Or just about, at least. They claimed a transitional species had existed for a long time – a species worthy of investing one's hopes in, capable of making that great leap – Cyborgs.

            Actually, in that period during the second half of the 26th century a great deal of humans could be classified as such as well, in spite of most not accepting or approving of it. They thought it brought them lower somehow, to be nothing more than an ordinary robot, a construct, not that dissimilar to some household appliance, a vacuum cleaner or what have you. Yet, they had no reason to be ashamed of what they were. The scientific advances of cybernetics had made it possible to elevate the species. It was not just that human beings became sick less often and lived twice as long as their 21st century counterparts; they could enhance the scope and abilities of their very intellect. Those who chose to have their heart replaced, their skeletal framework strengthened, or have their mental capacity increased via artificial additions, were not in any way opposed to these improvements. Still, they did not wish to be referred to as cyborgs. And with good reason, too; a simple explanation that was evident and valid on its own merit. That reason was the Cyborg Society.

            In the beginning, hundreds of years ago, it was not a true organization. More of a club of extravagant, eccentric individuals from different parts of the worlds. They were proud of the chips and circuits they integrated into their bodies to "shine the way for science", as they usually phrased it. As centuries passed, installing internal components and adding external ones into the human biology became mass practice. Post-2550, body modules were manufactured from predominantly organic materials and could scarcely be differentiated from natural organs. Almost, that is, as every scanner contrasted the two like puddles of water in the sand. Of course, nobody wanted to conceal the presence of such acquisitions as it was no different from having an artificial tooth in the old days. However, throughout the entirety of the history of cybernetics, there were those individuals who paraded their more advanced and costlier physical and mental enhancements, looking down on the common man.

            Gradually, people who liked the title of cyborg created their own organized hierarchical structure. They considered themselves superior to humans, apparently fancied themselves an entirely new species. Bit by bit, they began to stray from the rest of humanity, started to gather in their own groups and parties, finally forming a wholly separate society. One of Cyborgs, the Cyborg Society. Later on, they would leave behind the "gravitational confines", as they called planets, and live aboard their city ships. Only a small amount of humans were aware of this, while the masses were blissfully oblivious to such goings-on. They knew of the Society in as much as they knew they were not part of it and its unfounded claims of superiority. What business was it of theirs that there was this faction, imaginary or not, of peculiar and pathologically-deviant minds, thank you very much!

 

            4. Tsar Fog de Berg sat in his private upgrade clinic. The Doctor added the final lubial neuron, connected it to the synapses and psychodorms by means of a microbiosuture and, satisfied with his work, smiled at the Ruler. He, in turn, frowned in approval, and the Doctor applied the new strip of enhancing cortex tissue. Then he reattached the bone, fixed the scalp and irradiated the area with a ciffisian lamp to let the tissue grow back. Yet another regal cerebral upgrade was completed. De Berg smiled, seemingly at himself. Now he truly possessed the most powerful intellect in known space. He looked at himself in the mirror. Handsome too! Such a broad, manly brow. Now his head was worth over a trillion arfins (or Bergs, Fog corrected himself), not counting the unquantifiable aesthetic value it held. The best part was only he could make use of it, so no one would be tempted to take it away from him. Tsar Fog de Berg was so content that he did not even allow for the possibility of there being someone, who, like that, for the hell of it, would like to just blow up this jewel of the biocybernetic medical arts. Yet, he reminded himself that some devious foe could potentially break into the tacit corner of his artificial memory. That was only possible with the competent aid of the very physician who completed the update, who, as it happened, was just taking off his operating gown. The Tsar sighed in utter vexation and demolecularized him right to the floor. The sanitary robot sucked up the remnants of the physician (and his illustrious career), and deposited them into the trash compartment, where they were swiftly blown into space. Disgusted, Fog rubbed away a stray ashy particle from his eye. He contemplated whether it was possible for the discarded dust to be the spark to some proto-life and its ensuing evolutionary process, should it happen upon the right planet.

 

            5. Far from all those innovative, technologically-endowed corners of space, the state of Gorania pulsed with its own steady life beats. For millennia, it had remained uncared-for in a distant corner of Europe, Earth, and ultimately, of history. The ancient country had been witness to centuries of upward and downward surges, and now, at the end of the 26th century, had subsided into lethargy, the likes of which it had not experienced even during the countless times of being annexed, conquered, and having its borders redrawn. Nobody attacked anymore, for the values they once held dear were twisted, long-gone, to be replaced by those of outsiders. Well, there were still beautiful, unsullied swaths of nature to be sure, but those could be found in many different countries, on many different planets. And so, Gorania rested in its vegetative state, somewhere along the border between the rest of Europe and the member-nations of the Eurasian Union, undisturbed in its sublime backward-mindedness.

            A scarce but tough people lived there. They had learned to survive among their peers, which was no small feat in and of itself. Goranians were accustomed to being dependent on nobody but their closest; they didn't have any newfangled technology or machinery to aid them – they either coped by primitive means or were forced to leave their country… if at all possible. Through the centuries, in times of open borders, large parts of the population left and never returned. Thus, in a few centuries, the Goranian nation dwindled by a factor of seven, down to about a million inhabitants. For this reason, among others of a domestically-political nature, the government closed the borders. Unilaterally. With kind assistance from their neighbors. Eurasia and Europe, who periodically took turns at adding it to, and then excluding it from their amorphous and often-crumbling unions, were very quick to activate their border force-fields as though they were expecting to be pounced on by their sweetly snoozing brethren.

            Still, for violist Danninger Blagostino there were new, undiscovered horizons in store. His whole life was in front of him. Danny, the name those closest to him used, was a 23-year-old, fresh out of his viola course in the Tronnian Academy of Music. He was a bit of a dreamer, so when he came back from the capital and got accepted into the philharmonic opera orchestra of his home town of Fildion, his very soul was filled with reveries and illustrious visions of the future. He would work on his interpretations of majestic pieces of art, conquer stages, as well as hearts beating within the chests of young instrument players, choristers, and... perhaps, even ballerinas?

            With some trepidation, Danninger headed for the Opera building on his first day at work. He climbed up the steps to the reception hall, all in one breath, opened the door and... froze. Behind the music-stands there stood seemingly depressed, haggard, gray old people. The bowing was languid at best, and the brass section virtually molested their instruments in a fortissimo, taking revenge for the lives they had lost in the depths of artistic wreckage in this Temple of arts. He stepped forward, shoulder slumped, approached the viola group and greeted his colleagues as they politely pointed to his chair and then resumed probing the trickier passages. He took his viola out of its case, tightened the bow and began to practice some sixteenths from the sheets in front of him. He caught one female colleague's eyes as they fixated on him from behind the music stand opposite and sensed that in her view, he was attempting to display unwarranted amounts of virtuosity, so he carried on in a softer tone. The cacophony of sounds was suddenly gone. Danny took the bow off the strings and looked around. An old man with silver hair and sallow skin approached the conductor's stand in a flowing, swan-like gait. He greeted the room almost imperceptibly, opened up the score and shifted his watery gaze up, focusing on Danninger. Had the conductor simply noticed a fresh face among the orchestra? Or was it just that his unusual height that attracted attention? He shuddered. The eyes of a snake were peering straight at him.

 

            6. All seven presidents of Arfinia only gathered once or twice a year and then only for strictly-scheduled events. Even during times of war, the last one taking place more than half a century prior, they communicated through the airwaves. Naturally, Tim Shevchenko's six colleagues were rather surprised at his request for an unscheduled face-to-face meeting. He reassured them there was nothing to worry about, that his reasons for assembling the Presidents' Council were not troubling in any way – yet, when they asked him what those reasons actually were, Tim deflected the query. They all knew their eldest colleague well; knew he would not be calling if matters were trivial. Be it with a personal airpod, presidential cosmoplane, or private plain mechanical bicycle, they all hopped to the occasion on time, and, once gathered, hugged each other as was customary. Professor Belk only received handshakes, though just as cordial. Their faces revealed genuine surprise at the presence of the cosmological tech adviser.

            "My dear colleagues, I apologize if I have disturbed your delicate engagement scheduling," Shevchenko started apologetically, yet was reassured by his colleagues' vigorous hand-waving.

            "Tim," president Florence Alberti addressed him with a smile. "I am curious as to the nature of this emergency gathering. Perhaps we should be holding a classified meeting, no associates?"

            "No, no need. The nature of this meeting is not sensitive. In fact, I believe it may well become the most transparent matter we've ever ventured to embark upon."

            "Come now, my friend, tell us," young president Janusz Cordel could hardly contain himself. "Enough with the solemn secrecy."

            "I think you should listen to Alex now. We are gathered here because of an idea of his."

            More impatient urging followed. Professor Belk, who was not accustomed to feeling tense or uncertain before high-ranking councils or committees, coughed, and the sound carried the vaguest note of hesitation. He spoke in his typical, confident manner, "I have come upon an idea that is fit for a popular fiction film. If that was my goal, ladies and gentlemen, I would be speaking before executives from Hollywood, back on Earth. I have no connections in the world of cinema, however, thus I am here, where pure reality is forged instead of fantastic entertainment. The notion I wish to present is simple. Let us turn a planet into a functional ship."

            The presidents chuckled, then stopped to think, which brought to the room the first signs of surprise, approval, and disappointment all together. Then, President Commodore Johan Svenson said earnestly, "It is an astonishing idea, Alex. I myself have considered something similar. Are we not a couple of centuries too early, however?"

            "Johan!" President Anita Hegelman interjected in disbelief. "Are you being serious?"

            "I simply appreciate the genius of the thought. It remains to be determined whether it will be at all possible. We need to listen to the Professor's reasoning first."

            "Naturally, we will, " Admiral Giancarlo Ramsi Ramsay chimed in as well. "Just so you know, in case the end result is of no military advantage, I am against it."

            "But, Giancarlo, you are not minister of defense!" Florence exclaimed. "And how can you be against anything without having familiarized yourself with it?"

            "I am expressing my opinion as I am quite familiar with Alex's thought process. He comes forward with ideas only when they benefit the peaceful exploration and taming of space."

            "What's wrong with that, then?" Johan asked, frowning.

            "Nothing per se. Although… his projects do tend to be a drain on the treasury rather than creating an influx. This is no different, isn't that right, Professor?"

            Alex smiled widely, raised his eyebrows and said jovially, "Admiral, you have always been a marvelous psychologist. You've hit the nail on the head. More so than you think. Not only would the project be likely to drain Arfinia's military finance, but it would not even be feasible without all major countries on the six planets allotting portions of their budget totals."

            Anita gasped as if she felt some sharp pain while the rest laughed. Only Timothy Shevchenko sat there akin to a bronze statue, his eyes darting around to take in the expressions of the astonished auditorium of presidents.

            "Now, I don't mean to say that I have something against this emergency meeting," Janusz broke the silence, "but what exactly is the rush?"

            "President Cordel," Alex looked at him. "I shall share something most of you aren't aware of."

            "Classified?"

            "Let us say, it has been, up until now, deemed unnecessary to waste your time with incomplete projects."

            "Just the same, let us isolate the room," Florence said confidently as she pressed the security black-out button. "So, what is this invention not worthy of our stately time?"

            "It is not an invention, but a discovery, The Discovery, if you will. We call it a space-warper…"

            "Not possible!" Johan stood up from his seat.

            "Yes, commodore," Alex smiled at him triumphantly. "It very much is. Trials indicate we can do it. We simply have to build it."

            "What are you two on about?" Anita shook her head.

            "The engine of the future," Admiral Ramsay explained in an expertly manner. "It warps space so that a ship may traverse distances currently considered unattainable. If we can build it, we would be invincible."

            "Well, that's all just fine and dandy," Janusz interrupted, staring down Alex. "My question remains. Why go about this with such urgency?"

            "The engine is so intricate that constructing it is no simple matter. It is also rather expensive. If we were to build one for an ordinary ship, it would be like… strapping an elephant to a toy cart. Or, more like a microscopic cart."

            "And since we have our unborn elephant," Roberta Hu added playfully. "We want to build a gilded carriage for it to tow?"

            "Not precisely, President Hu," Shevchenko said at last, speaking in that soft tone he had grown accustomed to during his time as a children's instructor. "Not a shining carriage fit for nobles or a yacht for the chosen few, but a sturdy, tight raft, filled with the masses, ready to extend the reach of the human species into the Universe. We must not allow this opportunity to slip through our fingers – this nation simply must construct the revolutionary engine as we are the inventors. Or worse still – we must not permit it to be built and then let it collect dust for hundreds of years in some forsaken hangar because there's no ship worthy to be powered by it. We've come up with wind... Why not build that sailboat?"

 

            7. The Cosmographic was the best channel! It was perfect for everyone interested in the Universal goings-on, as well as those who wished to further their media careers in the best way possible. To make it there you had to part with any semblance of residence and become a citizen of the cosmos. To work for Cosmographic Life, you had to denounce yourself. If you were able to come up with a hot story, however, you and your former self would be reunited, and you become king. The ruler of men's hearts, corporate lavishness and all manner of managerial perks at your disposal. Well, Lilana Strombeyer had made it to the first level when she had been appointed two months ago.

            The editor was pulling his hair out, yelling at her, nagging her constantly, over and over again in the same order. The simplicid cam operator would anxiously twitch about, but never dared defend her. And Lilana herself simply stood there, frozen not out of fear, but with astonishment – how was it that they didn't like her downright genius story? She was fully capable of plunging her fist into the editor's repulsive face, but her body was encased in restraining surprise.

            "Do you have any idea who you're working for?" the editor raged. "Does Cosmographic Life ring a bell? Do you happen to know it's the department that airs non-stop live broadcasts from space, that we're part of the most prestigious interplanetary media in the galaxy? Not just news and reports. Entire events! That's what you lot are supposed to be doing."

            "But I…"

            "You?! You, intentionally I might add, did not film a colossal natural explosion that killed two astronauts! You deprived billions of viewers of the opportunity to witness this immense tragedy. What were you thinking? Did you think you were hired to report on a routine survey of some boring planet that may or may not have kiont deposits?"

            "That's why I pointed…"

            "Yes, precisely, because you don't have the slightest idea what sensation is, you made your cameraman shoot some slimy critter crawled out of the rocks, one dying of old age! And at the same time! …"

            "You really don't get it, huh?!" Lilana erupted.

            "Uh, you better..." Her colleague attempted to intervene.

            "Enough, Rob! He…"

            "I what?" the editor leaped forward. "Did I happen to film some critter's pathetic final gasps instead of the death of two heroes?"

            "I'm truly sorry, but they weren't …"

            "You better be sorry… and stop provoking me or I'll be forced to fire you!"

            "Fine, fire me, but hear me out first."

            "Hear you out?! Get out of my sight before I kick you out with my two bare hands."

            "Wouldn't you use your feet for that?"

            "Out!"

            She looked at him like a wild tigress and turned around swiftly.       "Hey, wait, I haven't given you your next assignment yet!"

            "Is there going to be one?" She asked with a sarcastic tone without even turning her head.

            "I'll give you one last chance."

            "Where?"

            "Hard labor duty." 

             Lilana Strombeyer gave him a disgusted look, turned and stormed our proudly. Such a kind editor! That animal on that empty planet was a total darling compared to him.

 

            8. The patient lay on the operating table. His body was burned, face a bloody mess, but he was still breathing. The team of physicians was working efficiently, like a well-oiled machine. They waited while the anesthesia took effect. The nurse then proceeded to pour out a jarful of nanobots which started 'eating' away the charred dead tissue. Some five minutes later, the patient's appearance was not unlike a skinned lamb. Doctor Ashrani switched on his laser scalpel and carefully started to separate muscle tissue from the skin and chest. He did the same with the groin, but there wasn't much there left, anyway. When he was done, his assistant commenced to hand him biosynthetic collabren pieces of different sizes and shapes. The surgeon worked quickly, and in a short while, the tissue containers were nearly depleted. He took a large syringe and emptied it into the patient's heart, which caused him to stop breathing. The nurse then pressed a button, and the operating table transformed into a translucent vat. She took a nondescript tube, pointed it toward the vat and filled it with a thick, drab substance. The tiny particles, which floated around in the liquid, started to stick to the patient's body. The vat's logic circuits precisely guided the thousands of specs to the right areas so that they would cover and support the flesh, and soon they formed a see-through film. The circuit switched to a higher voltage on the substance and the patient flinched as his nerve endings connected to the freshly-formed film of skin. The process took about ten more minutes; the body was completely covered with skin, and the turgid goo in the vat slowly became clear, after which it drained away. The vat was a cot again. A short burst of electricity caused the man to recommence his breathing, the first couple of breaths abrupt and wheezy. Doctor Ashrani stuck a tiny electrode in the man's cheekbone and made a few minor adjustments to the face whose shape and color changed as if by magic. He took the needle out and gave his patient a gentle tap on the cheek. The man woke up. His doctor was smiling at him.

            "Hello there!" said the surgeon. "What is your name?"

            "Janvier Lagrange, why?"

            The Doctor took a small mirror and brought it up to the patient so he could see himself in it.

            "That's you, isn't it?" he looked at the patient inquisitively.

            "I think so."

            "And this? Or this?" the Doctor was pressing buttons, while the features of the man's face shifted with each press.

            "Oh, fuck! Is all that me?"

            "Yes."

            "And who are you?"

            "The ones who brought you back. We made a few adjustments, as per your contract. You will get used to controlling the change in a few minutes. You will be impossible to track down."

            "How... how come?"

            "You are now a transformer. Congratulations!"

 

            9. Alex and Tim said goodbye to the presidents and headed towards the exit. They walked slowly across the spacious corridors, nodded cursory nods to the vast amount of service-people they came across and spoke in subdued, quiet voices.

            "Al, you really amazed them with your idea, you know that?"

            "That is… with the utter craziness of my proposal. Hah. Tim, I wouldn't hold it against them if they don't take it very seriously. I plan on patenting the idea right away. Not that anybody is rushing to beat me to it."

            "You believe that if somebody thought of it, they wouldn't have the capability of bringing it to fruition and would therefore abstain from protecting it."

            "If we don't make it happen, it falls flat on its back."

            "Why?"

            "In years the space-warper will be mass-produced, and nobody will ever think of building and populating a whopping planet just to utilize one of the myriad such engines in existence."

            "The device will become commonplace?"

            "Look what happened to the dark matter drive. It took twenty years for nearly every nation's fleet to make it standard issue, and it was top-secret to begin with."

            "I remember the first ship powered by Darkforce drive. When they finally revealed it, it was like showing a multi-module aerotrain during a tram exhibition."

            "Commodore Svenson was its captain. There's a man who still has his umbilical. Tied to space, too. He loved the idea."

            "Oh, he did, and much more. Trust me, he'll throw everything he can at it. He'll analyze it thoroughly, consider it carefully and study the possibility of making it a reality."

            "I thought so too. The man has my hopes riding high. If there's one person who can convince the rest..., forgive me, Tim, but that's…"

            Alex bumped into someone without noticing. He apologized automatically and only then did he realize who it had been. He knew the woman vaguely. He'd run into her in President Central, where she was employed. She was a young, lovely brunette with barely noticeable Asian features. She'd dropped a box of some storage media when they bumped into each other and the pieces were now scattered on the floor like grains of unground black pepper. Alex leaned down to help her gather her things.

            "Nora," Tim addressed her with a smile, "I'll leave my friend to deal with the consequences of his absentmindedness."

            "I'm terribly sorry, president Shevchenko. I…"

            "Not your fault, young lady, don't apologize. Al, I'll be contacting you soon. We need to go over our next move. I'll be going now. My wife is waiting. Bye-bye."

            "Bye, Mr. President. All the best to Anna and your family. Oh, here's the last one…"

            "One more over there, and there…"

            "Any idea how many of them there were?"

            "No, I'm just carrying some folders over from the Head Secretary's office. I was going to the info center anyway."

            "And if we leave one or two behind…?"

            "… I'll be penalized," she finished with a smile.

            "Well then, I'll have to pay the fine. It is my fault, is it not?"

            "No, no. I was just being funny. I wouldn't actually be in trouble."

            "Ha. Good one. By the way… I'm Alexander Belk, nice to meet you."

            "Nora Lang."

            "If people celebrated every chance encounter, happiness would be humanity's never-failing companion."

            "Sorry?"

            "I'm inviting you to a drink."

            "Why?"

            "Because I'd like to take care of the fine you won't be getting.

            "That's a very interesting way of putting it. What do you do?"

            "I teach. And you?"

            "The assistant pool. Archiving."

            "When do you get off work?"

            "Well, he-he, in five minutes."

            "Really now, he-he! Shall I wait for you out front?"

            "I'll be there in a minute. Think about where you're taking me to pay up."

Our big goal is $100 million! If it is collected within the first three days, $500 of pledges will immediately be spent on spreading the word for this campaign! Additionally, 10% of all pledges collected within the first three days will also go towards advertisement for this project!!! Regardless of whether this project reaches its financing goal or not, each of our supporters will receive an e-book for their reading pleasure and a special web certificate within a month of supporting us. You can read the first twenty pages of the novel below! Greetings, dear friends!I know what you’re thinking. “This guy is out of his mind, setting a goal like that!” Please, read on, and you’ll see I’m not *that* crazy. ;)Who am I? Just an ordinary guy with a big dream. Don’t they say that you’re as big as your dreams? Something like that, anyway ;)My name is Dobromir Ivanov, though I tend to write under the pen name of Dob Vans. I am a classically trained musician; I play the viola. I worked in an opera theater for fifteen years, and I currently own a small business while I make different kinds of art. I live in Bulgarian, Europe, and am fully aware of how difficult it is to publish stuff written by an author from such a small country, even if they specifically have the western reading audience in mind. In the novel at hand, there is nothing bound by region or conviction. Well, perhaps just a gentle whiff of my home country.***Dear friends,Since my end goal is colossal - $100 million to finance the creation of a high-budget film adaptation of PLANET SHIP 1 – PREDATORY FOG – I will need to be backed by quite a lot of people. So, to better reach a wider audience, some of which may kindly and graciously become backers, I will need to popularize my idea. The more people come across this project, the more likely it is that it will gain more supporters and backers.So, in one project, I’ve separated the pledge options into two. The SMALL project aims to gather traction for the BIG project, which I have described below. Those of you who believe in the success of this project and back me within the first three days after the project launch date will receive a special perk – a digitized version of one of my paintings, signed for the respective SPECIAL BACKER.First, I’d like to thank each and every one of you from the bottom of my heart – I thank all of you who decide to back and share my project with friends! I want you to know that, if we, you and me, manage to turn my novel  PLANET SHIP 1 – PREDATORY FOG into a big blockbuster movie, you will have been the main reason for this being possible!! Thank you all!   PREDATORY FOG is the first novel of the PLANET SHIP series and features everything a big Hollywood production requires. The plot is highly dynamic, the characters are varied and interesting, and, naturally, there are plenty of twists and turns. You’ll get to see future tech the likes of which have not been featured in science fiction. Espionage, adventure, genuine human relationships, love, war, breathtaking space vistas, colossal construction projects and new, amazing weaponry. Galactic skirmishes, arena fights between people with muscles of iron and artificial creatures. The novel has been written as a, if you will, glimpse into the future. That is, it treats fiction as a plausible progression of what we know to be true. This piece of science fiction is as much about science as it is about humanity.
The plot spans some five-hundred pages, taking place around the year 2569. Humanity has spread to six planets throughout the galaxy, yet, its innate adventurous spirit drives it to search for ever greater and faster means of travel and more ways of conquering the Universe. A genius inventor comes up with a way to achieve just that – a planet, which can function as an enormous space vessel. However, evil forces lead by a fanatical dictator will aggressively intervene and seek to take over the greatest achievement of the united human species. Only an individual of unique qualities and abilities can help neutralize the space-faring threat. But where can such an individual be found? How is he or she to be recruited for the noble cause?
From the very beginning, I thought of the book, and eventually wrote it, as a dramatized movie script. While I worked on it, I could picture the various scenes – real, fleshed out, as if they were happening right in front of my eyes. This is why the chapters are usually short and lead into one another like quick film edits.
The book is not intended only for fans of the Sci-Fi genre. A number of my friends, all from different walks of life, interests and social strata have thus far read and like it quite a bit.
This is not just science fiction. It is my best guess as to what things will be like fife hundred years into the future in all facets of life. In its pages, readers will encounter a veritable bubbling volcano of relationships, passion and real characters – love, hate, friendship, betrayal, hypocrisy, lies, naivety, lust for power, despotism, manipulativeness and subordination, ambition and domination, treachery and honesty, willingness to suffer and egoism. All fundamental components of a society, regardless of whether we locate said society in medieval times, today, or a couple of centuries in the future.
You may ask, “Why not publish it back home?” Well, that’s something of a tall order in my country, unless, of course, you’ve already established yourself and have stable financial backing. And, as I said, the novel is meant for a global audience. Ideally, there will be copies of it from the North Pole all the way down to Antarctica. Publishing houses here don’t have the resources for that sort of thing, and there aren’t many agencies who introduce local authors internationally. I was told that western publishers aren’t really all that interested in authors from my general geographic whereabouts. I have no clue why. Is it the way locals have presented themselves on the international stage or because of some prejudice? Honestly, I don’t know, but that publishing employee turned out to be right. I wrote to a few big agencies, but I never heard back. I’m no Stephen King or Michael Chrichton. Definitely no Donald Trump or Putin. I actually have no idea how an agency chooses their clients based on a short letter and (when they *do* ask for a text sample) ten or so pages of a novel. Whether a person is popular or not is definitely part of the equation. Sometimes I wonder how many great works are just gathering dust in the dusky drawers of their creators?!
Meanwhile, I approached a major documentary network about possibly creating a killer of an ad film based on my novel, since their name, logo design, activity can be a notable element in the production. It was in there, in the plot, a key component from the very beginning. I was told that such a venture was “not part of their programming plans.” I even tried to contact Elon Musk, since he is obviously a visionary, dreamer, and citizen of the cosmos in general, to try and introduce him to my book, but to no avail. Same thing with Neil deGrasse Tyson. I wrote to the Bulgarian representatives of a big film and TV production corporation – no response. I could go on, but I trust the point has been made.
This is where I should clarify why I’m not seeking to self-publish via physical media. It’s simple. If I set a goal of $5,000 and reach that, I could print (at a price of  $10 per copy) five hundred copies! I’d need more just to thank my backers! Let’s say I set a much higher goal and succeed? How would that benefit my future development? Isn’t that what crowdfunding is for? Do I need to reimagine myself and qualify as my novel’s production line? What market should I aim it at? How do I deal with delivery etc. That, I believe, should be left to the professionals, while the creators… create away.
And so, I’m aiming high. My dream is to have a big Hollywood movie made on the basis of my novel, and I’m certain that no major studio would scoff at a $100,000,000. That, in my mind, is the budget required for a worthwhile production. Also, I’m not just going to give that money away to a studio. Even if I’m not a producer per se, I’m definitely taking an active part in the creative process for my novel’s adaptation.
My dear future backers, this project might seem unfeasible, even delusional, I know. Yet, I am convinced that a belief in oneself is the first step to accomplishing ANY task. There is a saying in Bulgaria, which roughly translates into “gathered and united, people can even lift a mountain.” In other words, unity makes strength. Take on the challenge so that we can all be proud of our common deed! Share the project with your friends, let us be the driving force behind a fearsome wave of creative life force. When George Lucas made the original Star Wars, he had no notion of how successful his passion project would become. He must have stood at the door of the movie theater after that first projection, waiting to examine the expressions on the faces of the departing patrons. How deeply excited he must have been to see them not departing, but lining up again to buy another ticket!
I believe that you’re here not to simply buy another book. I know that you want to greenlight human creativity, so that more pieces that result from that creativity may belong to humanity, even if that means opposing those who are in control of humanity’s resources. Each of you will be rewarded with a little piece that will hopefully remain with you as a monument to generosity. Most important of all, you will be left with the indelible knowledge of having made possible something awesome!
The novel wasn’t written with 7.5 billion people in mind. Some of you, after you back the project and receive your copies will, no doubt, not find it to your liking. What I hope, though, is that you’ll enjoy supporting a wacky dreamer who dares meddle in the world of the all-mighty players and hopes to change it for the better, even if it’s just a tiny, tiny change.
I am fully cognizant of what it means to undertake such a project, and I truly believe that it will be successful world-wide. After all, I’m not going into this all alone. I am beyond certain that among those reading this, there is a sufficient number of kindred spirits and supporters. I’d just like to say, at this point, thank you!
I’ve not been alone up to this point during all my years in the creative netherworld. There are a number of people, my friends, without whose help and support this project would not be possible. I would like to express my unending gratitude to my most selfless supporters.
Lyubomir Petkov – attorney
Diyana Nikolova – linguist
Dessimir Zakov – musician and businessman
Todor Kalaydzhiev – financial expert
Blagovest Petrov – IT specialist
Atanas Dikov – owner of a printing center
Svetlana Dinkova – accountant
Petar Vasilev – engineer
Ivailo Kavaldjiev – businessman
Boris Stoilov – cover artist
 
They all helped me while I was writing the novel.
 
The novel itself is finished and the text has been translated into English. A huge thanks to my incredible translator, editor, and friend, Vadim Banev – faculty member of the English Linguistics and Literature department in the Paisii Hilendarski University, Plovdiv, Bulgaria.
 
Naturally, I am in no way stopping. I’m currently writing the second volume in the trilogy, and it’s going great. Over a hundred chapters so far, with the entire plot already finalized in my head. After all, we have the second movie to think about, don’t we? ;)
 
A few clarifications:
 
Predatory Fog is not being distributed commercially, and nobody but me has the authority to do so. To officially claim my rights as the author of a book with a unique ISBN, I’ve self-published the original Bulgarian text in a small number of paperback copies, and have offered the first of seven parts of the English translation as an e-book purchase option on a popular e-commerce platform.
 
Each of our supporters will receive the entirety of the English translation as an e-book shortly after pledging, along with a special electronic certificate, which features cover art. The latter is suitable for larger scale prints and framing.
 
A portion of the funds I manage to collect as a result of this campaign will be set aside to publish the novel. I’m looking for a small and reliable publishing house that will be willing to give me a chance. This is not going to be a quick or easy process, so I can’t promise you printed copies just yet. Once the novel has been published, I plan to send a signed copy to the top 1000 backers.
 
If I do reach my goal $100 million, the top 100 will also receive a custom, personalized statuette in the Planet Ship design style, which will bear the respective backers’ names; a kind of personal little academy award.
 
I honestly don’t know whether a big movie company would be willing to have my top backers on set to enjoy the filming process, but I intend to fight for the inclusion of a such a clause in any potential contracts. My top ten backers would then be able to join me on location in Hollywood or wherever the movie is being made.
 
I’ve also come up with a unique gift for some of supporters, to be chosen randomly – a drawing I’ve made myself in an avant-garde aesthetic, which features a stylized signature. I can’t really say how long each of the drawings will take to produce, since I only draw when inspiration really pummels me hard and out of nowhere, so I can’t really give you details on that gift as far as numbers and dates.
Since some would ask what I’d be using the money for if I don’t reach my goal of $100 million, I’ve included a small map, if you will, of how I intend to proceed depending on what portion of the intended financing is collected.
 
From $60 million to $100 million – a big-budget film
From $20 million to $60 million – an impressive series
From $1 million to $20 million – a miniseries featuring the first few episodes of larger series
From $100,000 to $1 million – seeking co-financing from a producer
From $20,000 to $100,000 – self-publishing of the novel, advertisement campaigns for said novel
From $5,000 to $20,000 – working with a publishing house to get the novel out there
From $3 to $5,000 – popularizing of PREDATORY FOG, since, naturally, the book can’t just sit there on a shelf and gather dust!
 
And now, I would kindly direct you to go back and look at the first entry in this list! ;)
Dear friends,
It would be an immense pleasure to have you on the team that can make my dream come true! I sincerely thank you for your attention and wish you robust health and good fortune in everything you do.
 
To better understand what you might be getting yourself into, I’d like to invite you to read the first twenty pages of the novel here.
 
DOB VANS
