The boy was playing in the sandbox in front of the apartment building. His father observed him – the smile on his face twitching in an unconscious impulse of pride and tenderness. His son had constructed a couple of sand hills, apparently a proxy for the glorious palace in the boy's mind. The child rose and glanced at his father, whose entire being exuded a kind of singular sense of triumph. The boy stretched out with his hands, laughed in anticipation of the father's approval, but was too late. The man stood up from the bench and started forward, arms stretched out as well. As he walked, a dark shadowy mass came in and dimmed the sunlight. He looked up and froze on the spot; his face contorted in a grimace of horror. The flying object obstructing the sun hovered, immobile, above the open areas between the apartment buildings. The boy followed his father's gaze and immediately turned to him with bewildered, questioning eyes. Before the father could move even slightly, a lightning-white flash struck him. The man turned gray, much like concrete, and was literally rendered into stone in seconds – then fell apart into countless tiny particles. What seemed like grains of fine sand settled on the concrete slab the man had been standing on. The boy just stood there, confused. His eyes filled with tears as he started to sob and look around. There was no soul in sight; he was all alone amid the palpable workday afternoon silence. He looked up. The sun's rays caressed his cheeks glistening with teardrops. Once again he focused on the small pile of sand on the playground. He leaned down, took his bucket and toy spade, approached, tripping and stumbling along the way, knelt and began collecting his father's ashes.
 
 
PART ONE
GHOSTLY AID
 
 
            1.Professor Alexander Belk was so amazed at the idea that had just bloomed in his mind that he nearly spilled his coffee. It was early in the afternoon on December 10, 2569 of the Standard Interplanetary Calendar. In what constituted a small wonder, the Professor was currently enjoying a brief period of no meetings or arrangements, so he made the most of his break out in the open air. He sat alone at a table in the café overseeing the Third strait of Swan city, enjoying the gentle sunshine of the local star Lan. His thoughts fired rapidly, flowing into each other like dissimilar layers of fog and mist. He pictured the lecture hall, full of students, not much younger than himself. Then he dove into deep thought about how necessary it was for him to finally stir up his monotonous, orderly scholar being by means of the affections of some interesting young lass. He then decided to leave such burdensome contemplation behind and let himself focus on what he loved most – fantasizing about space exploration, the future of civilization, even considering the notion of universal dissemination of the human species. The last subject was something he came back to quite often. No, it couldn't be done with ships. Even if said ships could house hundreds of thousands of individuals. The distances which had to be traversed and the amounts of time that would take were so great that no artificially-manufactured society of beings would be able to cope without succumbing to self-annihilation. What is more, nothing could justify using the newly-discovered engine technology, known only to a small number of scientists and high-ranking politicians on Arfinia, in a simple space-faring vessel. The so-called space-warper was a discovery of colossal importance; producing an actual working engine based on the technology would take immense resources, the likes of which even his own homeland would not be able to spare, in spite of being the most powerful state on all six habitable planets.
            Alex tasted his coffee as he reached this point in his contemplation and … The image came to him without warning, striking and clear. Not just an idea, but an entirely functional system of analysis, concept, and implementation. His hands twitched but Alex overcame the urge without spilling a single drop of the precious fragrant liquid. He looked around, saw nobody was paying attention and stood up. He leaned on the railings and gazed into the wave-like structure of the strait splitting the continent in two. He took in a few breaths of fresh air, looked wistfully at the emerald-green sky of Grenaira, sighed a sigh of affirmation and set his body phone to dial mode. The cerebral impulses of the answering party responded, but there was no voice on the line. Probably not the best time or place to talk, yet listening was obviously an option. Alex smiled, his face taking on a provocative expression. He caressed his stubble and declared triumphantly, "Planet ships! But, don't mind me, please, carry on with your ever-so-important affairs of state, he-he-he ..."
 
            2. Timothy Shevchenko sat at the Round table where the Interplanetary Council of leaders was holding session. The place chosen for the meeting was a middling hall some ten floors above the Mahmuldar congress center, Mahmuldar being the leading state on the planet Saa. On this specific occasion it was Timothy's go at representing Grenaira. He was selected from a pool of the seven presidents of Arfinia and leaders of other, smaller states. Earth's representative had been speaking when Timothy received the call. He waited, rather impatiently, for the speech to be over, so as to make use of the small break window that would follow.
            He retired to the room assigned to him and immediately activated his holographic monitor to contact Belk. The Professor popped up on the screen, grinning a ridiculously wide grin.
            "Quite the meeting, I take it?" he stated inquisitively.
            "Young man, have you thought this through?" Shevchenko started, not skipping a beat. "Or are you just keeping yourself busy and wasting my time with science fiction?"
            "Through? I haven't thought at all," the Professor added, maintaining his upbeat delivery, "the whole thing just materialized in my head. The whole system, Mr. President, a completed project, down to the smallest detail."
            "You believe it would be feasible for us to execute?"
            "Depends on what you mean by us."
            "Right, so we can't do it alone. Hm, a planet ship you say, Al?"
            "A planet ship."
            "Quite the idea. Probably in the quadrillion ballpark..."
            "More like quintillion, Tim."
 
            3. The dissemination of humans was not a new idea. The subject had been considered current ever since Homo sapiens had taken its first steps and haughtily looked down upon all other creatures roaming the African plains of its homeworld. Not long after, at least on the immensely grand scale of time itself, the nascent species conquered and populated its planet. It was not enough, however, and humans looked up at the stars. In 2171 a human astronaut stepped on a habitable alien planet for the first time. This opened the proverbial floodgates for the little green planet. Grenaira became humanity's second home. Slowly but surely, space exploration went further and further, and throughout the centuries, thousands of ships criss-crossed the galaxy, discovering ever more twins of old Earth. The number of human beings grew incessantly, and there was no lack of enthusiastic volunteers who wanted to settle, start anew, throw away the shackles of one gravity index for another. Regardless of the motives of any single individual, by the end of the 25th century human civilization consisted of six planets, perfectly suited for life, as well as hundreds of less hospitable colonies which provided an endless supply of valuable natural resources, built upon sparsely populated asteroids and planetoids.
            And even though there was sufficient space for billions more humans on these worlds, even though they could feed many generations to come, even though the members of the societies there could traverse distances, which just a few hundred years prior might have seemed unthinkable, to visit their brethren from light-years away, there were, nevertheless, people who never stopped dreaming of taming more of the frontier. Just like the man who had constructed the first raft and sailed Earth's oceans to colonize another continent, there were modern humans who dreamed of building ships to lead humanity to other galaxies. Nobody had gone beyond the Milky Way as of yet. That is, unless one believed the numerous myths and legends of astronaut folklore.
            Some insisted that man had not yet matured enough to travel the distances between galaxies, and that such a thing could not happen before humanity developed into whatever evolution had in store for it. Others were convinced that very thing had already happened. Or just about, at least. They claimed a transitional species had existed for a long time – a species worthy of investing one's hopes in, capable of making that great leap – Cyborgs.
            Actually, in that period during the second half of the 26th century a great deal of humans could be classified as such as well, in spite of most not accepting or approving of it. They thought it brought them lower somehow, to be nothing more than an ordinary robot, a construct, not that dissimilar to some household appliance, a vacuum cleaner or what have you. Yet, they had no reason to be ashamed of what they were. The scientific advances of cybernetics had made it possible to elevate the species. It was not just that human beings became sick less often and lived twice as long as their 21st century counterparts; they could enhance the scope and abilities of their very intellect. Those who chose to have their heart replaced, their skeletal framework strengthened, or have their mental capacity increased via artificial additions, were not in any way opposed to these improvements. Still, they did not wish to be referred to as cyborgs. And with good reason, too; a simple explanation that was evident and valid on its own merit. That reason was the Cyborg Society.
            In the beginning, hundreds of years ago, it was not a true organization. More of a club of extravagant, eccentric individuals from different parts of the worlds. They were proud of the chips and circuits they integrated into their bodies to "shine the way for science", as they usually phrased it. As centuries passed, installing internal components and adding external ones into the human biology became mass practice. Post-2550, body modules were manufactured from predominantly organic materials and could scarcely be differentiated from natural organs. Almost, that is, as every scanner contrasted the two like puddles of water in the sand. Of course, nobody wanted to conceal the presence of such acquisitions as it was no different from having an artificial tooth in the old days. However, throughout the entirety of the history of cybernetics, there were those individuals who paraded their more advanced and costlier physical and mental enhancements, looking down on the common man.
            Gradually, people who liked the title of cyborg created their own organized hierarchical structure. They considered themselves superior to humans, apparently fancied themselves an entirely new species. Bit by bit, they began to stray from the rest of humanity, started to gather in their own groups and parties, finally forming a wholly separate society. One of Cyborgs, the Cyborg Society. Later on, they would leave behind the "gravitational confines", as they called planets, and live aboard their city ships. Only a small amount of humans were aware of this, while the masses were blissfully oblivious to such goings-on. They knew of the Society in as much as they knew they were not part of it and its unfounded claims of superiority. What business was it of theirs that there was this faction, imaginary or not, of peculiar and pathologically-deviant minds, thank you very much!
 
            4. Tsar Fog de Berg sat in his private upgrade clinic. The Doctor added the final lubial neuron, connected it to the synapses and psychodorms by means of a microbiosuture and, satisfied with his work, smiled at the Ruler. He, in turn, frowned in approval, and the Doctor applied the new strip of enhancing cortex tissue. Then he reattached the bone, fixed the scalp and irradiated the area with a ciffisian lamp to let the tissue grow back. Yet another regal cerebral upgrade was completed. De Berg smiled, seemingly at himself. Now he truly possessed the most powerful intellect in known space. He looked at himself in the mirror. Handsome too! Such a broad, manly brow. Now his head was worth over a trillion arfins (or Bergs, Fog corrected himself), not counting the unquantifiable aesthetic value it held. The best part was only he could make use of it, so no one would be tempted to take it away from him. Tsar Fog de Berg was so content that he did not even allow for the possibility of there being someone, who, like that, for the hell of it, would like to just blow up this jewel of the biocybernetic medical arts. Yet, he reminded himself that some devious foe could potentially break into the tacit corner of his artificial memory. That was only possible with the competent aid of the very physician who completed the update, who, as it happened, was just taking off his operating gown. The Tsar sighed in utter vexation and demolecularized him right to the floor. The sanitary robot sucked up the remnants of the physician (and his illustrious career), and deposited them into the trash compartment, where they were swiftly blown into space. Disgusted, Fog rubbed away a stray ashy particle from his eye. He contemplated whether it was possible for the discarded dust to be the spark to some proto-life and its ensuing evolutionary process, should it happen upon the right planet.
 
            5. Far from all those innovative, technologically-endowed corners of space, the state of Gorania pulsed with its own steady life beats. For millennia, it had remained uncared-for in a distant corner of Europe, Earth, and ultimately, of history. The ancient country had been witness to centuries of upward and downward surges, and now, at the end of the 26th century, had subsided into lethargy, the likes of which it had not experienced even during the countless times of being annexed, conquered, and having its borders redrawn. Nobody attacked anymore, for the values they once held dear were twisted, long-gone, to be replaced by those of outsiders. Well, there were still beautiful, unsullied swaths of nature to be sure, but those could be found in many different countries, on many different planets. And so, Gorania rested in its vegetative state, somewhere along the border between the rest of Europe and the member-nations of the Eurasian Union, undisturbed in its sublime backward-mindedness.
            A scarce but tough people lived there. They had learned to survive among their peers, which was no small feat in and of itself. Goranians were accustomed to being dependent on nobody but their closest; they didn't have any newfangled technology or machinery to aid them – they either coped by primitive means or were forced to leave their country… if at all possible. Through the centuries, in times of open borders, large parts of the population left and never returned. Thus, in a few centuries, the Goranian nation dwindled by a factor of seven, down to about a million inhabitants. For this reason, among others of a domestically-political nature, the government closed the borders. Unilaterally. With kind assistance from their neighbors. Eurasia and Europe, who periodically took turns at adding it to, and then excluding it from their amorphous and often-crumbling unions, were very quick to activate their border force-fields as though they were expecting to be pounced on by their sweetly snoozing brethren.
            Still, for violist Danninger Blagostino there were new, undiscovered horizons in store. His whole life was in front of him. Danny, the name those closest to him used, was a 23-year-old, fresh out of his viola course in the Tronnian Academy of Music. He was a bit of a dreamer, so when he came back from the capital and got accepted into the philharmonic opera orchestra of his home town of Fildion, his very soul was filled with reveries and illustrious visions of the future. He would work on his interpretations of majestic pieces of art, conquer stages, as well as hearts beating within the chests of young instrument players, choristers, and... perhaps, even ballerinas?
            With some trepidation, Danninger headed for the Opera building on his first day at work. He climbed up the steps to the reception hall, all in one breath, opened the door and... froze. Behind the music-stands there stood seemingly depressed, haggard, gray old people. The bowing was languid at best, and the brass section virtually molested their instruments in a fortissimo, taking revenge for the lives they had lost in the depths of artistic wreckage in this Temple of arts. He stepped forward, shoulder slumped, approached the viola group and greeted his colleagues as they politely pointed to his chair and then resumed probing the trickier passages. He took his viola out of its case, tightened the bow and began to practice some sixteenths from the sheets in front of him. He caught one female colleague's eyes as they fixated on him from behind the music stand opposite and sensed that in her view, he was attempting to display unwarranted amounts of virtuosity, so he carried on in a softer tone. The cacophony of sounds was suddenly gone. Danny took the bow off the strings and looked around. An old man with silver hair and sallow skin approached the conductor's stand in a flowing, swan-like gait. He greeted the room almost imperceptibly, opened up the score and shifted his watery gaze up, focusing on Danninger. Had the conductor simply noticed a fresh face among the orchestra? Or was it just that his unusual height that attracted attention? He shuddered. The eyes of a snake were peering straight at him.
 
            6. All seven presidents of Arfinia only gathered once or twice a year and then only for strictly-scheduled events. Even during times of war, the last one taking place more than half a century prior, they communicated through the airwaves. Naturally, Tim Shevchenko's six colleagues were rather surprised at his request for an unscheduled face-to-face meeting. He reassured them there was nothing to worry about, that his reasons for assembling the Presidents' Council were not troubling in any way – yet, when they asked him what those reasons actually were, Tim deflected the query. They all knew their eldest colleague well; knew he would not be calling if matters were trivial. Be it with a personal airpod, presidential cosmoplane, or private plain mechanical bicycle, they all hopped to the occasion on time, and, once gathered, hugged each other as was customary. Professor Belk only received handshakes, though just as cordial. Their faces revealed genuine surprise at the presence of the cosmological tech adviser.
            "My dear colleagues, I apologize if I have disturbed your delicate engagement scheduling," Shevchenko started apologetically, yet was reassured by his colleagues' vigorous hand-waving.
            "Tim," president Florence Alberti addressed him with a smile. "I am curious as to the nature of this emergency gathering. Perhaps we should be holding a classified meeting, no associates?"
            "No, no need. The nature of this meeting is not sensitive. In fact, I believe it may well become the most transparent matter we've ever ventured to embark upon."
            "Come now, my friend, tell us," young president Janusz Cordel could hardly contain himself. "Enough with the solemn secrecy."
            "I think you should listen to Alex now. We are gathered here because of an idea of his."
            More impatient urging followed. Professor Belk, who was not accustomed to feeling tense or uncertain before high-ranking councils or committees, coughed, and the sound carried the vaguest note of hesitation. He spoke in his typical, confident manner, "I have come upon an idea that is fit for a popular fiction film. If that was my goal, ladies and gentlemen, I would be speaking before executives from Hollywood, back on Earth. I have no connections in the world of cinema, however, thus I am here, where pure reality is forged instead of fantastic entertainment. The notion I wish to present is simple. Let us turn a planet into a functional ship."
            The presidents chuckled, then stopped to think, which brought to the room the first signs of surprise, approval, and disappointment all together. Then, President Commodore Johan Svenson said earnestly, "It is an astonishing idea, Alex. I myself have considered something similar. Are we not a couple of centuries too early, however?"
            "Johan!" President Anita Hegelman interjected in disbelief. "Are you being serious?"
            "I simply appreciate the genius of the thought. It remains to be determined whether it will be at all possible. We need to listen to the Professor's reasoning first."
            "Naturally, we will, " Admiral Giancarlo Ramsi Ramsay chimed in as well. "Just so you know, in case the end result is of no military advantage, I am against it."
            "But, Giancarlo, you are not minister of defense!" Florence exclaimed. "And how can you be against anything without having familiarized yourself with it?"
            "I am expressing my opinion as I am quite familiar with Alex's thought process. He comes forward with ideas only when they benefit the peaceful exploration and taming of space."
            "What's wrong with that, then?" Johan asked, frowning.
            "Nothing per se. Although… his projects do tend to be a drain on the treasury rather than creating an influx. This is no different, isn't that right, Professor?"
            Alex smiled widely, raised his eyebrows and said jovially, "Admiral, you have always been a marvelous psychologist. You've hit the nail on the head. More so than you think. Not only would the project be likely to drain Arfinia's military finance, but it would not even be feasible without all major countries on the six planets allotting portions of their budget totals."
            Anita gasped as if she felt some sharp pain while the rest laughed. Only Timothy Shevchenko sat there akin to a bronze statue, his eyes darting around to take in the expressions of the astonished auditorium of presidents.
            "Now, I don't mean to say that I have something against this emergency meeting," Janusz broke the silence, "but what exactly is the rush?"
            "President Cordel," Alex looked at him. "I shall share something most of you aren't aware of."
            "Classified?"
            "Let us say, it has been, up until now, deemed unnecessary to waste your time with incomplete projects."
            "Just the same, let us isolate the room," Florence said confidently as she pressed the security black-out button. "So, what is this invention not worthy of our stately time?"
            "It is not an invention, but a discovery, The Discovery, if you will. We call it a space-warper…"
            "Not possible!" Johan stood up from his seat.
            "Yes, commodore," Alex smiled at him triumphantly. "It very much is. Trials indicate we can do it. We simply have to build it."
            "What are you two on about?" Anita shook her head.
            "The engine of the future," Admiral Ramsay explained in an expertly manner. "It warps space so that a ship may traverse distances currently considered unattainable. If we can build it, we would be invincible."
            "Well, that's all just fine and dandy," Janusz interrupted, staring down Alex. "My question remains. Why go about this with such urgency?"
            "The engine is so intricate that constructing it is no simple matter. It is also rather expensive. If we were to build one for an ordinary ship, it would be like… strapping an elephant to a toy cart. Or, more like a microscopic cart."
            "And since we have our unborn elephant," Roberta Hu added playfully. "We want to build a gilded carriage for it to tow?"
            "Not precisely, President Hu," Shevchenko said at last, speaking in that soft tone he had grown accustomed to during his time as a children's instructor. "Not a shining carriage fit for nobles or a yacht for the chosen few, but a sturdy, tight raft, filled with the masses, ready to extend the reach of the human species into the Universe. We must not allow this opportunity to slip through our fingers – this nation simply must construct the revolutionary engine as we are the inventors. Or worse still – we must not permit it to be built and then let it collect dust for hundreds of years in some forsaken hangar because there's no ship worthy to be powered by it. We've come up with wind... Why not build that sailboat?"
 
            7. The Cosmographic was the best channel! It was perfect for everyone interested in the Universal goings-on, as well as those who wished to further their media careers in the best way possible. To make it there you had to part with any semblance of residence and become a citizen of the cosmos. To work for Cosmographic Life, you had to denounce yourself. If you were able to come up with a hot story, however, you and your former self would be reunited, and you become king. The ruler of men's hearts, corporate lavishness and all manner of managerial perks at your disposal. Well, Lilana Strombeyer had made it to the first level when she had been appointed two months ago.
            The editor was pulling his hair out, yelling at her, nagging her constantly, over and over again in the same order. The simplicid cam operator would anxiously twitch about, but never dared defend her. And Lilana herself simply stood there, frozen not out of fear, but with astonishment – how was it that they didn't like her downright genius story? She was fully capable of plunging her fist into the editor's repulsive face, but her body was encased in restraining surprise.
            "Do you have any idea who you're working for?" the editor raged. "Does Cosmographic Life ring a bell? Do you happen to know it's the department that airs non-stop live broadcasts from space, that we're part of the most prestigious interplanetary media in the galaxy? Not just news and reports. Entire events! That's what you lot are supposed to be doing."
            "But I…"
            "You?! You, intentionally I might add, did not film a colossal natural explosion that killed two astronauts! You deprived billions of viewers of the opportunity to witness this immense tragedy. What were you thinking? Did you think you were hired to report on a routine survey of some boring planet that may or may not have kiont deposits?"
            "That's why I pointed…"
            "Yes, precisely, because you don't have the slightest idea what sensation is, you made your cameraman shoot some slimy critter crawled out of the rocks, one dying of old age! And at the same time! …"
            "You really don't get it, huh?!" Lilana erupted.
            "Uh, you better..." Her colleague attempted to intervene.
            "Enough, Rob! He…"
            "I what?" the editor leaped forward. "Did I happen to film some critter's pathetic final gasps instead of the death of two heroes?"
            "I'm truly sorry, but they weren't …"
            "You better be sorry… and stop provoking me or I'll be forced to fire you!"
            "Fine, fire me, but hear me out first."
            "Hear you out?! Get out of my sight before I kick you out with my two bare hands."
            "Wouldn't you use your feet for that?"
            "Out!"
            She looked at him like a wild tigress and turned around swiftly.       "Hey, wait, I haven't given you your next assignment yet!"
            "Is there going to be one?" She asked with a sarcastic tone without even turning her head.
            "I'll give you one last chance."
            "Where?"
            "Hard labor duty." 
             Lilana Strombeyer gave him a disgusted look, turned and stormed our proudly. Such a kind editor! That animal on that empty planet was a total darling compared to him.
 
            8. The patient lay on the operating table. His body was burned, face a bloody mess, but he was still breathing. The team of physicians was working efficiently, like a well-oiled machine. They waited while the anesthesia took effect. The nurse then proceeded to pour out a jarful of nanobots which started 'eating' away the charred dead tissue. Some five minutes later, the patient's appearance was not unlike a skinned lamb. Doctor Ashrani switched on his laser scalpel and carefully started to separate muscle tissue from the skin and chest. He did the same with the groin, but there wasn't much there left, anyway. When he was done, his assistant commenced to hand him biosynthetic collabren pieces of different sizes and shapes. The surgeon worked quickly, and in a short while, the tissue containers were nearly depleted. He took a large syringe and emptied it into the patient's heart, which caused him to stop breathing. The nurse then pressed a button, and the operating table transformed into a translucent vat. She took a nondescript tube, pointed it toward the vat and filled it with a thick, drab substance. The tiny particles, which floated around in the liquid, started to stick to the patient's body. The vat's logic circuits precisely guided the thousands of specs to the right areas so that they would cover and support the flesh, and soon they formed a see-through film. The circuit switched to a higher voltage on the substance and the patient flinched as his nerve endings connected to the freshly-formed film of skin. The process took about ten more minutes; the body was completely covered with skin, and the turgid goo in the vat slowly became clear, after which it drained away. The vat was a cot again. A short burst of electricity caused the man to recommence his breathing, the first couple of breaths abrupt and wheezy. Doctor Ashrani stuck a tiny electrode in the man's cheekbone and made a few minor adjustments to the face whose shape and color changed as if by magic. He took the needle out and gave his patient a gentle tap on the cheek. The man woke up. His doctor was smiling at him.
            "Hello there!" said the surgeon. "What is your name?"
            "Janvier Lagrange, why?"
            The Doctor took a small mirror and brought it up to the patient so he could see himself in it.
            "That's you, isn't it?" he looked at the patient inquisitively.
            "I think so."
            "And this? Or this?" the Doctor was pressing buttons, while the features of the man's face shifted with each press.
            "Oh, fuck! Is all that me?"
            "Yes."
            "And who are you?"
            "The ones who brought you back. We made a few adjustments, as per your contract. You will get used to controlling the change in a few minutes. You will be impossible to track down."
            "How... how come?"
            "You are now a transformer. Congratulations!"
 
            9. Alex and Tim said goodbye to the presidents and headed towards the exit. They walked slowly across the spacious corridors, nodded cursory nods to the vast amount of service-people they came across and spoke in subdued, quiet voices.
            "Al, you really amazed them with your idea, you know that?"
            "That is… with the utter craziness of my proposal. Hah. Tim, I wouldn't hold it against them if they don't take it very seriously. I plan on patenting the idea right away. Not that anybody is rushing to beat me to it."
            "You believe that if somebody thought of it, they wouldn't have the capability of bringing it to fruition and would therefore abstain from protecting it."
            "If we don't make it happen, it falls flat on its back."
            "Why?"
            "In years the space-warper will be mass-produced, and nobody will ever think of building and populating a whopping planet just to utilize one of the myriad such engines in existence."
            "The device will become commonplace?"
            "Look what happened to the dark matter drive. It took twenty years for nearly every nation's fleet to make it standard issue, and it was top-secret to begin with."
            "I remember the first ship powered by Darkforce drive. When they finally revealed it, it was like showing a multi-module aerotrain during a tram exhibition."
            "Commodore Svenson was its captain. There's a man who still has his umbilical. Tied to space, too. He loved the idea."
            "Oh, he did, and much more. Trust me, he'll throw everything he can at it. He'll analyze it thoroughly, consider it carefully and study the possibility of making it a reality."
            "I thought so too. The man has my hopes riding high. If there's one person who can convince the rest..., forgive me, Tim, but that's…"
            Alex bumped into someone without noticing. He apologized automatically and only then did he realize who it had been. He knew the woman vaguely. He'd run into her in President Central, where she was employed. She was a young, lovely brunette with barely noticeable Asian features. She'd dropped a box of some storage media when they bumped into each other and the pieces were now scattered on the floor like grains of unground black pepper. Alex leaned down to help her gather her things.
            "Nora," Tim addressed her with a smile, "I'll leave my friend to deal with the consequences of his absentmindedness."
            "I'm terribly sorry, president Shevchenko. I…"
            "Not your fault, young lady, don't apologize. Al, I'll be contacting you soon. We need to go over our next move. I'll be going now. My wife is waiting. Bye-bye."
            "Bye, Mr. President. All the best to Anna and your family. Oh, here's the last one…"
            "One more over there, and there…"
            "Any idea how many of them there were?"
            "No, I'm just carrying some folders over from the Head Secretary's office. I was going to the info center anyway."
            "And if we leave one or two behind…?"
            "… I'll be penalized," she finished with a smile.
            "Well then, I'll have to pay the fine. It is my fault, is it not?"
            "No, no. I was just being funny. I wouldn't actually be in trouble."
            "Ha. Good one. By the way… I'm Alexander Belk, nice to meet you."
            "Nora Lang."
            "If people celebrated every chance encounter, happiness would be humanity's never-failing companion."
            "Sorry?"
            "I'm inviting you to a drink."
            "Why?"
            "Because I'd like to take care of the fine you won't be getting.
            "That's a very interesting way of putting it. What do you do?"
            "I teach. And you?"
            "The assistant pool. Archiving."
            "When do you get off work?"
            "Well, he-he, in five minutes."
            "Really now, he-he! Shall I wait for you out front?"
            "I'll be there in a minute. Think about where you're taking me to pay up."

story:
Synopsis

Set in early 18th-century Spain, Yad reimagines the life of architect Narciso Tomé and the story of the construction of one of the highest achievements of Spanish Baroque architecture, the El Transparente altar.

During construction, Narciso’s love affair with the wife of Toledo’s public prosecutor leads to a confrontation between the two men that results in the accidental death of the prosecutor. Fearful of being accused of murder by the Inquisition, Narciso abandons the construction of El Transparente and leaves his family behind.

Knowing that Narciso’s disappearance will be interpreted by the Inquisition as an admission of guilt and a death sentence for the remaining family, Narciso’s wife disguises herself as her husband and continues to work on the cathedral. She saves his masterpiece while he is gone, but will she forgive him once he returns?

Yad is a fast-paced historical thriller about a man’s search for identity. Featuring fictionalized accounts of historical figures such as the painters Francisco Goya and El Greco, it takes its readers on a tour of 18th-century Toledo, stopping in at marzipan shops, visiting famed Toledo steel blacksmiths, and uncovering an underworld of crime and prostitution. Engaging, funny, cerebral, and touching, Yad is more than a high-concept, historical novel; it is a meditation on betrayal, repentance, forgiveness, and love. 

 

About the author

Daniel Karpinski is the author of I jak inni (O Like the Others or A like Another) (WL, 1998), and Fikcja (Fiction) (WL, 2000), which were both nominated for the Nike Literary Award, the most prestigious Polish book prize. Born in Tarnow, Poland, he moved to West Berlin after earning a PhD in architecture. Since 1989, he has lived with his family in Toronto, where he writes, designs, and teaches architecture at Ryerson University.

Daniel’s architectural work has won several awards and has been published in Architectural Design and The Canadian Architect among other publications. His artwork has been exhibited in galleries, including the Musée d’Orsay in Paris, the Aedes Gallery in West Berlin, the International Congress of Architecture in Berlin (2002), and the Cracow Biennale.

 

Prologue from Yad

In the city, where we lay our scene, the streets are narrow and steep. It is easy to stumble, descending them, and tiresome to walk uphill. In the city, where the plot unfolds, the houses are tall and thin. Pressed one beside the other, the rows form ducts, create gaps into which the sun falls only in the afternoon, shining almost vertical. The houses along the street are several levels stacked one above the other, connected by steep stairs, like the rays of the sun at its zenith.

Every street is like fate, every house like faith. But this is a city, not a metaphor.

In the spring, when hot days announce the bullfighting season, canopies are hung above the streets. White canvas sheets, rinsed by rain, dried by heat, like clouds drifting at the height of the tallest floor, they mimic the shape of the streets for the birds.

Is that all?

In the evening… Under the soaring curtains, lamps are hung between houses. Lit at dusk, the lamps turn the streets into tunnels of light, piercing the darkness. They are quenched at bedtime. When the light disappears, the canopies fill with the breath of night, sailing in search of the Golden Fleece or to Ithaca. In the streets, late passers carry lanterns before them, deep-sea fish paying no attention to the sails above their heads, mistaking them for the Milky Way, which nobody will ever measure, whose stardust nobody will ever shake from their feet.

That it?

If you look up, you can read the traces of cat paws and bird feathers, or see a skinny cat who lives only on love and barley.

Oh!

There, straight from the open window jumps a barely clothed youth! A flight of triumph? Young like Icarus, but skillful like Daedalus, he balances a moment on the canvas trampoline, then rushes in the direction of the Cathedral. Barefoot, he leaps as though in seven-league boots. His every step is ascension, the moon kissing his sweaty breast through an open shirt. He rises like a balloon of the Montgolfier brothers, like the first plane of the Wright brothers. Flying is a brotherly thing. Jumping too. And further and further, like a cricket, like a grasshopper, like locusts…

Locusts? I should not have used that word. Suddenly, behind his jumping back another figure appears. He runs like an Andalusian dog, fully clothed, heavy boots, an overcoat. What’s this? A sword of Toledo steel, cold and sharp like the moonlight. Stretched out just, just behind the youth’s back:

- Turn around! You coward! You took my—

A thrust! The sword pierces the back of the shirt and emerges through the front. Blood from the youth’s back repeated on his breast. Two stains. Pierced through.

The pursued does not fall. As if he does not notice the strike and the blood, he jumps ahead, leaping over the sagging sheets. Across the Milky Way canopy, he traces a new constellation, composed only of Mars, repeated blotches of red.

The pursuer, after delivering the blow, catches his foot in a seam. There is the sound of tearing cloth, the sheets rip in two and open beneath the feet of the offender, throwing him into the abyss. He grabs an edge with one hand, grips his sword with the other like a precious treasure. The material slips from his grasp and he tumbles onto the lamp below, onto the rope, which he clutches, this time with both hands. The rope rips from one wall and, flying like a pendulum, he slams into the opposing wall—then he falls limply into the street beside his humming sword.

Silence.

Nobody awoke, no one had seen his fall. The sail above the street swayed to the rhythm of snores. The sky cried a lonely star that leaked into the grave. An auburn shadow crawled from the alley, picked up the blade, which flashed in the darkness, and fled towards the Jewish quarter. And then another shadow and another… The second grabbed the purse and jewels, and the third looked in the robbed man’s face and—like a Good Samaritan—began to howl:

- Help!!!

On the ground, without feeling, lay Don Miguel de Juaclac, the public prosecutor of Toledo. Of the jumping youth, not a trace remained, if you don’t count the red stars on the canvas sky.

Who he was and whose blood this is, nobody will know. Nobody except You and I. Only we know, this leaping youth was named Narciso Tomé. This is his story. Keep it for yourself, as a warning. I don’t have anything to do with it. I’m just telling it.

I am this story.

Narciso is me. 

 

About the cover

The cover image uses the oil painting, El caballero de la mano en el pecho by El Greco, which was created in Toledo in 1580 and is currently on display at the Museo del Prado. In English, its title has been translated as The Gentleman with His Hand at His Breast. The subject’s identity is shrouded in mystery; it may be a portrait of Juan de Silva y Ribera or a self-portrait of El Greco himself.

The image was horizontally flipped and the face of the man adjusted to a “regular” perception by removing the deformations caused by El Greco’s astigmatism. The original has been left, giving the portrait the appearance of having two faces, revealing the duality present in the novel’s main character. The sword figures heavily in the story’s plot and acts as a reference to Toledan steel.
story_txt:
Synopsis
Set in early 18th-century Spain, Yad reimagines the life of architect Narciso Tomé and the story of the construction of one of the highest achievements of Spanish Baroque architecture, the El Transparente altar.
During construction, Narciso’s love affair with the wife of Toledo’s public prosecutor leads to a confrontation between the two men that results in the accidental death of the prosecutor. Fearful of being accused of murder by the Inquisition, Narciso abandons the construction of El Transparente and leaves his family behind.
Knowing that Narciso’s disappearance will be interpreted by the Inquisition as an admission of guilt and a death sentence for the remaining family, Narciso’s wife disguises herself as her husband and continues to work on the cathedral. She saves his masterpiece while he is gone, but will she forgive him once he returns?
Yad is a fast-paced historical thriller about a man’s search for identity. Featuring fictionalized accounts of historical figures such as the painters Francisco Goya and El Greco, it takes its readers on a tour of 18th-century Toledo, stopping in at marzipan shops, visiting famed Toledo steel blacksmiths, and uncovering an underworld of crime and prostitution. Engaging, funny, cerebral, and touching, Yad is more than a high-concept, historical novel; it is a meditation on betrayal, repentance, forgiveness, and love. 
 
About the author
Daniel Karpinski is the author of I jak inni (O Like the Others or A like Another) (WL, 1998), and Fikcja (Fiction) (WL, 2000), which were both nominated for the Nike Literary Award, the most prestigious Polish book prize. Born in Tarnow, Poland, he moved to West Berlin after earning a PhD in architecture. Since 1989, he has lived with his family in Toronto, where he writes, designs, and teaches architecture at Ryerson University.
Daniel’s architectural work has won several awards and has been published in Architectural Design and The Canadian Architect among other publications. His artwork has been exhibited in galleries, including the Musée d’Orsay in Paris, the Aedes Gallery in West Berlin, the International Congress of Architecture in Berlin (2002), and the Cracow Biennale.
 
Prologue from Yad

In the city, where we lay our scene, the streets are narrow and steep. It is easy to stumble, descending them, and tiresome to walk uphill. In the city, where the plot unfolds, the houses are tall and thin. Pressed one beside the other, the rows form ducts, create gaps into which the sun falls only in the afternoon, shining almost vertical. The houses along the street are several levels stacked one above the other, connected by steep stairs, like the rays of the sun at its zenith.
Every street is like fate, every house like faith. But this is a city, not a metaphor.
In the spring, when hot days announce the bullfighting season, canopies are hung above the streets. White canvas sheets, rinsed by rain, dried by heat, like clouds drifting at the height of the tallest floor, they mimic the shape of the streets for the birds.
Is that all?
In the evening… Under the soaring curtains, lamps are hung between houses. Lit at dusk, the lamps turn the streets into tunnels of light, piercing the darkness. They are quenched at bedtime. When the light disappears, the canopies fill with the breath of night, sailing in search of the Golden Fleece or to Ithaca. In the streets, late passers carry lanterns before them, deep-sea fish paying no attention to the sails above their heads, mistaking them for the Milky Way, which nobody will ever measure, whose stardust nobody will ever shake from their feet.
That it?
If you look up, you can read the traces of cat paws and bird feathers, or see a skinny cat who lives only on love and barley.
Oh!
There, straight from the open window jumps a barely clothed youth! A flight of triumph? Young like Icarus, but skillful like Daedalus, he balances a moment on the canvas trampoline, then rushes in the direction of the Cathedral. Barefoot, he leaps as though in seven-league boots. His every step is ascension, the moon kissing his sweaty breast through an open shirt. He rises like a balloon of the Montgolfier brothers, like the first plane of the Wright brothers. Flying is a brotherly thing. Jumping too. And further and further, like a cricket, like a grasshopper, like locusts…
Locusts? I should not have used that word. Suddenly, behind his jumping back another figure appears. He runs like an Andalusian dog, fully clothed, heavy boots, an overcoat. What’s this? A sword of Toledo steel, cold and sharp like the moonlight. Stretched out just, just behind the youth’s back:
- Turn around! You coward! You took my—
A thrust! The sword pierces the back of the shirt and emerges through the front. Blood from the youth’s back repeated on his breast. Two stains. Pierced through.
The pursued does not fall. As if he does not notice the strike and the blood, he jumps ahead, leaping over the sagging sheets. Across the Milky Way canopy, he traces a new constellation, composed only of Mars, repeated blotches of red.
The pursuer, after delivering the blow, catches his foot in a seam. There is the sound of tearing cloth, the sheets rip in two and open beneath the feet of the offender, throwing him into the abyss. He grabs an edge with one hand, grips his sword with the other like a precious treasure. The material slips from his grasp and he tumbles onto the lamp below, onto the rope, which he clutches, this time with both hands. The rope rips from one wall and, flying like a pendulum, he slams into the opposing wall—then he falls limply into the street beside his humming sword.
Silence.
Nobody awoke, no one had seen his fall. The sail above the street swayed to the rhythm of snores. The sky cried a lonely star that leaked into the grave. An auburn shadow crawled from the alley, picked up the blade, which flashed in the darkness, and fled towards the Jewish quarter. And then another shadow and another… The second grabbed the purse and jewels, and the third looked in the robbed man’s face and—like a Good Samaritan—began to howl:
- Help!!!
On the ground, without feeling, lay Don Miguel de Juaclac, the public prosecutor of Toledo. Of the jumping youth, not a trace remained, if you don’t count the red stars on the canvas sky.
Who he was and whose blood this is, nobody will know. Nobody except You and I. Only we know, this leaping youth was named Narciso Tomé. This is his story. Keep it for yourself, as a warning. I don’t have anything to do with it. I’m just telling it.
I am this story.
Narciso is me. 
 
About the cover
The cover image uses the oil painting, El caballero de la mano en el pecho by El Greco, which was created in Toledo in 1580 and is currently on display at the Museo del Prado. In English, its title has been translated as The Gentleman with His Hand at His Breast. The subject’s identity is shrouded in mystery; it may be a portrait of Juan de Silva y Ribera or a self-portrait of El Greco himself.
The image was horizontally flipped and the face of the man adjusted to a “regular” perception by removing the deformations caused by El Greco’s astigmatism. The original has been left, giving the portrait the appearance of having two faces, revealing the duality present in the novel’s main character. The sword figures heavily in the story’s plot and acts as a reference to Toledan steel.

story:
**Update** Thanks to the generosity of so many donors, we have met and exceeded our fundraising goals for Storyteller and Head Start, and are now raising funds to offer books to Artesania Para La Familia, to be added to a distribution they will do in January to families in Carpinteria, along with art supplies and protective masks. Any donations of books using the existing perks on the right will go to Artesania Para La Familia. We so appreciate your continued support! Thank you!** 

We hope you enjoyed the reading of Why Am I  and learning about our campaign partners in the video above. Thank you for sharing the love this holiday season by joining us at Seven Seas Press, as we gift this delightful book to 250 (or more!) three through five-year-old children served by Head Start and Storyteller Children’s Center.

We chose these outstanding organizations for their commitment to providing services to low-income families and children, and those living below or close to the poverty guideline, including those who meet the federal definition of homelessness. 

For more information about Head Start and Storyteller and the exceptional work they do, click here:

www.communifysb.org/childrens-services/head-start

www.storytellercenter.org

Why Am I  is a dreamy, soulful, joyous journey though a delightful day, beginning with a predawn discovery in the garden, and ending in a dance by moonlight with a sprinkling of stardust. Echoes of curiosity, respect and appreciation for the miracle of our natural world resonate from cover to cover. In addition, there is a comprehensive Discussion and Activity Guide at the back of the book for parents and teachers to use.

"Why Am I is as soothing as a lullaby. Lush illustrations engage children immediately, and the musical text speaks to their hearts. It recognizes that children have big questions and that we can respond gently and without moralizing. Reading Why Am I is a beautiful way to start the morning, a calming break in the middle of a busy day, and a sweet way to say good-night. It’s a helpful book to share with children during trying times, and an equally wonderful book to read in moments of joy and wonder. Conceived as a book for children, this is one of those poetic pieces that is likely to become a comforting adult favorite as well.”

~ Beverly Abrams ~ Mother, Lifelong Educator, School Founder and Administrator

The team at Seven Seas Press is passionate about the well-being of children. We pay close attention to world events that are affecting children, and connect with local, national, and international groups providing support. We partner with them to get our books to children and their caregivers in a timely way.

And we are grateful to partner with individuals like you, who would like to help make the holidays a little sweeter for some precious children. Thank you for joining us, and enjoying these special discounted rates for the duration of the campaign.

Please click on a “Perk" for more detailed information. If you don't see a perk that fits your needs, just send us a message (click on the blue letters: Ask A Question, in the upper right of the campaign page by our logo) and we'll make one especially for you. And we're so pleased to be able to offer a hardcover option with this campaign! You will be given the option at checkout to select either the English version or bilingual Spanish/English. You will also be given the opportunity to add additional copies of Why Am I to your order at checkout.

Thank you for your generous support. And please share this link with friends and family: https://igg.me/at/whyami

Seven Seas Press is a 501(c)3 Public Charity EIN 83-0792556. Donations of books and funds are fully tax deductible.

Learn more: www.sevenseaspress.org

story:
Short Summary

Hello fellow friends, family, and contributors! We are the co-founders of RANT Publishing, Sophie Binns and Eleonora Vaccariello. 

 

We formed a strong bond in college through our love for the social sciences, literature, and a hunger for knowledge. We never shied away from impassioned debates of hot button issues and have always been advocates for social justice. The idea for RANT flourished in the midst of the frenzied political climate during one of the wildest years of everyone’s lives; 2020. 

 

During this crazy time, we wanted to educate ourselves on various social issues so we chose to seek out books that were written by marginalized groups — It was throughout our searches that we realized the inherent bias that exists within the publishing industry as well as the lack of liable platforms where individuals can seek out informative literature on critical social topics. 

 

...That’s when the idea for RANT Publishing was born.

 

RANT Publishing will provide an outlet for authors who seek to promoting powerful content that delves into unorthodox topics such as mental health struggles, immigration, homelessness, racism, and much more. RANT will support the integration of these topics across genres. These can include both fiction and non-fiction, can be blatant or more subtle, and will not discriminate. We vow to value high-quality literature and uplift authors with didactic messages by buttressing their talent and creativity.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We’re seeking approximately $15,000 dollars in funding. About 50% of this money will go toward website development costs, marketing and PR, legal fees, and author recruitment. The other 50% will go toward the graphic design electronic book covers, editing, and creating the ebooks themselves. 

 

If you contribute, you will receive a package of RANT-branded items. Such as pens, notebooks, stickers, a T-shirt, and out favorite— a chance to win a 1-year subscription to our books!

 

The Impact

The underlying goal for RANT Publishing is to educate people and to give a voice to talented, underrepresented artists. If you contribute to our business, you will help give these individuals a safe platform to share their stories. As a bonus, you will also help two young female entrepreneurs reach their dream of owning a business that can make a small, yet important different in the world. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Competing against large companies such as the “big five” and other current eBook publishing platforms will be a trying endeavor. Although a small number of independent publishers are attempting to change the norms of the industry, they lack the scope and outreach that we envision for RANT. Despite the challenges we face, we have come to realize that other individuals, particularly younger generations, have similar aspirations as we do. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute, don’t worry! You will still  be helping us by spreading the word about RANT Publishing and by sharing our campaign.

Thank you everyone for your support!! It means the world to us. We are so excited about this journey, and we cannot wait to bring you some amazing content.

story:
Év végére tervezzük ennek az ünnepi kötetnek a kiadását Magyarországon. A könyv természetesen Izraelben is kapható lesz.

Ki álmodta meg Izrael államát?

Kinek a filmjét nevezték először Oscar-díjra?

Ki hamisította Eichmann útlevelét?

Ki fejlesztette ki a Vaskupolát?

Mindezekre választ kap, aki belelapoz ebbe az ünnepi albumba, melyet Izrael állam függetlenségének 70. évfordulójára készítettük. 70 magyar vonatkozású izraeli történet szerepel benne, ismert és elismert, de leginkább szerintünk bemutatásra érdemes magyar származású személyiségekről. Magyarországon adjuk ki, magyar nyelven. 

Miért 1000$?

A könyv gyakorlatilag készen van – teljes mértékben önkéntes munkával írtuk a cikkeket, de a korrektúra és a borítóterv is hasonló módon készült. Jelenleg a tördelés és nyomdai előkészítés utolsó fázisain dolgozunk – szintén önkéntes alapon. 

Ezzel a kampánnyal a könyv magyarországi kiadásához toborzunk támogatókat, mivel a kiadás költségei – elsősorban a nyomdaköltség – meghaladják az alapítvány pénzügyi lehetőségeit. 

És ha több pénz gyűlik össze?

Abban az esetben, ha 1000 dollárnál több pénz gyűlne össze, a fennmaradó összeget a kötet előbb angol-, aztán héber nyelvű kiadásának finanszírozására fordítanánk. Az angol fordítás már teljes egészében kész van.

Banki átutalás

→ Név: Izraelinfo
→ Bank Mizrahi Tefahot (20) 
→ Fiók: 514
→ Számlaszám: 236690
→ IBAN: IL65 0205 1400 0000 0236 690
→ SWIFT: MIZBILIT

Hetven magyar arc

Hetven magyar arc Izrael állam történetéből: vannak a listánkon köztudott dolgok, melyeket az egész világ ismer, mint például az Aviva módszer vagy a krav maga, és vannak az albumban olyan magyar felmenőkkel rendelkező izraeli személyek és fogalmak, amelyek minden nap itt vannak a kezünk ügyében vagy a fejünk felett, mint például a Vaskupola, vannak tudósok – még Nobel-díjas is –, nagy művészek, híres színészek, zenészek, költők.

 

Jair Lapid írta nekünk

A könyv előszavát Jair Lapid kneszet-képviselő írta. Ebből egy részlet:

"Kétlem, hogy bárki a magyar zsidóknál gyorsabban integrálódott volna Izraelben. Ha nem lett volna olyan rettenetes akcentusuk, észre sem vette volna senki, hogy a magyarok máshonnan jöttek. Egy magyar zsidó, akit Herzl Tivadarnak hívtak, és aki a Dohány utcai zsinagóga melletti házban született, megálmodta a zsidók államát, a szomszédai pedig az elsők között eredtek álmai nyomába. Ők nemcsak kivándorolni akartak Erecbe, hanem új hazát teremteni ott kávéházzal, színházzal, újsággal, szatírával. A magyarok azzal a céllal alijáztak Izraelbe, hogy haladéktalanul izraelivé váljanak...  Igazi cionisták voltak, de hitük szerint a cionizmus lényege nem abban áll, hogy feláldozzuk magunkat a szent hazáért, hanem hogy ott egy normális államot teremtünk és minden percet kiélvezünk. Izráel országában kelt életre a zsidó nép – aztán jöttek a magyarok, és így szóltak hozzá: „Na gyere, gyere, ülj le, együnk valamit..."

Heisler András is ajánlja

Magyarországról pedig Heisler András, a MAZSIHISZ elnöke írt személyes, megható ajánlást a könyv kiadásához, melyet ezekkel a szavakkal zár: 

"...Fontos e könyv, mert bemutatja, hogy mi magyar zsidók nem csak távolról szeretjük ezt a csodálatos országot, de a magyar zsidók az élet számtalan területén alkottak nagyot, Izrael dicsőségére."

Az Izraelinfo Alapítvány

A projektet – önkéntes alapon – egy Izraelben bejegyzett, magyar nyelvű izraeli újságírással foglalkozó alapítvány (Izraelinfo) készíti.

Pár szót rólunk, az Izraelinfóról, a kiadványt létrehozó alkotóközösségről:

Az Izraelben bejegyzett "Izraelinfo Alapítvány" magyarul beszélő izraeliek közössége, akik lelkesedésből és önkéntes alapon azért tevékenykednek, hogy a magyar nyelvű izraeli média éljen és virágozzék, a magyar olvasóközönség első kézből tájékozódhasson Izrael állam mindennapjairól. Az alapítvány célja elsősorban a magyar nyelvű izraeli újságírás támogatása, fejlesztése. Projektjeink között szerepel az izraelinfo.com magyar nyelvű, kizárólag Izraellel foglalkozó honlap fenntartása és működtetése, melyen személyes írásokat, valamint az izraeli közélet aktuális eseményeiről szóló tudósításokat, cikkeket, kommentárokat és véleményeket jelentetünk meg magyar nyelven. Ezen kívül szervezünk a céljainkkal összefüggő témákban előadásokat, konferenciákat, közönségtalálkozókat is. 

A 70-es Projekt

A 2018-as év elsősorban Izrael állam 70 éves fennállásáról szólt, ezt pedig egy különleges projekttel szerettük volna megünnepelni. Hetven magyar vonatkozású történetet kerestünk és írtunk meg Izrael állam történetében, melyeket egy erre a célra létrehozott weboldalon hetven napon át tettünk közzé – az utolsót (na kiről? természetesen Herzl Tivadarról!) a jeles ünnep napján.

Sokat tanultunk ezekből a történetekből, mert általuk megismerhettük, hogyan jött létre Izrael állama, kik alapították és kik alkotják ma, milyen értékei vannak – mindezt az ország egy kicsiny keresztmetszetéből nézve, csak a magyar vonatkozású történeteket kiragadva. Szeretnénk, ha minél többen megismernék ezeket a történeteket – és ezen keresztül magát Izraelt is, 

Egy nyomtatott album kilép az internet világából, megfogható tárgyként foglalhat helyet polcainkon.

Egyszóval: 70 izraeli magyar története a könyvespolcra!!!

Az angol fordítás már teljes egészében kész van.Banki átutalás→ Név: Izraelinfo→ Bank Mizrahi Tefahot (20) → Fiók: 514→ Számlaszám: 236690→ IBAN: IL65 0205 1400 0000 0236 690→ SWIFT: MIZBILITHetven magyar arcHetven magyar arc Izrael állam történetéből: vannak a listánkon köztudott dolgok, melyeket az egész világ ismer, mint például az Aviva módszer vagy a krav maga, és vannak az albumban olyan magyar felmenőkkel rendelkező izraeli személyek és fogalmak, amelyek minden nap itt vannak a kezünk ügyében vagy a fejünk felett, mint például a Vaskupola, vannak tudósok – még Nobel-díjas is –, nagy művészek, híres színészek, zenészek, költők. Jair Lapid írta nekünkA könyv előszavát Jair Lapid kneszet-képviselő írta. Ebből egy részlet:"Kétlem, hogy bárki a magyar zsidóknál gyorsabban integrálódott volna Izraelben. Ha nem lett volna olyan rettenetes akcentusuk, észre sem vette volna senki, hogy a magyarok máshonnan jöttek. Egy magyar zsidó, akit Herzl Tivadarnak hívtak, és aki a Dohány utcai zsinagóga melletti házban született, megálmodta a zsidók államát, a szomszédai pedig az elsők között eredtek álmai nyomába. Ők nemcsak kivándorolni akartak Erecbe, hanem új hazát teremteni ott kávéházzal, színházzal, újsággal, szatírával. A magyarok azzal a céllal alijáztak Izraelbe, hogy haladéktalanul izraelivé váljanak...  Igazi cionisták voltak, de hitük szerint a cionizmus lényege nem abban áll, hogy feláldozzuk magunkat a szent hazáért, hanem hogy ott egy normális államot teremtünk és minden percet kiélvezünk. Izráel országában kelt életre a zsidó nép – aztán jöttek a magyarok, és így szóltak hozzá: „Na gyere, gyere, ülj le, együnk valamit..."Heisler András is ajánljaMagyarországról pedig Heisler András, a MAZSIHISZ elnöke írt személyes, megható ajánlást a könyv kiadásához, melyet ezekkel a szavakkal zár: "...Fontos e könyv, mert bemutatja, hogy mi magyar zsidók nem csak távolról szeretjük ezt a csodálatos országot, de a magyar zsidók az élet számtalan területén alkottak nagyot, Izrael dicsőségére."Az Izraelinfo AlapítványA projektet – önkéntes alapon – egy Izraelben bejegyzett, magyar nyelvű izraeli újságírással foglalkozó alapítvány (Izraelinfo) készíti.Pár szót rólunk, az Izraelinfóról, a kiadványt létrehozó alkotóközösségről:Az Izraelben bejegyzett "Izraelinfo Alapítvány" magyarul beszélő izraeliek közössége, akik lelkesedésből és önkéntes alapon azért tevékenykednek, hogy a magyar nyelvű izraeli média éljen és virágozzék, a magyar olvasóközönség első kézből tájékozódhasson Izrael állam mindennapjairól. Az alapítvány célja elsősorban a magyar nyelvű izraeli újságírás támogatása, fejlesztése. Projektjeink között szerepel az izraelinfo.com magyar nyelvű, kizárólag Izraellel foglalkozó honlap fenntartása és működtetése, melyen személyes írásokat, valamint az izraeli közélet aktuális eseményeiről szóló tudósításokat, cikkeket, kommentárokat és véleményeket jelentetünk meg magyar nyelven. Ezen kívül szervezünk a céljainkkal összefüggő témákban előadásokat, konferenciákat, közönségtalálkozókat is. A 70-es ProjektA 2018-as év elsősorban Izrael állam 70 éves fennállásáról szólt, ezt pedig egy különleges projekttel szerettük volna megünnepelni. Hetven magyar vonatkozású történetet kerestünk és írtunk meg Izrael állam történetében, melyeket egy erre a célra létrehozott weboldalon hetven napon át tettünk közzé – az utolsót (na kiről? természetesen Herzl Tivadarról!) a jeles ünnep napján.Sokat tanultunk ezekből a történetekből, mert általuk megismerhettük, hogyan jött létre Izrael állama, kik alapították és kik alkotják ma, milyen értékei vannak – mindezt az ország egy kicsiny keresztmetszetéből nézve, csak a magyar vonatkozású történeteket kiragadva. Szeretnénk, ha minél többen megismernék ezeket a történeteket – és ezen keresztül magát Izraelt is, Egy nyomtatott album kilép az internet világából, megfogható tárgyként foglalhat helyet polcainkon.Egyszóval: 70 izraeli magyar története a könyvespolcra!!!

story:
Dear Friends and Fans of Poetry,

It is with beaming pride that I'm happy to say that Spooky Girlfriend Press is turning ten years old this year. When I started the press in a basement apartment in Minnesota while earning my MFA, I couldn't imagine the amazing authors I'd get to work with or the stunning quality of poetry I'd have the privilege of releasing. We published Nicole Steinberg's debut, Getting Lucky. We've published 13 physical chapbooks (including a pizza poem anthology and a non-fiction collection) and three digital titles. We love what we do and we want to GO BIG this year and release another essential collection into the world.

Help Us Celebrate Our 10-Year Anniversary!

To celebrate, we want to publish our second full-length collection of poetry by the amazingly talented Amber Nelson. Many of you may recognize Amber as one of the driving forces behind the much beloved (and missed) alice blue. But in addition to promoting the work of others, Amber is a great poet in her own right and we think her book, The Sexiest Man Alive, will be a book you love. Here's Amber talking a little big about where this book came from:

"So, one day, in 2011, I was at the grocery store waiting in line. The line was kind of long and I was pretty tired from an exerting session at the gym, and People Magazine was there, just staring at me. And I was staring back, looking at this cover full of women who I didn’t recognize. And I was just confused. Like, aren’t these magazines supposed to be covered with famous people so that you want to buy them and read all about the intimate and sordid details of their lives?

You see, I was relatively freshly out of grad school where I took classes, taught classes, worked a part time job, partied a little too much, and didn’t have a television. It was during this time that the movie Twilight came out. I was home for the holidays and told my mom “Hey, I hear there’s a new vampire movie out. Wanna go see it?” That was literally the only thing I knew about this phenomenon going in. It was a couple weeks before I learned of the chaos that surrounded it. 

My life in Seattle my first year after grad school wasn’t much different from my time going to grad school in Boise, except replace partying too much with training for a 100 mile bike ride and volunteering and watching old movies with my gang of introverts.

Anyway, back to the grocery store – there I was staring at these strangers and thinking about the weird nature of celebrity. At work the next day, I asked my coworkers for any old issues of People they might have lying around. The first that came to me? The Sexiest Man Alive 2011: Bradley Cooper. I didn’t know what I was doing, only that I wanted to think about this, this weird thing, this celebrity, this elective public eye, this performance of self. And so these poems were born.

Writing them was an exercise in patience. They are hard to write. Tons of research went in to each one, building a large corpus of pubic speech to work from. And then came the laborious process of picking at and shaping that public speech into something that ultimately represented each Sexist Man Alive’s performance of their own self as I experienced it. Writing them took a lot of mental and emotional energy, and a fair amount of coffee, beer and wine.

In the end, it was all worth it. I learned a lot about these strangers. I learned a lot about what it means to be a celebrity, and it isn’t all pretty. It’s not always a romping good time. But sometimes it is.

I also quickly learned who the women were on the cover of that fateful People Magazine. They were the Kardashians."

Your Contribution!

Your help will go a long way in making Amber's book a reality! First and foremost, your contribution will help pay for production costs of the book (300 copies). Your generosity will also help with the following:

  • Shipping! (Getting Lucky taught us how much it costs to ship books)
  • Art! (proper compensation for our great cover artist, Ben Giles)
  • Amber! (funds for a book tour)

Spooky Girlfriend Press is a labor of love that's made possible by supporters of small, independent presses, like you. I sincerely thank you for your time and consideration and hope you'll join us in celebrating ten years of the press by helping us publish The Sexiest Man Alive!

Spookily,
Nate

...

What People Are Saying About The Sexiest Man Alive

"I thought it would be funnier, honestly. Lighter. A “romp” of some sort. It made me laugh, it made me cry, it made me punchy, but ultimately it left me sort of aghast and that’s hard to do. It made me think about how trapped people can be by their performance of self, by cultural ideas of maleness, and about the generational trauma that gender can inflict. How the internet, the speed of the media/culture, and the increasing mad-grab commodification here in domestic capitalism’s twilight, has changed celebrity and our relationship to it. I had to rethink about what is sexy to me, to other people, and what that means. This shift away from nuance and reflection (and patriarchal life-lesson passing) towards a frantic look-at-me shallowness of concentrated maleness-as-product-for-consumption, with its ultimate loss of real sense of self/place in humanity, I mean…  :/ " -- Sarah Gallien, cofounder and editor, alice blue review

***

Links

Please consider helping spread the word about our campaign on social media! You can find us in these places:

Facebook: Spooky Girlfriend Press
Instagram: spookygirlfriendpress
Twitter: @Spooky_GF_Press

SOBRE EL LIBRO

El indio Lacota es  una obra innovadora porque es un cuento hipnótico. Mientras la lees tú eres uno de los personajes, que sin darte cuenta, a través de las técnicas hipnóticas vas entrando en trance y pones a trabajar tu inconsciente, de una forma... Inconsciente.

SOBRE LA CAMPAÑA

Esta campaña se realiza con tres fines:

1- Costear, con el dinero recaudado de la venta del libro, los gastos de edición, producción y promoción de la obra.

2- Dar promoción previa a la obra y hacer parte de ella accesible a sus futuros lectores.

3- Medir el éxito que puede tener la obra antes de ser publicada.

Al colaborar con esta campaña, no haces una donación, sino que compras el libro del autor a precios de preventa y adquieres el privilegio de leerlo antes de que salga a la venta. 

Puedes apoyar comprando cualquiera de las recompensas que hay en esta página: desde el libro electrónico hasta la versión en papel con dedicatoria especial. ¡Cualquier apoyo es bienvenido!

story:
Founder of MycoSymbiotics, William Padilla-Brown is a social entrepreneur, citizen scientist, mycologist, amateur phychologist, writer, Youtube vlogger, contributing editor for Fungi mag, researcher, poet, and father. William holds Permaculture Design Certificates acquired through Susquehanna Permaculture and NGOZI. William is leading the country in the field of Cordyceps cultivation. William regularly teaches across the country at mushrooms clubs, festivals, Agricultural conferences, and more.

In 2015, William hosted the first annual MycoSymbiotics Mushroom & Arts Festival (MycoFest) in Duncannon, Pennsylvania. During the first MycoFest, Charlie Aller of Mush Luv Mushrooms found a Cordyceps militaris mushroom and gifted it to William. With this first specimen in 2015, William cultured it and shared it with everyone who showed interest. At the time this was only 30 people. Out of 30 people, only one person corresponded on growing the mushroom, Ryan Paul-Gates of Terrestrial Fungi. Ryan and William collaborated efforts in understanding techniques for the first grow. By 2016, William was working on the first Cordyceps Cultivation Handbook, which was released in January 2017.
 
 
 
 
Cordyceps are the sexy new health product on the market toted with benefits including
  • Increased Energy & Endurance
  • Increased Oxygen Intake & Respiratory Function
  • Increased Sex Drive & Pleasure Potentiator 
  • Anti-Aging
  • Anti-Malarial 
  • Anti-HIV
But are they really new?
 
Cordyceps, more specifically Cordyceps militaris is a small orange club-shaped entomopathogenic fungus. Let's break this down. Entomo- of an insect; relating to insects Pathogen- an infectious agent. So basically, it's a fungus that infects insects. Don't worry! Corydceps will not infect humans, and, in fact, they are proving to be quite beneficial for human health!  Cordyceps have been revered in traditional Chinese medicine for a few thousand years. Cordyceps are now showing themselves to us in the English speaking world. Cordyceps are prized for their main active ingredient Cordycepin, which has been researched for its myriad potentials. 

We are even starting to understand Cordyceps as a biological insecticide, or bio-control. Cordyceps often grow on species of insects that have the potential for overpopulation or decimation of important plants, and trees.
 
 
Join the militaris! 
 
This Indiegogo campaign is focused on raising funds to finish the Cordyceps Cultivation Handbook Volume 2. This book will be a completely elevated version of the original Cordyceps Cultivation Handbook. The original handbook was completely funded by the author with all research done by him in a small home-scale operation. Since the release of the first book, William has traveled the country teaching and visiting new Cordyceps farmers. In 2017, he started the first North American large-scale commercial Cordyceps farm in a warehouse in Weaverville, North Carolina. 

Now equipped with 5 years of experience with Cordyceps and seemingly countless connections, this new book will be a compilation of thousands of successes and failures, and professional research from independent laboratories, and universities. 

This book will be the Standard for Cordyceps cultivation, Wild Collection, and Consumption. With stunning visuals, well-thought-out instructions, and answers to questions, this book will be suitable for beginners and experienced growers alike.
 
This book will touch on:
  • The History of Cordyceps
  • The Future of Cordyceps
  • Wild Harvesting Cordyceps
  • Host Species
  • Cordyceps as a Biological Control / Bio Pesticide
  • The effects of Climate Change and Over Harvesting on Wild Cordyceps
  • Medicinal & Nutritional values of Fruiting Bodies & Mycelium
  • Building a Cordy-centric Laboratory
  • Building out a Cordyceps Farm
  • Substrates (With research backing for best yields and active compounds)
  • Growing Mycelium for food and products
  • Producing Fruiting Bodies
  • Harvesting
  • Storage
  • Extraction Techniques (Research Backed)
  • Dealing with Pests & Contamination
  • Epicurean Cordyceps for Culinary Enjoyment (With Recipes from a Chef)
This book will be Full Color, Paper Back and expected to be over 150 pages. The book is set to be released sometime around December, January, or February 2019. Contributors will receive updates on the progression of the book and gain access to some of our research results..
 
 
The $14,000 dollar goal will mostly be funding Research through Independent Laboratories. The goal will also be funding Publishing, Printing, and Distribution.
 
Heres the Breakdown
  • Indiegogo's percentage + Taxes: about $4000
  • Creating and Shipping Non-Book perks: about $600
  • Stipend for Author to secure 2-3 months to work on finishing the book: $2000 
Research

Lab Test including; 

  • Which substrates produce more active constituents
  •  Antioxidant capacity
  • Immune Cell effects
  •  Wild vs Cultivated Mycelium & Fruiting Bodies 
Estimated $5000
 
Publishing
  • Review & Editing $300
  • Printing: about $1500
  • ISBN: $500
 
Wouldn't it be great if we exceeded our $14,000 goal? If we do we have plans, big plans!
 
 
 
Anything beyond these goals will be used to purchase equipment to begin doing more in house research.
 
 
All donations above $5 receive the perks of all tiers below 
The eBook and Physical Copy are significantly discounted for contributors.
 
 
Many thanks to those who believed in my work and helped me to get where I am today! Honestly, there are too many people to feature, but here are a few.
-William 
 
 
Check out these awesome articles & interviews with the Author
 
Civil Eats
Lancaster Online
Probiotic Life Podcast
Get in my Garden Podcast
Cornell Small Farms Program
Spore Addict Times
 
Cordyceps in the Press
New York Times
National Geographic
Vice
 
 

There are so many other ways you can help out!

Like & Share MycoSymbiotics on Facebook

Share this Campaign with Friends on Facebook & Twitter

Share this Campaign on your Instagram Story

Add us on Instagram & Share our pages with friends @MycoSymbiote @MyoSymbiotics

Become a Patron on our Patreon
