Cette campagne est maintenant terminée! Vous pouvez vous procurer le livre de la norme BNQ 21000 dès maintenant.

Merci à tous ceux qui ont contribué à faire de cette campagne de financement participatif un succès. Au cours de l'année 2013, il y aura une série d'articles qui seront publiés pour vous aider à démarrer une démarche de développement durable.

 

 

COMMENT DEVENIR UN LEADER EN DÉVELOPPEMENT DURABLE

Guide pour intégrer la nouvelle norme BNQ 21000 à vos pratiques d'affaires

 

> Avez-vous envie d'aider votre organisation à prendre le virage du développement durable?

> Comment convaincre votre patron d'aller de l'avant?

> Par où commencer, comment faire?

> Quelles sont les facteurs de succès d'une démarche de développement durable?

> Quels sont les pièges à éviter?

> Qu'est-ce que la norme BNQ 21000, comment l'utiliser?

 

Je m'appelle Jean-Sébastien Trudel (ma bio) et je travaille à la publication d'un livre pour vous aider à devenir un leader en développement durable à l'aide de la méthode BNQ 21000.

 

MISE EN CONTEXTE

Depuis près de 10 ans, j'accompagne les dirigeants et les gestionnaires dans l'intégration du développement durable dans leurs pratiques d'affaires. Certains projets d'accompagnement connaissent un véritable succès alors que d'autres ne dépassent pas les initiatives élémentaires, comme instaurer un système de recyclage ou remplacer les tasses jetables par des tasses réutilisables.

Cependant, l'expérience montre que tous les projets qui connaissent du succès ont un point en commun: ils sont pilotés par des leaders passionnés et respectés de la direction et de leurs collègues.

Aussi sait-on que ces leaders manquent généralement d'outils et de moyens pour prendre le virage du développement durable. C'est pourquoi le gouvernement du Québec a financer un projet de normalisation d'une méthode d'accompagnement: le BNQ 21000.

 

QU'EST-CE QUE LA MÉTHODE BNQ 21000?
 
Le Bureau de normalisation du Québec (BNQ) lancera officiellement, le 19 novembre prochain, tous les outils de la nouvelle norme BNQ 21000.

En 2008, le gouvernement du Québec s’est donné comme cible que 20 % des entreprises québécoises aient amorcé une démarche de développement durable d’ici 2013.

Le Projet BNQ 21000 vise donc à offrir une norme de référence et des outils pour que les entreprises d'ici puissent progresser dans une perspective de développement durable.

 

POURQUOI UN LIVRE?

L'idée du livre est d'aider les leaders dans les organisations et les entreprises à mettre en oeuvre une démarche de développement durable.

Il vise à leur donner des outils et à départager les approches qui fonctionnent le mieux de celles qui conduisent à l'échec. Bref, il s'agit d'apprendre des erreurs des autres pour progresser plus facilement et plus rapidement.

Pour y arriver, le livre présentera sous forme de guide la nouvelle méthode BNQ 21000.

 

POURQUOI MAINTENANT?

Depuis 2010, je suis mandaté pour contribuer au développement de ce projet, qui a été testé dans près d'une soixantaine d'organisations par une douzaine de consultants.

Au cours de cette période, la norme et les outils ont fait l'objet de plusieurs révisions. À partir du 19 novembre prochain, tous les référentiels et les outils seront rendus publics gratuitement.

Cependant, il n'y a pas de guide vulgarisé pour les gens d'affaires. C'est ce que je compte faire à l'aide de ce livre, en bonifiant la méthode à partir d'exemples vécus sur le terrain et en partageant mes meilleurs trucs pour vous aider à réaliser votre démarche de manière autonome.

 

POURQUOI NE PAS AVOIR UN ÉDITEUR?

Ce livre propose une approche différente de mise en marché:
  • Ce sera un livre sans papier. Il sera disponible uniquement en version électronique.
  • Il sera distribué exclusivement en ligne.
  • Différentes options seront disponibles avec le livre, comme un DVD d'une formation pour les employés, des mises à jours ou encore, du coaching individualisé.
Cette formule vise à tirer profit des nouvelles possibilités d'Internet, du multimédia et des tablettes numériques. Il s'agit donc d'un laboratoire qui ne convient pas aux méthodes traditionnelles des éditeurs.
 

À PROPOS DU TITRE!

Avec des titres comme:

  • Arrêtons de pisser dans de l'eau embouteillée
  • Le grand mensonge vert

On me demande souvent quel sera le titre du prochain livre. La pression est donc grande pour trouver un titre original. Il sera dévoilé ici en primeur le 9 octobre 2012, vers 15h!

D'ici là, je vous invite me dire lequel des trois titres encore en lice vous préférez en VOTANT.

MISE À JOUR: La période de sondage est maintenant terminé. Le titre retenu sera:

Au secours! La planète se meurt et mon boss s'en fout

Merci aux 94 personnes qui ont pris le temps de voter. Ce choix a été préféré par 42% d'entre elles.

 
À QUOI SERVIRONT LES FONDS?
 
La publication d'un livre, même électronique, implique des coûts importants, pour la plupart préalables au lancement, tels que:
  • La recherche et la rédaction (déplacements, frais de communication, etc.)
  • Le graphisme et la mise en page
  • La correction
  • La révision et l'édition
  • La programmation et le développement d'un site Internet
  • La réservation des marques, ISBN, site, etc.
  • La campagne de promotion et les relations publiques
  • L'enregistrement du DVD pour la formation (caméras, micros, éclairage, salle de conférence, montage et production)
  • La soirée de lancement

Au total, le projet coûtera entre 10 000 et 15 000 $.

Mon objectif de financement est au minimum 7 000 $.

 

COMMENT POUVEZ-VOUS AIDER?

Il existe plusieurs façon pour m'aider à réaliser ce projet:

  1. En achetant en pré-vente une copie du livre.
  2. En assistant à la conférence du 31 octobre à Montréal.
  3. En faisant un don de 5 $.
  4. En étant commanditaire.
  5. En devenant un partenaire-affilié (écrivez-moi pour savoir comment).
  6. En diffusant la nouvelle dans vos réseaux.
  7. En donnant une copie à votre patron, à un ami ou à un collègue.

Il vous suffit de cliquer à droite sur l'option de votre choix. Parce que je considère ceux qui me soutienne dans cet effort comme des partenaires privilégiés, les tarifs proposés ici représentent un rabais de 50% par rapport au prix régulier. Merci de votre confiance.

 

COMMENT PARTAGER DANS VOS RÉSEAUX?

Si vous diffusez dans Twitter, je vous invite à utiliser le hashtag #BNQ21000.

Vous pouvez également visiter notre page Facebook.

 

Merci!

story:
"Dolores De Luce's memoir is unlike any I've ever read. It's as if the gods of comedy and pathos, wisdom and chaos were zooming these pages all at once. Never have I laughed so loud. Seldom have I taken such a pause because of righteous fury. The writer is an original force of nature, abundant with talent and stories that amaze, delight, and instill wonder."  --Mark Thompson, author and editor

Welcome!

Thanks so much for helping me manifest my goal of publishing my first memoir. My Life, a Four Letter Word: Confessions of a Counter Culture Diva. It is a project I am very passionate about. The memoir is a send up to “my big little life” and a fabled era and a community that I am so very grateful for today.

Being what the economy is in this strange new world I call past- middle- age, I have exhausted leads to find a publishing house for my first book. Therefore, I have decided to take the advice of esteemed writer friends and self-publish this work of love.

Your contributions will be used wisely to pay for the many aspects to suceed with my vision for this project: editing, art work, formating and printing for both a hard copy and formatting for an E-book for your Kindel or Nook. Some of the funds will also help toward the budget for marketing and travel to reading's and book launches at a book store near you.

The publication of My Life, a Four Letter Word: Confessions of a Counter Culture Diva is extremely important to me. It is a portrait of a single mom raising a bi-racial daughter during the tumultuous post Stonewall times inside the Gay Counter Culture. In this ultra-fabulous queer theatrical community I found refuge after being rejected by my family for giving birth to a mixed race daughter.

Written from my view as a  less-than five foot Diva in six inch heels, I created a new family with the most unlikely people under the most unusual circumstances. Through tears and glitter, I confess to my encounters with endless bad boys and loving gay “husbands.” stripping in dive bars, and surviving bitter family estrangements that led to heartfelt reconciliations. And then faced the pain of the AIDS crisis first-hand.

As the adage goes, "What doesn't kill you makes you stronger.” So with candor, humor and the wisdom of a survivor, I offer the lessons learned as well as unique insights from an era that was one of our country’s most vivid periods.

“Dolores DeLuce’s, My Life, a Four Letter Word: Confessions of a Counter Culture Diva, is a sociological study as well as study of sexuality:Ann-Margret meets Margaret Mead. DeLuce has been-there/done-that but she retains an innocence that will melt your heart. Not only did she usher in the queer theatre scene in San Francisco, she then watched her comrades die of the plague as she, single-handedly, raised a daughter. The counter culture diva is brutally herself—in all her fabulousness and painfulness—from beginning to end, making My Life, A Four Letter Word a must read for anyone who wants a peek into the underground from the vantage point of Ms. DeLuce’s teetering pumps.” Michael Kearns. author, actor, activist.

BIO

I have been a performer since 1970 and was trained by the best artists of those times, including the legendary Divine, who mentored my early career on stage. I debuted as a dancing pumpkin in a drag version of Cinderella with the infamous gender-bending Cockettes and guest stared in caberets with the magical Angels of Light.

I began writing for and performed with comedy troupes including White Trash Boom Boom, a girl’s group who wowed the boys in the San Francisco gay bars and performed the same shows for women behind bars in California state prisons.

By 1977, I was nominated for “Best Performer in a Musical,” by The Bay Area Credits Association for the musical revue, Broken Dishes, which I co-wrote and starred in with Amber Waves. I brought my act to Los Angeles where I wrote and starred in a critically acclaimed, multi-media romp, The Last Dance of the Couch Potatoes.

Today I live in Venice Beach and continue to act and write and help promote my grown daughter Viva's singing career.

Your support and contribution to this project means more to me that I can say.  Please help me share my story with the world at large.

If you can’t contribute you can still support my campaign by sharing it with your friends and family on Facebook and Twitter just by clicking the links below. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

Again, thank you so much.


Dolores De Luce

story:
Story of My Book

 

Restaurant Redefined: Adapt and Compete offers insight into trends gaining traction in and shaping the restaurant industry we know today.

My name is Saamia Bukhari and I am the author of Restaurant Redefined: Adapt and Compete. I wrote this book because after researching more about high performing regional restaurants in a private equity internship, I became motivated to learn how these businesses could successfully separate themselves from the competition. 

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover key trends in the industry that truly have the power to change what we think a restaurant means today. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for the restaurant landscape in you. Ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you became a more enlightened consumer.

In this book, you'll learn about key principles that drive restaurant innovation and how to apply it to restaurants in varying stages:

  • Know where the money is: Online food delivery is a billion dollar industry that’s only going to grow and changes the traditional idea of a restaurant
  • Know where the market is: Differentiating one’s self from the competition can happen on multiple levels (food, service, recognition, etc.) and feeds into the overall branding of a restaurant 
  • Know where the value is: Sustainable practices not only grant more varied menus, increase transparency, and drive profits, but uplift the surrounding community

You will love this book if you are a consumer interested in getting the inside scoop on industry knowledge.

Restaurant Redefined: Adapt and Compete is a non-fiction book that speaks to consumers who are looking at trends and innovative applications for the first time.

 

The Book - Restaurant Redefined: Adapt and Compete 

 

The book is written in different parts....​


Part 1 contains Chapters 1-3. This section lays the foundation of the past and current state of the restaurant industry. I explore some necessities in the saturated industry: adapting to trends, thinking about customer behavior, utilizing advancements in technology and more.

Part 2 contains Chapters 4-24. In this section, the trends and principles of restaurant innovation are explained in depth: technology, marketing, sustainability, food choice, and experiential dining. I offer real-life examples to illustrate these trends, from automated restaurant Spyce to Starbucks’ successful loyalty program.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

 

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in July, 2020.
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this Summer.

 

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.


I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish

  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book

And more...

 

About the Author

 

Saamia Bukhari studies at Boston College’s Carroll School of Management. She has interned in varying areas including marketing, operations, private equity, and business development, allowing her to cultivate diverse skills.

Saamia wrote this book because she loves discovering new restaurants, reviewing food, and staying up to date with new trends in the industry. She has combined her passions for business and food together to write a book as interesting as it is informative. She hopes that the knowledge and skills she gained while researching and writing the book will help establish herself to pursue other opportunities in the industry.

Beyond her interests in business, Saamia enjoys competitive sports, card and board games, and various creative outlets. She applies her tenacity in sports, strategy in card games, and inventiveness in art to all her life pursuits. 

For more information you can connect with Saamia at saamia.bukhari@gmail.com as well as through LinkedIn (Saamia Bukhari), Instagram (saamiabukhari), and Twitter (@saamia_bukhari).

 

Risks & Challenges

 

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #restaurantredefined and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Saamia Bukhari

story:
For English translation see below.

 

"Y por eso, compatriotas: pregunte no lo que su país puede hacer por usted, sino lo que usted puede hacer por su país"

Preguntas frecuentes:

En donde se van a depositar los fondos:


Los fondos se desitaran a la siguiente cuenta. Pueden donar acá o como mejores les quede.

 

CUENTA NO: "81-0002060-2"

A NOMBRE DE: ERICK BERNABÉ BARRONDO GARCÍA

BANCO: GYT CONTINENTAL, CUENTA MONETARIA

¿Qué pasa si no llegamos a la meta?

la idea es AYUDAR A ERICK BARRONDO, y eso se logra con el total que estamos tratando de recaudar. En caso de no llegar a la meta, sea cual sea la cantidad de dinero recaudada va a ser depositada íntegramente a la cuenta que Erick Barrondo y su familia deseen. 

¿El sitio es confiable?

Aquí pueden revisar las politicas de privacidad del sitio:

http://www.indiegogo.com/learn/faqs

Hola a todos, mi nombre es Pablo Estrada Fuentes y soy un guatemalteco más.

Licenciado en Publicidad y RPPP de la Universidad de Navarra, mi único sueño es ver una mejor Guatemala y dedico mi vida a ello, desde mis negocios hasta mis hobbies.

Si quieren saber más de mí pueden ver algunas cosas que he hecho:

http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2010/09/26/soc...

http://es.linkedin.com/in/pabloestradaf
www.pabloestradafuentes.com
www.twitter.com/PabloEstrada

La razón por la que decidí hacer este movimiento es para que nosotros los guatemaltecos, sin esperar nada de los gobiernos, le demos una pequeña ayuda a Erick Barrondo.

¿Se han puesto a pensar que la única persona que ha ganado una medalla olímpica para nuestro país vive en una casa de bajos recursos; o que los primeros tres meses como seleccionado durmió en el piso de la casa de su entrenador?

¿Cuánto nos gastamos a la semana en ocio, fiesta, comida rápida o gustos?

Les propongo a los guatemaltecos y el resto del planeta que donen lo que puedan.

Por cada persona que done les ofrezco incluir su nombre en un cartel que le entregaré a Erick, con los nombres de todas las personas que donaron.

Les enviaré una copia digital del documento para que lo tengan de recuerdo.

Al terminar el conteo haré un comunicado en mi página personal www.pabloestradafuentes.com, certificando todos los ingresos y diré la fecha y hora en que le entregaré el dinero a Erick, todo lo haré en linea para que todos seamos parte del movimiento.

cualquier duda, me pueden escribir a mi correo personal.

pabesfu@libropedia.es

Con gusto converso con ustedes,

Pablo

 

 

"Ask not what your country can do for you - ask what you can do for your country"

 Where will we deposit the funds?

You can either donate through this website or directly to the following account, which is Erick Barrondo's personal account.

 

ACCOUNT NUMBER: "81-0002060-2"

NAME: ERICK BERNABÉ BARRONDO GARCÍA

BANK: GYT CONTINENTAL, CUENTA MONETARIA

 

What happens if we do not reach the goal?

The idea is to HELP ERICK BARRONDO with all the money that we are trying to raise. If we do not reach the goal, whatever the amount of money that is raised will be deposited in its entirety to the account where Erick Barrondo and his family wish for it to go.

Is the site reliable?

You can review the sites privacy policies in the following link: 

http://www.indiegogo.com/learn/faqs

Hello, my name is Pablo Estrada Fuentes and I am just another guatemalan. 

I have a degree in Advertising and PR from the University of Navarre, my only dream is to see a better Guatemala and I devote my life to helping achieve that from my business ventures to my hobbies.

If you want to know more about me you can see the following links to review some of the things I have done:

http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/2010/09/26/soc...

http://es.linkedin.com/in/pabloestradaf
www.pabloestradafuentes.com
www.twitter.com/PabloEstrada

The reason why I decided to start this fund raiser is because us, as guatemalan citizens, without expecting the government to do anything for us should help Erick Barrondo in any way we can. 

Have you thought about the fact that the only person that has won an Olympic medal for our country lives in a broken down house? Or that he spent his first three months as an official athlete sleeping on the floor of his trainers house?

How much do we spend each week in parties, fast food, travels or leisure?

I invite guatemalans and people around the world to donate whatever they can. 

For every person that donates I offer you the possibility of including your name on a banner that will be delivered to Erick detailing the names of everyone that contributed with this campaign in his favor. 

I can also send you a digital copy of the document so you can have as a keepsake of the donation.

After the campaign is over I will release a statement via my personal webpage www.pabloestradafuentes.com certifying all the money that we have received and will also announce the date and time in which I will deliver the money to Erick. I will do all of this online so that we can all be part of the movement. 

If you have any doubts you can contact me through my personal e-mail:

pabesfu@libropedia.es

Have you thought about the fact that the only person that has won an Olympic medal for our country lives in a broken down house? Or that he spent his first three months as an official athlete sleeping on the floor of his trainers house?
How much do we spend each week in parties, fast food, travels or leisure?
I invite guatemalans and people around the world to donate whatever they can. 
For every person that donates I offer you the possibility of including your name on a banner that will be delivered to Erick detailing the names of everyone that contributed with this campaign in his favor. 
I can also send you a digital copy of the document so you can have as a keepsake of the donation.
After the campaign is over I will release a statement via my personal webpage www.pabloestradafuentes.com certifying all the money that we have received and will also announce the date and time in which I will deliver the money to Erick. I will do all of this online so that we can all be part of the movement. 
If you have any doubts you can contact me through my personal e-mail:
pabesfu@libropedia.es

story:
My Story

My name is Joseph Paul Haines.  I am a professional science fiction writer of over one hundred short stories whose work has been recognized in almost every collection of year's best fiction. My stories have been reprinted various times, most recently in a collection of the best dystopian short fiction ever written, alongside stories by Ray Bradbury, Shirley Jackson, Harlan Ellison, Kurt Vonnegut, Jr., and Neil Gaiman.  


I've focused on short fiction over the span of my career, honing my story-telling skills and learning the business and art of being a professional writer, but the biggest reason I didn't write novels was that I didn't want to write a novel that couldn't speed you along with the breakneck pace of a short story.  I love the thrill of turning the pages with reckless abandon while reading and I want to produce fiction that does the same for my audience.  Until I found the story I could tell that would yank the reader along at a breathless pace and a character with whom they could fall in love, I wouldn't fall into the trap of so many writers who switched to the long form just because it it was the expected thing to do.


Four months ago, all that changed.  My imagination met a young lady by the name of Punk Jordan and all hell broke loose.


The first book of this planned trilogy is titled, "Marooned," and it is finished, edited and available in e-versions as I write this, with the trade paperback version to follow September 15th, 2011.  The video trailer for the first book is above to give you a taste of the series and I'm writing under the pen-name of P.J. Druce in order to keep this Young Adult series separate from my more adult short stories.


I was able to fund the editing, cover design, interior design, book trailer and extra expenses on my own for Marooned, but due to life changes over the last few weeks I find that the next two are going to need a little help. That's where you come in.


I'd like to raise enough money to fund the publication of the next two books, along with a limited edition hard-back version containing all three books by June of 2012.  Book one is written, book two is in process and book three will immediately follow.   


The Impact

I won't lie to you.  I will proceed with publishing these books on my own even if I don't meet my goal, but I'd most likely have to extend the timeframe.  One of the reasons I pulled these books from consideration by major literary agencies was that I didn't want my readers to have to wait two years just to get their hands on the first book, and then wait another year at least for each successive volume.  I walked away from a potentially large advance in order to bring these books directly to my readers in a timely fashion, but in doing so took on all costs associated with their publication.  I think it's worth it.


What We Need & What You Get

Between professional editing, cover design, marketing and associated fees, the cost of publishing each book with the quality you'd expect from a major publishing house is between a thousand and fifteen hundred dollars.  Yes, it can be done for less but it's always been my belief that if you aren't putting out a product that equalled the quality of anything you can find on the shelves of your local bookstore that you're cheating your readers.  The limited edition hardback will run approximately the same as new cover art and interior design will be necessary.  


Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand if you can't donate to the cause.  Money is tight these days and were that not the case I wouldn't be here asking you to contribute.  If you can't add a few dollars (every one counts!) then pass the link along through social media.  The more people that see this page the more people can help finance this series.  More than anything else, if you'd read all the way to this point, accept my sincere thanks for allowing me a few moments of your time.  More than money, your time and tolerance for allowing me to ask you to help out is the most precious thing you could give.

story:
CRACKERS will be an exciting and exploratory experience in the spirit of the Borders Trilogy. In it, we will look at the illegal side of computer creativity and how cracking and hacking computer games evolved as a unique contemporary phenomenon in the 80s. ​
 


The Atari ST and The Creative People

Volume I, 1984 – 1990, BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS (sold out, PDF available) 
Volume II, 1991 – 1993, BEYOND THE BORDERS (on sale)
Volume III, 1994 – 1997, RETURN OF THE BORDERS (on sale)
Dark Addition, 1984 – 1991, CRACKERS  Episode I (this campaign) 

This additional book is the untold story of the best Atari ST crackers, their exceptional methods and deals, their way of life, desires, successes and setbacks. ​
 

Please note: The cover artwork will be designed at the end of the production. Only in this way can we find an essential representation. Book title and design shown are for illustration purposes only. Please be patient until delivery in 2021 ... ;)


We promise:

  • High Quality book printing
  • English Hardback Edition
  • ~400 colour pages 
  • Offset printing, 120 raster 
  • High pigment inks 
  • 230 x 170 mm landscape format 
  • 135 gr/m² semi-matt illustration paper 
  • Surface sealing (varnished pages)
  • Made in Germany


Quality goals


US$ 20,000 ::::: 1st Goal // reached!
Paperback Edition
Adhesive binding 

US$ 22,000 :::: 2nd Goal // reached!
Hardback Edition
Thread sewn binding

US$ 24,000 ::::: 3rd Goal // reached!
Hardback Edition
Thread sewn binding
Book title printed in high gloss​

Summary

In the beginning there was a troll .... 
 

The digital people of the last century were completely on their own when they began to understand the inner workings of system. Networking became a great longing of the dawning computer age.

Illegal activities on 16-bit computers began after two hackers left the Apple II to face new electronic fields.
 

The idea of the digital troll only came to full bloom in the 2000s. This book tells the story of a group of hitherto unknown computer experts who sacrificed their youth to the gamers’ entertainment. They were called Crackers.


Many excellent programmers whose only home for a long time was the boot sector, learned their craft by breaking a copy protection. It was no easy task. They worked hard at night and found their sources far away from the consumer. Eventually they found success as their raster bars, scroll texts, pixel art and chip music, spreaded through the disk slots of hundreds of thousands of young people who just wanted to play.

Cracktros became popular. The times were a paradise for pirates, for the few lucky ones, as only the people with the most influential contacts were high up enough in the scene and to be able to play the trickiest game called “software piracy”. The 80s felt just right for that and everybody hoped for his secret little slice of illegal pie. 
 

The cracker’s hour, it had to come ...

Read about 42-Crew, The Medway Boys, Cynix, Hackers Of The Arena, B.O.S.S, Fallen Angels, The Marvellous V8, Black Monolith Team, Pompey Pirates, CSS, Fuzion, ICS, MCA, Hotline,
Flame of Finland, D-Bug, Vectronix, TEX, Delight, Adrenaline U.K., Admirables, Bad Boys, BBS, Sewer Software, S.T.C.S. ... and many more.
 

Learn about the structure, the changes, development and history of the greatest cracking associations on the Atari ST computers: Automation, The Blade Runners, Elite, Empire, Federation of Free Traders, The Replicants, The Corporation.


Their experience stands for the 16-bit era of hacking and cracking in general. This book will summarize the dark side of disk life as a unique contemporary spiritual phenomenon. It is our goal to tell the truth behind the entanglements of the games industry in the 80s and 90s. The plot will reveal how it was possible to crack and spread diskette games so efficiently in Europe and worldwide.

In a narrative journey through time, Microzeit will let the top crackers have their say and report from their teenage bedrooms.
 

The Atari ST scene will be the heart of the story, but we also take the journey back to the 8-bit era on the C64 and deliver sidekicks to Apple II, Atari XL, Amstrad CPC and Sinclair Spectrum. Also Amiga insiders joined in.


You will find yourself side by side with the famous swappers and experience what computer life was like at that time. What possibilities and machinations did one have to deal with and how did  they spin the strings to their shady sources. We tell the story from an underground perspective and let it collide with the media, the law and game producers.

Interviews

 

We ask the people. The following underground experts are planned for participation, whether as informer or full interview partner:
 

  • The Lord aka. Tsunoo Rhilty // Troll & Co., 42-Crew, STCS, The Bladerunners 
  • Actarus // STCS, The Bladerunners
  • Ratboy // STCS, The Bladerunners
  • Banzai // STCS, The Bladerunners
  • Zippy // The Medway Boys
  • Floyd // 42-Crew
  • Pet // B.O.S.S.
  • HC-Crack // The Bladerunners
  • Arthur Dent // Copy Service Stuttgart
  • The Law // Automation, D-Bug
  • Was (Not Was) // LSD, Automation, D-Bug
  • E.G.B. // Cynix, Automation
  • Brume // Elite
  • The Alien // Pompey Pirates
  • Robocamp // VMAX
  • Metallinos // Tristar and Red Sector Inc.
  • Lethal // Hotline
  • Sledge // Hotline, Elite, Elitendo
  • Lowlife // Hotline, Elite, Elitendo
  • Angel // HMD, Elite
  • R.AL // Hackers Of The Arena
  • Excalibur // A-Team, The Replicants
  • Rank Xerox // A-Team, The Replicants
  • Illegal // The Replicants
  • Orion // The Replicants
  • Maxi // The Replicants
  • DOM // HOFA, The Replicants
  • Snake // HOFA, The Replicants
  • Fury // The Replicants
  • Ellfire // The Replicants
  • Yoda // The Marvelleous V8
  • Mr. Fly // Italian Cracking Service
  • Gaston // BMT
  • Ford Perfect // BMT
  • Angel Face // The Fallen Angels
  • Cameo // Fuzion
  • Skinhead // Vex, International Cracking Service
  • Troed // SICS, International Cracking Service
  • The Threat // International Cracking Service
  • Bandit // Climatics
  • SLiPPY // Vectronix 
  • AN Cool // TCB
  • Daryl // TEX
  • Axe // Delight, Superior
  • Jabba // Delight, Superior
  • Stranger // HMD, Rebels (Amiga, ST)  
  • Spy // Quartex (Amiga)
  • TFT // Skid Row (Amiga)
  • Fairlight (C64, Amiga) // Group interview
  • Triad (C64) // inquired

 

We would also like to let industry experts have their say. Opinions of the producers and some famous software houses of that time are captured:

 

  • Electronic Arts
  • FTL Games
  • Ocean Software
  • U.S. Gold
  • Gremlin Software
  • Hewson
  • Loriciel SA
  • Lankhor
  • Silmarils
  • Ubisoft
  • Infogrames
  • Rainbow Arts
  • Starbyte
  • Software 2000
  • Thalion
  • Eclipse Software
  • Martin Backschat (FastCopy Pro)
  • Rob Northern (Copylock)



Please understand that we need to protect the identities of most participants and therefore do not publish their real names here. It is only their permission that some of them are published in the book.

If we have missed you somehow, but you would like to see your opinion in the book, pls. get in touch with the author. E-mail: mbreddin[at]gmail.com 


Overview

 

In the following section we introduce the main topics. They will accompany the narrative. The book will be narrated in the tradition of The Atari ST and The Creative People and is driven by protagonists of the cracking scene.

 

When Cracking became popular ... 

A blazing C64 nostalgia tour written by David Almer.

The passionate editor of the Swedish magazines Axess and Aorta has published numerous articles in Datormagazin Retro. He also knows everything about Genesis Project: The largest cross-platform collaboration among the most productive C64 cracking groups was founded in the late 80s and is still active. As a true insider, Almer tells you the story that made cracking so popular.

The colourful flashback to formative groups and cracktros of Fairlight, Eagle Soft Incorp., Radwar, Dynamic Duo, Hotline, Mr. Z, Strike Force, Triad, Yeti, 1001, ABC, Ikari and others ...

 

“Danger of Software Piracy”

The times were chaotic and the law was not prepared for what was coming.

State authority and law operated side by side to attempt to eliminate the piracy networks. One example of such took place in Germany when a judge declared a personal war on the whole cracking scene. The likes of famous personalities such as Günter Freiherr von Gravenreuth turned up at “copy parties” and side by side he sat next to crackers on TV shows. Eventually documentary films began to appear questioning the sense of computer games altogether.

We undertake a dramatic flight through the contemporary press and media. The book will reheat the “danger of piracy”. 

 

The Dark Net of the 80s

Up to 100 people came together in the various subgroups of what they referrred to as The Blade Runners. Half as much in The Replicants. With various groups forming on the dark net of the 80s, the race for the fastest crack began.

In Germany, France and the United Kingdom in particular, conspiratorial information chains were working secretly from the public to rapidly acquire the hottest software.

How did such big underground networks come into being? Who were the suppliers? The dealers? Which roles made a cracking group functional? We keep an eye on the creation, development and organization of the greatest Atari ST-Cracking conspiracies.

 

Copy Parties

It was an exciting time.

Everyone wanted to get their hands on the new digital goods! But up to 80 DM (US$ 40, £ 27) per computer game was just too much for the most young people. As a result “copy parties,” in which people gathered to copy and distribute games, started to be held at secret locations and “warez” attracted every player in the late 80s. It was at these scenes that some of the most notorious people met and it was there that they drew the attention of law enforcement.

THE CRACKERS jumps into contemporary events and lets the reader experience what it was like at such meetings.

 

Spirit of Swapping

A notorious underground report by Stranger of Hemoroids/Rebels. 

The former French swapper and pack disk editor stood with both feet firmly planted in the ST and Amiga scene for many years. He took a key position. It was then that an individual called Stranger popped up everywhere and became a central figure of the early European file-sharing scene.

As part of numerous trading groups Stranger gives a deep insight into the business and communication of the 90s diskette dealers.

 

Snail Mails & Scribbles

Without the Internet, communication between the groups was often only possible by weeks of postal correspondence. Game lists and recommendations, code snippets and drawings. With the authors’ permissions we will publish some of the most interesting swapper letters for the first time in a book.

The digital counterpart was the scroll text. Here the letters were running across the screens, often revealing important scene contacts and praising the crack...

 

Intros, Cracktros, Compact Disks

Like magic.

On the Atari ST, various cracks were highly compressed and one floppy disk turned into a compact disk. As disk space remained, it was used for an introduction and a way to get in contact with other swappers and traders. This was vital as many groups tried to expand their networks or simply wanted to praise a particularly difficult crack. There were feuds and there was cooperation, but some of the coders preferred to build spectacular graphics and music demonstrations while discovering their enthusiasm for Demo Making.  

We show the finest cracktros and look back to the time when the demo scene suddenly became a child of the cracker scene.

 

The Way of a Cracker

The story of hacking and cracking is full of little side stories.

We’ve been talking to the insiders. Zippy of The Medway Boys was one of them. We follow him back to when he discovered the British floppy world in the 80s. Very few people at that time understood the mathematics of a crack like he did and fewer can tell you about the inner workings of the dark scene.

Come along for a journey down to the cracker’s ground.

 

BBS Times

Written by Troed, a former SysOp of the International Cracking Service. 

When night fell, “bulletin boards” became a mysterious meeting point for hackers. They developed into the first interactive network of the computer scene. But with modem speeds of less than 10,000 baud, downloading the latest software was a test of patience. FidoNet, Blue Boxing, Calling Cards – high phone bills had to be avoided and the darkest hours used to minimize costs.

In the U.S. Little Lulu’s was the transshipment point for European cracks. But how were the boards operated and who were the SysOps behind such strange aliases? ​

 

The Secret of Dungeon Master

Many have cracked it. But who has really mastered it?

One of the smartest protections was that of the game, Dungeon Master. For over a year the formative Dungeon Crawler resisted attacks from the underground and became the No. 1 bestseller on the Atari ST. It was a quick buy that remained unbeaten with a floppy disk encryption method imitated by many. Cracking this copy protection was one of the toughest challenges a hacker could face.

Finally, read the secret story behind the extraordinary copy protection of Dungeon Master.

 

Masters of Decryption

Crackers were forced to think outside the box.

They invested all their time to get around the multi-layered encryption technologies. These unknown computer freaks were surrounded by an almost mystical aura. However, their expertise was only passed on to like-minded people. They used homemade ROM cartridges and advanced decrypting methods no one else understood those days. Eventually, some of them were even hired by software companies to develop better encryptions.

Even though every second counted, code was mostly analyzed and modified by hand night after night and line after line. For those who were best at it, cracking developed into an art. 

 

Greatest Cryptography (Hall of Fame)

War Heli, Parasol Stars and Maupiti Island were some of the most sophisticated protections, including trace encryption, checksums, page zero code and self-modifying code. Interpreted high level language protections were extremely hard to understand for any cracker and made it nearly impossible to find a “key” in time. Games like Future Wars, Operation Stealth, Loom and Monkey Island were fortified by their publishers like castles under siege.

We ask the best hackers and compile their hardest decryption challenges in a hall of fame.

 

Trainers & Cheaters

Many fell in love with games, but not all of them had the patience to beat the challenges they presented. This motivated hackers who were up for a new trial. During a crack, the computer game had to be analyzed in such detail that even bugs in the code were ironed out. As an encore, they levered out game systematics, created infinite lives and weapons, and provided trainers and cheat features for the gamer.

It was the right food for starving teenagers who longed for every level of a game.

 

Replicants and Replicates 

Fast, free, executable.

When it came to general cracker attitude, The Replicants were on the front lines. The French Atari formation had one of the most sophisticated illegal networks of its time. It worked like a well-oiled machine. If a cracker wanted to be known, he had to be the first to the goal-post. The group quickly grew into an international organization with worldwide connections, boards and supplier channels.

Learn how The Replicants became world famous for “speed”. The whole crew in an interview.

 

Spy vs. Spy 

Who were the informants, who were the spies? How could they trust each other? Some cracks ended up in the teenagers’ floppy drives even before the game was released. How was that possible?

Take a trip to the forgotten diskette countries of the last century and learn about the loopholes of the early computer industry.

 

Producers against Piracy

16-bit developers knew their opponents very well (picture: Marc Rosocha/Eclipse).

They placed explicit messages on their disks, in a sector that only a cracker would enter. Many scene people rushed into the profession and with the advent of the games industry they opened their own studio when they suddenly had to face an almost impossible task: to sell their idea to an unknown market with renowned crackers. 

We want to give old feuds new space and let opinions collide. The producers and the scene: a love-hate relationship of unimagined dimensions.

 

Rob Northern’s Copylock

Rob Northern turned the disk into a vault.  

The industry standard disk protection on the Atari ST was ported to the Amiga. It was very clever, but was it clever enough? We not only analyse the way it works, but also ask the experts for the possibility of an unbreakable protection. What kind of thinking was necessary to develop a functional encryption? What kind for decryption? Was the ST designed in such a way that, if an encryption was used to its fullest, even a fanatic cracker would not have had any chance?

We search for the limits of thinking and ask the crackers for their finest hours.

 

The Underground Wars

The illegal race for intelligence, speed and distribution began.

Which crack lands first at the player and which features can be included? Will it work on the different computer models of the ST and Amiga series? There were two sides: those who wanted to do business and those who saw it as a free service to the digital people.

When the underground wars broke out, everything had to change and many groups were caught in their blazing flames.

 

The Art of Compact Disk

The cracking machine could no longer be stopped and the competition for attention grew tougher. The so-called Compact Disks needed a more eye-catching presentation – sometimes even a political statement. The production pressure was high and very small number of graphic artists had to deal with a lot of demanding pixel work in a short time. Two of them in particular stand out: Wizpop and Syd B. They almost did all the work for the likes of Automation, Medway Boys or Pompey Pirates.

Experience their best pixel artworks for the first time in a book.

 

Digital Copies

Not only were the games cracked, the groups did not stop at the seemingly invincible protection of a paper manual. The illegal upload of physical data – it started in the 90s. We talk to the only group on the ST that specialized in transferring physical manuals to floppy disk. Their Doc Disks were on everyone’s radar and appeared non-stop.

How did these geeks manage to digitize the partly 100-page game manuals on such a large scale using simple technical means?

 

Cracking Business

Besides the free distribution, which was part of the ethos of many crackers, there were also a number of underground dealers who made profit from the cracks. The mass sale of these games has enriched some unpopular personalities. They became first class diskette dealers and inflicted enourmous damage on the industry.

Track down the shady underground trading of the hottest floppy goods.

 

Cracking Tools

Ripping, debugging, packing, unpacking, DMA loading, automated cracking, copying, sector-to-file technologies: crackers had their own techniques to get to the encryption. Initially, in the underground scene, special software and hardware was developed that the market never saw, sometimes even with a soldering iron. The book will show examples of these proprietary solutions. But all this changed as The Medway Boys and Adrenaline released ripping tools that anyone could use. 

Suddenly the world of cracking became open to everyone.

 

ASCII Art

A cross scene feature by Senser (SNS), French Ascii artist. 

Developed mainly through restrictions on low data transmission in the bulletin boards more and more Ascii images evolved. Logos and graphics made with the character set only. Senser talks about the difference of the Atari and Amiga character sets, the restrictions and the signature character of the hardly considered graphic art. His works have been published widely and on numerous systems since 1994: ST, Amiga, Falcon, Windows and MS-DOS.

The book shows the most outstanding ASCII works with explanations in a special section.

 

The Great Interpol Raids

Mountains of 3.5 inch floppy disks were hidden deep in cellars.

Copy stations, copy parties and copy sessions spread “warez” first all over Europe, and then across the world. As these copies were spreading like a virus, the law struck. Wherever you turned, you could be betrayed. Paranoia took hold. The hunt for “software pirates” had begun and The Criminal Police Organisation searched for the private homes of well-known dealers in international operational raids.

Read about the consequences of illegal diskette trading in the age of home computers.

 

Has Piracy killed 16-bit Games?

ST/Amiga Format, ST Action, ACE, ST Magazine, Génération 4, Happy Computer, Power Play, ASM – above all, the game-concentrated magazines sought ways to address the scene and encouraged young buyers to maintain the games market and their jobs. 

What impact has piracy had on the programming market and computer sales? Undertake a press analysis with us – we ask the industry experts for facts and figures.

 

When Demo infected Cracktro ...

The development of 16-bit programming was mutually beneficial.

The demo scene was known for extremely efficient machine code, which also challenged the cracktro scene and vis-à-vis. Intros became demos and demos became full-blown menus with joystick control. THE CRACKERS delivers an interesting insight into the artistic aspects of screen programming.

We look at the iconic side of cracktros and search for decisive works with formative aesthetics and technology and ask what has developed and changed over time.

 

The Crackers Goodies

Now let us have a look at the goodies which you are going to get with the different backing options. The following pictures are made for illustration purposes and show the different packages which are tied to the perks. Let’s get into it.
 

Browse the borders.

First time you are able to experience Volume 1 as digital version. The whole layout for your PC or Tablet in half the printing resolution!

 

Open up every fluid treasure with this great mobile cracker!

Feel the power and decrypt the bottles of your choice. Get an aluminium cap lifter with metal key ring. Design will be chosen through survey after the campaign. 

 

Do you always like to have your hot tea or coffee right next to your computer?

This is the right coaster for you! And those cracking hours! Two coasters are coming with the set. Not yet designed.

 

The new 6-pack with postcard motifs of classic iconic Atari ST cracktros.

For the collector and the writer or just for a cracking thought: these cards are simply something special. Motifs will be carefully chosen.

 

What could that be? A trouser button?

It might be delicious and it could be something you like. But will it be useful? Just wait and let the Cracker’s delight surprise you!

 

Almost sold out! Yet it still comes with the speed of light!

Return to Eclipse Software

 



 

 

Three additional packs for you to choose from. Very limited amount. Original sealed games from the legendary 16-bit and Jaguar developer of the 90s. Atari STE/Amiga Dual Format. Functional floppy disks with high collector’s value. We can’t promise that all disks will work, but in our experience, they do!
 

Monster Business. Released in 1991.

Developed by Fabian Hammer (Oxygen/The Lost Boys) with graphics by Michael Grohe (Ex-Thalion). An advanced version of the famous arcade game Dig Dug with great sprites and smooth 50 Hz scrolling on the ST/E. Marvelous chip music by Synth Dream.

 

Lethal Xcess. Released in 1991.

Developed by members of X-Troll. Technically the best shooter ever made on the ST which also uses all of the STE power: bigger playfield, upper and lower borders removed, more sprites and cleaner sample sound. Up to 200 sprites on the STE at a resolution of 320x256 px.

Sync-scrolling routines on the ST and Jochen Hippel's energetic digi-drum music: shoot’em up lovers will be driven to madness.

 

Stone Age. Released in 1992.

Developed by Michael Rausch (Ford Perfect/BMT) with sound tracker music by Sven Bauer (Jora/BMT). Special Fan Box Edition with 3,5" PC version. One of the most compatible ST games supports Atari ST/STE/TT and is even running in monochrome mode! It also uses the STE sound capabilities and works on the Amiga.

You find lots of additional stickers in the box, e.g. different disk labels for C64, IBM PC and Atari ST/Amiga.

CRACKERS will be an exciting and exploratory experience in the spirit of the Borders Trilogy. In it, we will look at the illegal side of computer creativity and how cracking and hacking computer games evolved as a unique contemporary phenomenon in the 80s. ​ The Atari ST and The Creative PeopleVolume I, 1984 – 1990, BREAKIN’ THE BORDERS (sold out, PDF available) Volume II, 1991 – 1993, BEYOND THE BORDERS (on sale)Volume III, 1994 – 1997, RETURN OF THE BORDERS (on sale)Dark Addition, 1984 – 1991, CRACKERS  Episode I (this campaign) This additional book is the untold story of the best Atari ST crackers, their exceptional methods and deals, their way of life, desires, successes and setbacks. ​ Please note: The cover artwork will be designed at the end of the production. Only in this way can we find an essential representation. Book title and design shown are for illustration purposes only. Please be patient until delivery in 2021 ... ;)We promise:
High Quality book printing
English Hardback Edition

Quality goalsUS$ 20,000 ::::: 1st Goal // reached!Paperback EditionAdhesive binding US$ 22,000 :::: 2nd Goal // reached!Hardback EditionThread sewn bindingUS$ 24,000 ::::: 3rd Goal // reached!Hardback EditionThread sewn bindingBook title printed in high gloss​SummaryIn the beginning there was a troll ....  The digital people of the last century were completely on their own when they began to understand the inner workings of system. Networking became a great longing of the dawning computer age.Illegal activities on 16-bit computers began after two hackers left the Apple II to face new electronic fields. The idea of the digital troll only came to full bloom in the 2000s. This book tells the story of a group of hitherto unknown computer experts who sacrificed their youth to the gamers’ entertainment. They were called Crackers.Many excellent programmers whose only home for a long time was the boot sector, learned their craft by breaking a copy protection. It was no easy task. They worked hard at night and found their sources far away from the consumer. Eventually they found success as their raster bars, scroll texts, pixel art and chip music, spreaded through the disk slots of hundreds of thousands of young people who just wanted to play.Cracktros became popular. The times were a paradise for pirates, for the few lucky ones, as only the people with the most influential contacts were high up enough in the scene and to be able to play the trickiest game called “software piracy”. The 80s felt just right for that and everybody hoped for his secret little slice of illegal pie.  The cracker’s hour, it had to come ...Read about 42-Crew, The Medway Boys, Cynix, Hackers Of The Arena, B.O.S.S, Fallen Angels, The Marvellous V8, Black Monolith Team, Pompey Pirates, CSS, Fuzion, ICS, MCA, Hotline,Flame of Finland, D-Bug, Vectronix, TEX, Delight, Adrenaline U.K., Admirables, Bad Boys, BBS, Sewer Software, S.T.C.S. ... and many more. Learn about the structure, the changes, development and history of the greatest cracking associations on the Atari ST computers: Automation, The Blade Runners, Elite, Empire, Federation of Free Traders, The Replicants, The Corporation.Their experience stands for the 16-bit era of hacking and cracking in general. This book will summarize the dark side of disk life as a unique contemporary spiritual phenomenon. It is our goal to tell the truth behind the entanglements of the games industry in the 80s and 90s. The plot will reveal how it was possible to crack and spread diskette games so efficiently in Europe and worldwide.In a narrative journey through time, Microzeit will let the top crackers have their say and report from their teenage bedrooms. The Atari ST scene will be the heart of the story, but we also take the journey back to the 8-bit era on the C64 and deliver sidekicks to Apple II, Atari XL, Amstrad CPC and Sinclair Spectrum. Also Amiga insiders joined in.You will find yourself side by side with the famous swappers and experience what computer life was like at that time. What possibilities and machinations did one have to deal with and how did  they spin the strings to their shady sources. We tell the story from an underground perspective and let it collide with the media, the law and game producers.Interviews We ask the people. Please understand that we need to protect the identities of most participants and therefore do not publish their real names here. It is only their permission that some of them are published in the book.If we have missed you somehow, but you would like to see your opinion in the book, pls. get in touch with the author. E-mail: mbreddin[at]gmail.com Overview In the following section we introduce the main topics. They will accompany the narrative. The book will be narrated in the tradition of The Atari ST and The Creative People and is driven by protagonists of the cracking scene. When Cracking became popular ... A blazing C64 nostalgia tour written by David Almer. The passionate editor of the Swedish magazines Axess and Aorta has published numerous articles in Datormagazin Retro. He also knows everything about Genesis Project: The largest cross-platform collaboration among the most productive C64 cracking groups was founded in the late 80s and is still active. As a true insider, Almer tells you the story that made cracking so popular.The colourful flashback to formative groups and cracktros of Fairlight, Eagle Soft Incorp., Radwar, Dynamic Duo, Hotline, Mr. Z, Strike Force, Triad, Yeti, 1001, ABC, Ikari and others ... “Danger of Software Piracy”The times were chaotic and the law was not prepared for what was coming. State authority and law operated side by side to attempt to eliminate the piracy networks. One example of such took place in Germany when a judge declared a personal war on the whole cracking scene. The likes of famous personalities such as Günter Freiherr von Gravenreuth turned up at “copy parties” and side by side he sat next to crackers on TV shows. Eventually documentary films began to appear questioning the sense of computer games altogether.We undertake a dramatic flight through the contemporary press and media. The book will reheat the “danger of piracy”.  The Dark Net of the 80sUp to 100 people came together in the various subgroups of what they referrred to as The Blade Runners. Half as much in The Replicants. With various groups forming on the dark net of the 80s, the race for the fastest crack began.In Germany, France and the United Kingdom in particular, conspiratorial information chains were working secretly from the public to rapidly acquire the hottest software.How did such big underground networks come into being? Who were the suppliers? The dealers? Which roles made a cracking group functional? We keep an eye on the creation, development and organization of the greatest Atari ST-Cracking conspiracies. Copy PartiesIt was an exciting time. Everyone wanted to get their hands on the new digital goods! But up to 80 DM (US$ 40, £ 27) per computer game was just too much for the most young people. As a result “copy parties,” in which people gathered to copy and distribute games, started to be held at secret locations and “warez” attracted every player in the late 80s. It was at these scenes that some of the most notorious people met and it was there that they drew the attention of law enforcement.THE CRACKERS jumps into contemporary events and lets the reader experience what it was like at such meetings. Spirit of SwappingA notorious underground report by Stranger of Hemoroids/Rebels. The former French swapper and pack disk editor stood with both feet firmly planted in the ST and Amiga scene for many years. He took a key position. It was then that an individual called Stranger popped up everywhere and became a central figure of the early European file-sharing scene.As part of numerous trading groups Stranger gives a deep insight into the business and communication of the 90s diskette dealers. Snail Mails & ScribblesWithout the Internet, communication between the groups was often only possible by weeks of postal correspondence. Game lists and recommendations, code snippets and drawings. With the authors’ permissions we will publish some of the most interesting swapper letters for the first time in a book.The digital counterpart was the scroll text. Here the letters were running across the screens, often revealing important scene contacts and praising the crack... Intros, Cracktros, Compact DisksLike magic. On the Atari ST, various cracks were highly compressed and one floppy disk turned into a compact disk. As disk space remained, it was used for an introduction and a way to get in contact with other swappers and traders. This was vital as many groups tried to expand their networks or simply wanted to praise a particularly difficult crack. There were feuds and there was cooperation, but some of the coders preferred to build spectacular graphics and music demonstrations while discovering their enthusiasm for Demo Making.  We show the finest cracktros and look back to the time when the demo scene suddenly became a child of the cracker scene. The Way of a CrackerThe story of hacking and cracking is full of little side stories. We’ve been talking to the insiders. Zippy of The Medway Boys was one of them. We follow him back to when he discovered the British floppy world in the 80s. Very few people at that time understood the mathematics of a crack like he did and fewer can tell you about the inner workings of the dark scene.Come along for a journey down to the cracker’s ground. BBS TimesWritten by Troed, a former SysOp of the International Cracking Service. When night fell, “bulletin boards” became a mysterious meeting point for hackers. They developed into the first interactive network of the computer scene. But with modem speeds of less than 10,000 baud, downloading the latest software was a test of patience. FidoNet, Blue Boxing, Calling Cards – high phone bills had to be avoided and the darkest hours used to minimize costs.In the U.S. Little Lulu’s was the transshipment point for European cracks. But how were the boards operated and who were the SysOps behind such strange aliases? ​ The Secret of Dungeon MasterMany have cracked it. But who has really mastered it? One of the smartest protections was that of the game, Dungeon Master. For over a year the formative Dungeon Crawler resisted attacks from the underground and became the No. 1 bestseller on the Atari ST. It was a quick buy that remained unbeaten with a floppy disk encryption method imitated by many. Cracking this copy protection was one of the toughest challenges a hacker could face.Finally, read the secret story behind the extraordinary copy protection of Dungeon Master. Masters of DecryptionCrackers were forced to think outside the box. They invested all their time to get around the multi-layered encryption technologies. These unknown computer freaks were surrounded by an almost mystical aura. However, their expertise was only passed on to like-minded people. They used homemade ROM cartridges and advanced decrypting methods no one else understood those days. Eventually, some of them were even hired by software companies to develop better encryptions.Even though every second counted, code was mostly analyzed and modified by hand night after night and line after line. For those who were best at it, cracking developed into an art.  Greatest Cryptography (Hall of Fame)War Heli, Parasol Stars and Maupiti Island were some of the most sophisticated protections, including trace encryption, checksums, page zero code and self-modifying code. Interpreted high level language protections were extremely hard to understand for any cracker and made it nearly impossible to find a “key” in time. Games like Future Wars, Operation Stealth, Loom and Monkey Island were fortified by their publishers like castles under siege.We ask the best hackers and compile their hardest decryption challenges in a hall of fame. Trainers & CheatersMany fell in love with games, but not all of them had the patience to beat the challenges they presented. This motivated hackers who were up for a new trial. During a crack, the computer game had to be analyzed in such detail that even bugs in the code were ironed out. As an encore, they levered out game systematics, created infinite lives and weapons, and provided trainers and cheat features for the gamer.It was the right food for starving teenagers who longed for every level of a game. Replicants and Replicates Fast, free, executable. When it came to general cracker attitude, The Replicants were on the front lines. The French Atari formation had one of the most sophisticated illegal networks of its time. It worked like a well-oiled machine. If a cracker wanted to be known, he had to be the first to the goal-post. The group quickly grew into an international organization with worldwide connections, boards and supplier channels.Learn how The Replicants became world famous for “speed”. The whole crew in an interview. Spy vs. Spy Who were the informants, who were the spies? How could they trust each other? Some cracks ended up in the teenagers’ floppy drives even before the game was released. How was that possible?Take a trip to the forgotten diskette countries of the last century and learn about the loopholes of the early computer industry. Producers against Piracy16-bit developers knew their opponents very well (picture: Marc Rosocha/Eclipse). They placed explicit messages on their disks, in a sector that only a cracker would enter. Many scene people rushed into the profession and with the advent of the games industry they opened their own studio when they suddenly had to face an almost impossible task: to sell their idea to an unknown market with renowned crackers. We want to give old feuds new space and let opinions collide. The producers and the scene: a love-hate relationship of unimagined dimensions. Rob Northern’s CopylockRob Northern turned the disk into a vault.  The industry standard disk protection on the Atari ST was ported to the Amiga. It was very clever, but was it clever enough? We not only analyse the way it works, but also ask the experts for the possibility of an unbreakable protection. What kind of thinking was necessary to develop a functional encryption? What kind for decryption? Was the ST designed in such a way that, if an encryption was used to its fullest, even a fanatic cracker would not have had any chance?We search for the limits of thinking and ask the crackers for their finest hours. The Underground WarsThe illegal race for intelligence, speed and distribution began. Which crack lands first at the player and which features can be included? Will it work on the different computer models of the ST and Amiga series? There were two sides: those who wanted to do business and those who saw it as a free service to the digital people.When the underground wars broke out, everything had to change and many groups were caught in their blazing flames. The Art of Compact DiskThe cracking machine could no longer be stopped and the competition for attention grew tougher. The so-called Compact Disks needed a more eye-catching presentation – sometimes even a political statement. The production pressure was high and very small number of graphic artists had to deal with a lot of demanding pixel work in a short time. Two of them in particular stand out: Wizpop and Syd B. They almost did all the work for the likes of Automation, Medway Boys or Pompey Pirates.Experience their best pixel artworks for the first time in a book. Digital CopiesNot only were the games cracked, the groups did not stop at the seemingly invincible protection of a paper manual. The illegal upload of physical data – it started in the 90s. We talk to the only group on the ST that specialized in transferring physical manuals to floppy disk. Their Doc Disks were on everyone’s radar and appeared non-stop.How did these geeks manage to digitize the partly 100-page game manuals on such a large scale using simple technical means? Cracking BusinessBesides the free distribution, which was part of the ethos of many crackers, there were also a number of underground dealers who made profit from the cracks. The mass sale of these games has enriched some unpopular personalities. They became first class diskette dealers and inflicted enourmous damage on the industry.Track down the shady underground trading of the hottest floppy goods. Cracking ToolsRipping, debugging, packing, unpacking, DMA loading, automated cracking, copying, sector-to-file technologies: crackers had their own techniques to get to the encryption. Initially, in the underground scene, special software and hardware was developed that the market never saw, sometimes even with a soldering iron. The book will show examples of these proprietary solutions. But all this changed as The Medway Boys and Adrenaline released ripping tools that anyone could use. Suddenly the world of cracking became open to everyone. ASCII ArtA cross scene feature by Senser (SNS), French Ascii artist. Developed mainly through restrictions on low data transmission in the bulletin boards more and more Ascii images evolved. Logos and graphics made with the character set only. Senser talks about the difference of the Atari and Amiga character sets, the restrictions and the signature character of the hardly considered graphic art. His works have been published widely and on numerous systems since 1994: ST, Amiga, Falcon, Windows and MS-DOS.The book shows the most outstanding ASCII works with explanations in a special section. The Great Interpol RaidsMountains of 3.5 inch floppy disks were hidden deep in cellars. Copy stations, copy parties and copy sessions spread “warez” first all over Europe, and then across the world. As these copies were spreading like a virus, the law struck. Wherever you turned, you could be betrayed. Paranoia took hold. The hunt for “software pirates” had begun and The Criminal Police Organisation searched for the private homes of well-known dealers in international operational raids.Read about the consequences of illegal diskette trading in the age of home computers. Has Piracy killed 16-bit Games?ST/Amiga Format, ST Action, ACE, ST Magazine, Génération 4, Happy Computer, Power Play, ASM – above all, the game-concentrated magazines sought ways to address the scene and encouraged young buyers to maintain the games market and their jobs. What impact has piracy had on the programming market and computer sales? Undertake a press analysis with us – we ask the industry experts for facts and figures. When Demo infected Cracktro ...The development of 16-bit programming was mutually beneficial. The demo scene was known for extremely efficient machine code, which also challenged the cracktro scene and vis-à-vis. Intros became demos and demos became full-blown menus with joystick control. THE CRACKERS delivers an interesting insight into the artistic aspects of screen programming.We look at the iconic side of cracktros and search for decisive works with formative aesthetics and technology and ask what has developed and changed over time. The Crackers GoodiesNow let us have a look at the goodies which you are going to get with the different backing options. The following pictures are made for illustration purposes and show the different packages which are tied to the perks. Let’s get into it. Browse the borders. Feel the power and decrypt the bottles of your choice. Get an aluminium cap lifter with metal key ring. Design will be chosen through survey after the campaign.  Do you always like to have your hot tea or coffee right next to your computer? This is the right coaster for you! And those cracking hours! Two coasters are coming with the set. Not yet designed. The new 6-pack with postcard motifs of classic iconic Atari ST cracktros. For the collector and the writer or just for a cracking thought: these cards are simply something special. Motifs will be carefully chosen. What could that be? A trouser button? story:
ACA your word Minority Scholarship

Every year, teens gather in a stunningly natural environment to be mentored by master writers for two weeks of creative exploration. It's a magical experience, one I cherished when I taught at the your word retreat in 2013. These kids grow artistically, before your eyes and on the page. It's an opportunity of a lifetime for teens to explore the literary arts and their own creative possibilities. It's one I wish I'd had at that age, one I felt honored to contribute to as an established writer. Unfortunately, at a tuition of $1695, it's an opportunity that's out of reach for some deserving future writers. Your contribution could help an aspiring writer of color participate in a life changing creative moment.

ACA’s your word Teen Creative Writing Residency is a multi-genre summer writing residency that offers 9th through rising 12th grade writers workshops and mentorship by distinguished authors in poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction/memoir, on the grounds of a breathtakingly beautiful ecological preserve in New Smyrna Beach, Florida. At the end, following their final reading, the students disperse back across the country with a new found confidence and purpose.

This year, your word Teen Creative Writing Residency will be held from July 20 through Aug 2, 2014, offering 21 participants the opportunity to explore and expand the power of their individual voices through writing workshops and classes. This year I, along with my wife Meera Bowman-Johnson, and poets John Murillo and Nicole Sealey, are hoping to make this amazing experience available to a Black or Latino student who would otherwise be unable to afford the opportunity. With your donation, we could offer an experience that could open up a world and enrich a young life.

At the end, following their final reading, the students disperse back across the country with a new found confidence and purpose.This year, your word Teen Creative Writing Residency will be held from July 20 through Aug 2, 2014, offering 21 participants the opportunity to explore and expand the power of their individual voices through writing workshops and classes. This year I, along with my wife Meera Bowman-Johnson, and poets John Murillo and Nicole Sealey, are hoping to make this amazing experience available to a Black or Latino student who would otherwise be unable to afford the opportunity. With your donation, we could offer an experience that could open up a world and enrich a young life.

story:
SMALL WONDER MAGAZINE

Small Wonder is a quarterly magazine for kids and their grown-ups.

website - instagram - twitter - facebook

Small Wonder encourages wondering. Be curious, ask questions.
Small Wonder wishes to instill a sense of wonder. Be amazed, be inspired.

The idea for Small Wonder stemmed from the challenge I had as a parent (and as a magazine junkie) in finding a magazine that both my son and I could enjoy. I was searching for something that wasn't driven by cartoon characters or pop stars, but by original, creative and inspiring artwork, content and activities. Since I couldn't readily find it, I thought to myself, "I'll make it!"

With over 10 years experience as the co-founder, designer and editor of a successful publication (We Are Local) and a degree in the contemporary arts, it wasn't out of the realm of possibility that I could actually do this. So off I set to brainstorm ideas and to gather talented contributors to help provide fun content for readers big and small.

Published four times a year, each issue of Small Wonder will include recipes, arts and craft activities, travel features, recommendations for books, apps and products, original stories and much more. Printed in Canada on premium quality matte paper, the aesthetic will be fresh and modern while at the same time exposing readers to a variety of artistic styles — the first issue will include beautiful story illustrations by Ola Volo and playful activities by Russell Alton and Lisa Cinar.

I am excited to get this venture off the ground and into the hands of readers. Researching ideas and products and working with independent artists to create engrossing content for kids and their grown-ups has been very fulfilling and I believe has resulted in a product that will be enriching for those who engage with it.

WHY THE CAMPAIGN?

As we all know, with any new project there are costs involved in getting it up and running. The majority of the expenses, such as fees for contributing artists, business licenses, website domains, supplies and incidentals were covered out of pocket. The biggest cost, however, is the printing and it is for this that I am asking help. Small Wonder will be printed in Winnipeg, Canada. For the first issue, I am printing 1000 copies which will cost just over $5000.00 including the freight costs.

PERKS

The perks for donating to Small Wonder are divided into three categories:

1. FOR THE READERS: 
One Fun! • Two Woohoo! • Three Yippee! • Four You Score!
Receive copies of Small Wonder Issue 1, Issues 1-2, Issues 1-3 or Issues 1-4 at a discounted rate! Plus a personal thank you in Small Wonder Issue 1.

Bonus Perk: Limited offer of Small Wonder Issue 1 plus a Fun Flags Colouring Book donated to this campaign by contributing artist Lisa Cinar of Draw Me A Lion. Plus a personal thank you in Small Wonder Issue 1.


2. FOR BRANDS AND ORGANIZATIONS: These perks are a perfect opportunity for businesses looking to align their brand with Small Wonder right from the get go!

Sponsor Logo Listing: Your logo and web address will be included in the sponsor appreciation page in Small Wonder Issue 1.

Sponsor Full Page Ads: A one page (7.5"x10") ad at a one time discounted rate for your business, organization, or project in Small Wonder Issue 1, plus a personal thank you in Small Wonder Issue 1 and five copies of the issue. Ad spaces are available within the magazine pages, the inside cover, the inside back cover and the most coveted back cover.

3. FOR SHOPS: Be a Small Wonder stockist!
Reseller Perk: Ten copies of Small Wonder Issue 1 at a special reduced rate for resale at your lovely shop. Plus a personal thank you in Small Wonder Issue 1.

THANKS!

Thanks to my friends and family who have been supportive during the beginning stages of Small Wonder. A special thanks to Gordon Wong for putting together such a great video for this campaign.

Thanks too to those shops who have already committed to carrying Small Wonder. Thanks for your advice and encouragement! Visit these shops to find the magazine, as well as other beautifully curated goods: much&little • One of a Few • Walrus

And a big thanks to YOU for taking the time to check out the Small Wonder campaign. It would be wonderful and very much appreciated if you shared it with your friends.

Daniela Lee
hello@smallwondermag.com
