story:
A portion of this campaign will be donated to the March of Dimes which supports the fight against birth defects. Please help all those who are trapped in a body or mind that will not listen to their wishes. Remember that prosperity is not just for a few chosen few.  Joy and  a meaningful  life is for everyone.  We can make that happen if we share love, compassion, and support with those who who suffer through no fault of their own.  Together we can spread joy and success around the world. People need to be recognized for their unique talents before we make assumptions  based on a disability they did not choose to be burdened with.

                Thank you for joining  the campaign to create understanding and disability awareness

WHO IS MYRA GOLDICK

Hello, my name is Myra Goldick. I am physically challenged.  We live in a world full of glorious beauty. Yet, many of us are on a perpetual quest for perfection. Unfortunately, perfection ... in its raw form ... is unattainable. As human beings we are constantly searching for perfection within ourselves,both inwardly and outwardly. Sadly, occasionally we mistakenly judge others prematurely. Those among us who are challenged with either visible or invisible disabilities are frequently labeled and prejudged by the stigma of the word disabled, and viewed as less than perfect. Are you aware that the disabled community is one of fastest growing minorities on the planet today? Shockingly it is a community that anyone can become a part of at any moment. That statistic is a sobering reality to many of us and a reality that creates great discomfort and fear in our hearts.

 THE PURPOSE

We have come a long way since I became paralyzed by polio in 1953. However, we still have a long way to go until we see the person first, with his or her own unique talents and abilities that can be of great value to society, before we see the disability and make assumptions. I have traveled this road since the age of ten and struggled with the label disabled and even categorized as crippled. I have learned a lot along my journey of tears and perseverance. I am grateful for the generosity and help I received along my path to recovery. The March of Dimes paid for my rehabilitation when I was a little girl. With their help I learned to dance on my disabilities. Currently, the March Of Dimes supports the research for the eradication of birth defects. It is for that reason I am donating 5% of any funds raised with this campaign directly to them to aid their cause.Why should any child suffer, if we can possibly prevent it? I have discovered that anything is possible until we say it's not, and learning to Dance on Your Disabilities is the key to a life full of happiness and joy. I could never have achieved the success in my life I have experienced without the love and support of my caregivers.   First my mother and then my husband of 50 years. They are the unsung heroes that never  get recognition for their unyielding loyalty. My mission is to make a positive difference in the world and in the lives of one of the fastest growing minorities in the world, the disabled. I want to celebrate their caregivers, loving families, and their workplace associates who accommodate their needs in the spirit of love and support. Visible or invisible disabilities do not define the worth of an individual or their value to society. Education is the key.

THE GOAL

It is for this reason that I am writing the book "Dancing on Your Disabilities, Never Say Impossible to Your Dreams". Within the pages of my book I tell my story in an effort to inspire by example, to spread happiness throughout the world, and to motivate others to "Never Say Impossible to Their Dreams".  I want to see others  tap into their unique creativity to design their future based on desire and not self - imposed limitations or society’s prejudgment of their abilities. It is my way to of giving thanks for all the blessings I have received during my journey as I spread the message of faith and belief with those who are only beginning my journey. I am asking for your support and help to make this book become a reality. Chances are you already know or love someone with a challenge. Perhaps it's you who is suffering and feels like giving up. Giving up is not an option. If you find it in your heart please help me put this book in the hands of all those who are in a dark lonely place, whether they are the caregiver or the challenged. Together we can make a difference in the world. We are not alone. A Special Thank you to all the corporations and businesses that have offered opportunities and will continue to offer career options  for the challenged to contribute to society and become independent.

I AM ETERNALLY GRATEFUL TO THE MARCH OF DIMES

 I will donate an additional 10% for the first six months of all book sales of " Dancing On Your Disabilities/Never Say Impossible to Your Dreams to the March of Dimes.

Acknowledgement of my donation from the March of Dimes will be posted on my offical website at the end of the campaign at  http://myragoldick.com

story:
A quick introduction of the author Hi everybody, I'm Jim Killon. I am an American from Baltimore, Maryland. In 2009, I came
to Peru and started a project called Changes for New Hope. It was designed to help the children living
here in extreme poverty. We address issues such as malnutrition and hunger, education, self esteem
and other emotional issues, family crisis, general well being and creativity development projects. Our
growth is happening faster than our funding so... I decided to write this childrens story book.

    I am an avid writer. I have a blog at jimkillon@blogspot.com which you may enjoy reading. I have also written several articles and commentaries for e-publications such as Itsonehumanity.org, Youthemovement.org, Expatperu.com, Livinginperu.com, Omprakash.org, the Baltimore Sun, as well as on our own webpage at www.changesfornewhope.org.

 

   This childrens storybook will contain five stories that have moral imperatives to teach your children. Sharing, integrity, honesty and compassion to name a few. Due to be available in mid-2012 in e-form and print copy version, I feel that these stories that inspire the children of Changes for New Hope will also have a significant meaning to your children as well.

The Impact:  From on the ground in Peru

   Unless you live in the Peruvian Andes among the children and their families it is hard to imagine the severity of their poverty. Picture waking up in the morning in an adobe house, without heat. Perhaps there is no running water or electricity. Corrugated aluminum roofs held down with old tires and no bathroom. Many children are pulled out of school at early ages to help the family tend the land. Teenage pregnancies are common, swirling the poverty cycle into the next generation. The indigenous people have few opportunities to advance themselves.

   The victims are the children who can not do anything to help themselves. At Changes for New Hope, we see the impact we are making but so much more needs to happen before we can claim victory.

Here's what we need and this is what you will receive for helping   

   It is my sincere hope that this writing project raises far more than $8000. I have goals and plans that will require many times that amount. However, let's use this number as a starting point.

 

    So, how is the money being used? Why should I help children way down there in Peru? What do I get in return?

  

   All good questions.

   * To begin with, I will get the book published, printed, illustrated and marketed which will use some of the funds.

   * Next, we want to put food in the bellies of every child. Until hunger and malnutrition is arrested, nothing much else is going to be useful. We need childrens vitamins to suppliment the scant diets of these children.

  *  Protein rich foods and a daily balanced diet are urgent issues we are addressing.

  *  If you have ever worn a pair of ill fitting shoes you know how your body feels at the end of a day.

Imagine wearing ragged worn out laceless shoes everyday. Shoes last about one rainy season here in Peru. Families can not afford new shoes so the children wear shoes that are literally falling off their feet.

   * Educational materials and school supplies are desperately needed. Notebooks, pens, pencils, paper, colored pencils, erasers, sharpeners and rulers do not come easily to the children. School uniforms are required to attend school. Some children do not get an education because their families can not afford the uniforms. Education is the easiest, cheapest and most effective avenue out of poverty. 

   * Part of your contribution will also help to support our dedicated volunteers who are diligently working toward bringing about these changes.

   * Health issues among the children are rampant. They suffer from parasites, worm infestations, vision problems, lacking dental and pediatric care and emotional/psychological issues. Health care is a human right but doesn't always extend this far up into the Peruvian Andes, sadly enough.

 

   What do you get for your contribution?

   Of course the great perks that you see on the right column of this campaign, but there is a more intrinsic reward. You will feel the personal satisfaction and warm feeling that somewhere in the high mountains of Peru, there are children who will have a hope, a ray of sunshine knowing that their tomorrow will be so much better than their todays. That is a major reason I am committed to staying right here and see this project through. There is no finish line for me.

 

   Am I putting my money where my mouth is?

   Absolutely! Changes for New Hope was a new, unheard of project at its inception in 2009. No one was going to support a project they never heard of, in a place no one has ever seen, by a guy who was completely unknown. The initial start-up, all expenses, every pen, pencil and notebook was purchased with my life savings. Now it is time to ask for help.

   Let's get this book out and give these children a chance in life!

 

 
 
                                                ****  An Excerpt From A Story In The Book  ****
 
                                                                   The Winged Crawlers
 

    “If only I had a pair of beautiful wings like all the other Nadas, I could learn to fly. I could fly to other mountaintops, higher mountaintops and see new things I never saw before. I could fly so high that I would be able to see the glaciers from above the mountains.” That idea excited Frio very much. “Why do my friends not use their beautiful wings and fly?” He wondered, “Why do they not use their beautiful wings to discover new things so far away and so high? Why do they not visit far away places that they would no long have to crawl to go to?” He was very confused, “They have beautiful wings, why do they not use them?” Frio was very curious, very curious indeed.

   One day Frio was huddled in a group of his friends and they were happy , all licking their favorite treat, frozen glacier icicles. Frio asked a very important question, which he had thought about all night long. “Nadas, my friends, I have seen each of you with very beautiful wings on your backs, with many colors and they are large enough that if you fluttered them, like when you get excited, and maybe jumped at the same time, you might just be able to fly!” The other Nadas looked at Frio in disbelief, but Frio continued, “Imagine the possibilities, imagine what you could see if you could fly high up in the air. You would no longer have to drag yourselves from place to place when you walked.” It made perfect sense to Frio and he only wished he also had wings to fly himself to show them. He closed his eyes and imagined flying over the glaciers and mountains. He imagined himself looking down into valleys with his big blue eyes and seeing so many new things that no one had ever seen before. 

                                              **********************************************
 
   The following is a recent article about Jim Killon and Changes for New Hope. It was published in Volunteer Match (volunteermatch.org) by their writer Laura Weiss.   
 
      
Jim Killon with the children of 'Changes for New Hope'

Jim Killon, Changes for New Hope

   In 2009, Jim Killon moved to Peru, where he started a nonprofit organization to help impoverished children in the Peruvian Andes. With no funding and no Spanish, everyone told him to give up and go home. Three years later, Changes for New Hope has reached hundreds of children and helped change their despair into real hope.

About Jim

By Laura Weiss

 

   After twenty years of working in sales, Baltimore native Jim Killon was so moved by the poverty in South America that he spent his life savings to start an organization to improve the livelihood of Peruvian children and permanently relocated to Huaraz, Peru.

 

   When he first arrived in Peru in 2009, Jim was not intending to start his own organization. But when he began working as a volunteer coordinator at an NGO, he was immediately disappointed with the way the organization was run. Disillusioned with the corrupt way funds were allocated and the volunteers who seemed more interested in partying than helping, Jim decided that he needed to do more.

 

  "I was not content to help a handful of children with their homework and send them on their way…These children wore rags; shoes were literally falling off their feet. They were suffering from malnutrition. Their hair felt like straw," Jim recalls.

 

   So in 2009 he began Changes for New Hope, a nonprofit organization focused on providing Peruvian youth opportunities and hope for a better future. "We had to start from scratch," he says. "Respect for themselves and each other became part of the program. Those who arrived simply for the hand-outs left as soon as they realized this was more than a give-away program. We were left with children who wanted to develop themselves into young men and women one day."

  

   As a start-up nonprofit in a foreign country, Jim faced challenges that to most people would seem insurmountable. "I had no idea how to read a menu or make a phone call," he says. "The culture and customs were all alien to me. When people told me they eat guinea pigs as food I thought they were kidding. When I found a chicken foot in my soup I was sure it was a prank... I was told I could never succeed."

  

   For Jim, the solution to the challenges he faced was passion. "My tenacity drew others to the project and we developed a solid base," he says. "Spanish can be learned, obstacles can be overcome. Naysayers go silent in the face of determination and success."

Jim spoke at language centers and universities in Peru to encourage more people to donate and volunteer for the cause. Local poster campaigns and testimonials from previous volunteers helped the project gain credibility and fodder.

  

  Jim's passion is obvious to everyone around him. According to Marlie Ferron, a former volunteer with Changes for New Hope, local Huaraz residents refer to him as "Crazy Jim."

"Not crazy as in psychopath or lunatic, or out of his mind, but crazy as in one in a million who dropped his life in the United States to come to Peru and just do his best with what he could, no questions asked," Marlie writes on the CNH blog.

  

  Whereas three years ago, Jim's life was about the big-city grind, he now spends his days teaching children about the nature that surrounds them and facilitating games of "Gringo Bingo," an English vocabulary game. He does art projects with the children, some of whom have never been able to draw with crayons and paper before.

At its inception, Changes for New Hope only reached one group of children, but now Jim works with three groups – about 90 children total. And that number is constantly growing. The program continually adapts to the different teaching styles and hobbies of its volunteers. Jim notes, "Each volunteer has some skill or ability that the children have yet to experience or try. The children are eager learners now and embrace new faces."

With the invaluable assistance of volunteers from the US, the UK, Australia and more, Changes for New Hope is able to add new ideas, projects, learning games and choices as materials and donations allow.

  

  Jim hopes that in future years, Changes for New Hope will be able to engage Peruvian families to create sustainable business models to raise themselves out of poverty. He hopes that future generations will be able to give their children more than they had as a result of Changes for New Hope. "Mostly, I am happy to see that, while poverty continues, the desperation mentality is slowly melting away… When people realize opportunities are available, hope replaces despair," he says.

  

  It is clear that Jim's life has changed as a result of moving to Peru. He lost 60 pounds after living on a Peruvian diet. He's forgotten what "turning on the heat" means. He hasn't driven a car in almost three years. But Jim wouldn't call these changes sacrifices.

  

  "I think that had I ever viewed it as a sacrifice, I may have been tempted to throw in the towel and head for a beach in Hawaii," he says. "The reward for me was seeing the results and development of the children and their families."

  

Jim's multifaceted efforts have transformed his life, but he describes it as a "win-win endeavor" that has opened his heart to the beauty and reward that comes from helping others.

  

 "No one is telling me to go home anymore," he notes. "This is home for me now."

 

   Laura Weiss interned with VolunteerMatch during the summer of 2011.

About Changes for New Hope

   Changes for New Hope reaches poor and underprivileged children and their families in the Peruvian Andes. Initially developed as an English language program, CNH has expanded to address hunger and health issues in Huaraz, Peru.

James Killon, Changes for New Hope
c/o Serpost
Ancash, Huaraz, Peru
www.changesfornewhope.org

Check out Changes for New Hope opportunities at VolunteerMatch. 

    

Other Ways You Can Help

   There are many ways to further the project at Changes for New Hope and the publication and production of this book. Share us on Facebook, and other social media outlets, with your friends and suggest they share it as well. You can become a "Virtual Volunteer" right from your own home by supporting, sponsoring a child, fundraising, sending down materials and supplies, and spreading the word. 

  

   You can also come to visit us here in Huaraz Peru as an "On-The-Ground-Volunteer" and experience our day to day life, working in the villages we go to, meet the families and children and make a hands-on difference with us. Those who have volunteered with us have dispelled their pre-conceived ideas, renewed their faith in human kind, and come away with a deep feeling of accomplishment. One wonderful family actually blew off a cruise to Barbados to come volunteer with us. They left with no regrets and with great memories of their experience.  

  

   Please be sure to take a look at our web page at www.changesfornewhope.org. I would like for you to have  complete confidence in contributing to our campaign. There you will see some of our recent accomplishments.

 

   You can also find us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/changesfornewhope.

  Thanks for reading my campaign. I hope you will contribute and become part of the team.

   Siempre~~~ Jim Killon

We address issues such as malnutrition and hunger, education, self esteemand other emotional issues, family crisis, general well being and creativity development projects. Our growth is happening faster than our funding so... I decided to write this childrens story book.
    I am an avid writer. I have a blog at jimkillon@blogspot.com which you may enjoy reading. I have also written several articles and commentaries for e-publications such as Itsonehumanity.org, Youthemovement.org, Expatperu.com, Livinginperu.com, Omprakash.org, the Baltimore Sun, as well as on our own webpage at www.changesfornewhope.org. 
  
   This childrens storybook will contain five stories that have moral imperatives to teach your children. Sharing, integrity, honesty and compassion to name a few. Due to be available in mid-2012 in e-form and print copy version, I feel that these stories that inspire the children of Changes for New Hope will also have a significant meaning to your children as well. 

The Impact:  From on the ground in Peru
   Unless you live in the Peruvian Andes among the children and their families it is hard to imagine the severity of their poverty. Picture waking up in the morning in an adobe house, without heat. Perhaps there is no running water or electricity. Corrugated aluminum roofs held down with old tires and no bathroom. Many children are pulled out of school at early ages to help the family tend the land. Teenage pregnancies are common, swirling the poverty cycle into the next generation. The indigenous people have few opportunities to advance themselves. 
   The victims are the children who can not do anything to help themselves. At Changes for New Hope, we see the impact we are making but so much more needs to happen before we can claim victory. 


Here's what we need and this is what you will receive for helping   

   It is my sincere hope that this writing project raises far more than $8000. I have goals and plans that will require many times that amount. However, let's use this number as a starting point.
 
    So, how is the money being used? Why should I help children way down there in Peru? What do I get in return?
   
   All good questions. 
   * To begin with, I will get the book published, printed, illustrated and marketed which will use some of the funds. 
   * Next, we want to put food in the bellies of every child. Until hunger and malnutrition is arrested, nothing much else is going to be useful. We need childrens vitamins to suppliment the scant diets of these children.
  *  Protein rich foods and a daily balanced diet are urgent issues we are addressing.
  *  If you have ever worn a pair of ill fitting shoes you know how your body feels at the end of a day. 
Imagine wearing ragged worn out laceless shoes everyday. Shoes last about one rainy season here in Peru. Families can not afford new shoes so the children wear shoes that are literally falling off their feet.
   * Educational materials and school supplies are desperately needed. Notebooks, pens, pencils, paper, colored pencils, erasers, sharpeners and rulers do not come easily to the children. School uniforms are required to attend school. Some children do not get an education because their families can not afford the uniforms. Education is the easiest, cheapest and most effective avenue out of poverty. 
   * Part of your contribution will also help to support our dedicated volunteers who are diligently working toward bringing about these changes.
   * Health issues among the children are rampant. They suffer from parasites, worm infestations, vision problems, lacking dental and pediatric care and emotional/psychological issues. Health care is a human right but doesn't always extend this far up into the Peruvian Andes, sadly enough.
 
   What do you get for your contribution? 
   Of course the great perks that you see on the right column of this campaign, but there is a more intrinsic reward. You will feel the personal satisfaction and warm feeling that somewhere in the high mountains of Peru, there are children who will have a hope, a ray of sunshine knowing that their tomorrow will be so much better than their todays. That is a major reason I am committed to staying right here and see this project through. There is no finish line for me.
 
   Am I putting my money where my mouth is? 
   Absolutely! Changes for New Hope was a new, unheard of project at its inception in 2009. No one was going to support a project they never heard of, in a place no one has ever seen, by a guy who was completely unknown. The initial start-up, all expenses, every pen, pencil and notebook was purchased with my life savings. Now it is time to ask for help. 
   Let's get this book out and give these children a chance in life! 
 
 
 
                                                ****  An Excerpt From A Story In The Book  ****

 
                                                                   The Winged Crawlers
 

    “If only I had a pair of beautiful wings like all the other Nadas, I could learn to fly. I could fly to other mountaintops, higher mountaintops and see new things I never saw before. I could fly so high that I would be able to see the glaciers from above the mountains.” That idea excited Frio very much. “Why do my friends not use their beautiful wings and fly?” He wondered, “Why do they not use their beautiful wings to discover new things so far away and so high? Why do they not visit far away places that they would no long have to crawl to go to?” He was very confused, “They have beautiful wings, why do they not use them?” Frio was very curious, very curious indeed.
   One day Frio was huddled in a group of his friends and they were happy , all licking their favorite treat, frozen glacier icicles. Frio asked a very important question, which he had thought about all night long. “Nadas, my friends, I have seen each of you with very beautiful wings on your backs, with many colors and they are large enough that if you fluttered them, like when you get excited, and maybe jumped at the same time, you might just be able to fly!” The other Nadas looked at Frio in disbelief, but Frio continued, “Imagine the possibilities, imagine what you could see if you could fly high up in the air. You would no longer have to drag yourselves from place to place when you walked.” It made perfect sense to Frio and he only wished he also had wings to fly himself to show them. He closed his eyes and imagined flying over the glaciers and mountains. He imagined himself looking down into valleys with his big blue eyes and seeing so many new things that no one had ever seen before.                                                **********************************************
 
   The following is a recent article about Jim Killon and Changes for New Hope. It was published in Volunteer Match (volunteermatch.org) by their writer Laura Weiss.   

 
       

 Jim Killon with the children of 'Changes for New Hope' 
Jim Killon, Changes for New Hope
   In 2009, Jim Killon moved to Peru, where he started a nonprofit organization to help impoverished children in the Peruvian Andes. With no funding and no Spanish, everyone told him to give up and go home. Three years later, Changes for New Hope has reached hundreds of children and helped change their despair into real hope.





About Jim


By Laura Weiss
  
   After twenty years of working in sales, Baltimore native Jim Killon was so moved by the poverty in South America that he spent his life savings to start an organization to improve the livelihood of Peruvian children and permanently relocated to Huaraz, Peru.
  
   When he first arrived in Peru in 2009, Jim was not intending to start his own organization. But when he began working as a volunteer coordinator at an NGO, he was immediately disappointed with the way the organization was run. Disillusioned with the corrupt way funds were allocated and the volunteers who seemed more interested in partying than helping, Jim decided that he needed to do more.
 
  "I was not content to help a handful of children with their homework and send them on their way…These children wore rags; shoes were literally falling off their feet. They were suffering from malnutrition. Their hair felt like straw," Jim recalls.
 
   So in 2009 he began Changes for New Hope, a nonprofit organization focused on providing Peruvian youth opportunities and hope for a better future. "We had to start from scratch," he says. "Respect for themselves and each other became part of the program. Those who arrived simply for the hand-outs left as soon as they realized this was more than a give-away program. We were left with children who wanted to develop themselves into young men and women one day."
  
   As a start-up nonprofit in a foreign country, Jim faced challenges that to most people would seem insurmountable. "I had no idea how to read a menu or make a phone call," he says. "The culture and customs were all alien to me. When people told me they eat guinea pigs as food I thought they were kidding. When I found a chicken foot in my soup I was sure it was a prank... I was told I could never succeed."
   
   For Jim, the solution to the challenges he faced was passion. "My tenacity drew others to the project and we developed a solid base," he says. "Spanish can be learned, obstacles can be overcome. Naysayers go silent in the face of determination and success."
Jim spoke at language centers and universities in Peru to encourage more people to donate and volunteer for the cause. Local poster campaigns and testimonials from previous volunteers helped the project gain credibility and fodder.
  
  Jim's passion is obvious to everyone around him. According to Marlie Ferron, a former volunteer with Changes for New Hope, local Huaraz residents refer to him as "Crazy Jim."
"Not crazy as in psychopath or lunatic, or out of his mind, but crazy as in one in a million who dropped his life in the United States to come to Peru and just do his best with what he could, no questions asked," Marlie writes on the CNH blog.
  
  Whereas three years ago, Jim's life was about the big-city grind, he now spends his days teaching children about the nature that surrounds them and facilitating games of "Gringo Bingo," an English vocabulary game. He does art projects with the children, some of whom have never been able to draw with crayons and paper before.
At its inception, Changes for New Hope only reached one group of children, but now Jim works with three groups – about 90 children total. And that number is constantly growing. The program continually adapts to the different teaching styles and hobbies of its volunteers. Jim notes, "Each volunteer has some skill or ability that the children have yet to experience or try. The children are eager learners now and embrace new faces."
With the invaluable assistance of volunteers from the US, the UK, Australia and more, Changes for New Hope is able to add new ideas, projects, learning games and choices as materials and donations allow.
  
  Jim hopes that in future years, Changes for New Hope will be able to engage Peruvian families to create sustainable business models to raise themselves out of poverty. He hopes that future generations will be able to give their children more than they had as a result of Changes for New Hope. "Mostly, I am happy to see that, while poverty continues, the desperation mentality is slowly melting away… When people realize opportunities are available, hope replaces despair," he says.
  
  It is clear that Jim's life has changed as a result of moving to Peru. He lost 60 pounds after living on a Peruvian diet. He's forgotten what "turning on the heat" means. He hasn't driven a car in almost three years. But Jim wouldn't call these changes sacrifices.
  
  "I think that had I ever viewed it as a sacrifice, I may have been tempted to throw in the towel and head for a beach in Hawaii," he says. "The reward for me was seeing the results and development of the children and their families."
   
Jim's multifaceted efforts have transformed his life, but he describes it as a "win-win endeavor" that has opened his heart to the beauty and reward that comes from helping others.
  
 "No one is telling me to go home anymore," he notes. "This is home for me now."
 
   Laura Weiss interned with VolunteerMatch during the summer of 2011.



About Changes for New Hope


   Changes for New Hope reaches poor and underprivileged children and their families in the Peruvian Andes. Initially developed as an English language program, CNH has expanded to address hunger and health issues in Huaraz, Peru.
James Killon, Changes for New Hopec/o SerpostAncash, Huaraz, Peruwww.changesfornewhope.org
Check out Changes for New Hope opportunities at VolunteerMatch. 

     


Other Ways You Can Help
   There are many ways to further the project at Changes for New Hope and the publication and production of this book. Share us on Facebook, and other social media outlets, with your friends and suggest they share it as well. You can become a "Virtual Volunteer" right from your own home by supporting, sponsoring a child, fundraising, sending down materials and supplies, and spreading the word. 
   
   You can also come to visit us here in Huaraz Peru as an "On-The-Ground-Volunteer" and experience our day to day life, working in the villages we go to, meet the families and children and make a hands-on difference with us. Those who have volunteered with us have dispelled their pre-conceived ideas, renewed their faith in human kind, and come away with a deep feeling of accomplishment. One wonderful family actually blew off a cruise to Barbados to come volunteer with us. They left with no regrets and with great memories of their experience.  
  
   Please be sure to take a look at our web page at www.changesfornewhope.org. I would like for you to have  complete confidence in contributing to our campaign. There you will see some of our recent accomplishments. 
 
   You can also find us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/changesfornewhope. 
  Thanks for reading my campaign. I hope you will contribute and become part of the team. 
   Siempre~~~ Jim Killon

What is Talking Shop?

Talking Shop will be an online community of writers where members can experience the various facets of the writing life- business aspects, workshops, and camaraderie and commiseration- all in one place.

 

Why?

My transition from writing as a hobby to writing professionally was a rough one. At the time I lived in a very rural area without a writing community so I turned to online writing groups. Over the past 7½ years I have belonged to several. Each community had a specific focus. One focused largely on the business side of the writing life, such as how to query an agent. The second was a gathering place for writing mothers and there I found emotional support whenever a toddler meltdown ruined my precious writing time. The last group focused almost exclusively on workshop model and my writing greatly improved as a result.

However, meeting my writing needs in so many different places proved problematic; it was a chore. I've longed for a single online literary home. Other writers have, too. When I wasn't able to find one, I decided to create Talking Shop.

Combining the best aspects of the online writing communities to which I’ve belonged, a single visit to Talking Shop will enable a writer to learn about the business aspect of writing, get a piece workshopped by their chosen writing group, and be part of a community that is “soft place to fall.” In addition, Talking Shop will be able to grow, expand, and adapt to the various needs of its members.

 

How?

In order to accomplish Talking Shop’s various goals, we need a sophisticated forum software platform and a semi-dedicated server to handle the expected traffic. The software costs $285 and a month of server space runs over $60. To enable to group to get on its feet, I’m asking for one year’s worth webhosting or approximately $1000. This brings Talking Shop’s total goal to $1250.

If Talking Shop exceeds its fundraising goal, extra funds will provide forum support, extra months of server space, and expanded programs. 

 

Perks!

Levels 2-10 Perks (Reader-Vintage Level) require a valid, non-anonymous email address.

All books are on a first come, first serve basis and will be marked when no longer available. Once a donation is made, please email WritersTalkingShop (at) gmail (dot) com to request your chosen book and provide a mailing address.

Perks will be available within a month of the fundraiser's conclusion with the following exceptions: Valerie Fioravanti’s short story collection, Garbage Night at the Opera, will not be available until December.

Beta memberships will be available three months after the fundraiser’s conclusion. Thereafter, Talking Shop membership will be by invitation only.

Our eternal thanks and your name listed as a donor on the Talking Shop website.

An electronic copy of Sabra Wineteer’s award-winning short story, “A Siege of Herons” PLUS Level 1 perk.

A Talking Shop Beta membership PLUS Levels 1-2 perks.

(Beta memberships will be available three months after the fundraiser’s conclusion. Thereafter, Talking Shop membership will be by invitation only.)

On October 24th, at 12 noon, business magnate Donald Trump released a much hyped (by Mr. Trump) video. Check it out above.

We all know Donald is a bit over-the-top, but this time, he went to far.

Merriam-Webster defines a bribe as “money or favor given or promised in order to influence the judgment or conduct of a person in a position of trust; something that serves to induce or influence.”

On October 24th, at 12 noon, the most influential and widely recognized businessman in the world publicly offered a bribe to the President of the United States of America.

We are not affiliated with any political party. We are proud Americans who believe that our great nation deserves better.

We believe in two things:

  • The highest office in the nation is not up for sale
  • Real Americans do not require preconditions to do the right thing

We are calling on all Americans, Democrat, Republican, male, female, young and old - Help us OUTCLASS TRUMP!

Mr. Trump offered five million dollars in a garish political gimmick. We believe we can beat him. We are calling on everyone to donate what you can. Let’s show Mr. Trump what real charity is.

Our goal is $5,000,001. With no preconditions, all proceeds will be donated based on Mr. Trump’s recommendations: Boys and Girls Clubs of America, the American Cancer Society, and the AIDS Research Alliance.

Like Mr. Trump, we will also set a deadline of October 31, 2012.

And to you Mr. Trump, if you are willing to apologize to the American people for so publicly trying to use charity as a political weapon, and for trying to bribe the office of the President - we will let you match our donation.

We believe that charities should not be held hostage, and politics ought not be bought.

story:
I'm a former Canadian Track team member with two thrillers and one anthology. My biology degree helped me to write my first novel, Pandora's Succession. Fans of Robert Ludlum and Clive Cussler will love this breakneck thriller about a CIA operative who learns that the brutal weapons consortium that killed his fiancée has acquired a hyper-deadly microbe called Pandora. I've followed up with the anthology, Unsavory Delicacies, and the standalone thriller, Chill Run.

I need your help in helping me publish my upcoming thriller, The Demeter Code, which is the sequel to Pandora's Succession. I have a multitude of gifts to give to those who contribute.

I'm hoping to get a minimum of $3000 in order to cover the costs of production (editing, formatting, graphic cover design, printing) and promotion. Perks range from a "High Five", eBook and autographed glossy softcover copies, and even a cameo appearance in a future novel.

Both Pandora's Succession and Chill Run have over 50 reviews on Amazon.com, mostly 4-stars. They've also made the top 10 in the Thriller category on Amazon.

To make it easy for everyone to contribute, I've set the minimum very low. Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, etc, by using the Share tools. You can also spread the word offline. If ever I'm in your town, I'd be happy to meet you and give you a personal autograph.

Want to sample what I've written? Check out excerpts from PANDORA'S SUCCESSION and CHILL RUN.

Thanks for your support,

Russell.
